Overall the hotel was very nice and in a great location. You're close to shopping and a train stop. The hotel lobby was modern, check in was a breeze and breakfast was really good. When you go up to the rooms it's a different story. The hallways are a bit dated. Nothing like the lobby. Our room was a corner room and was smaller than I expected. It was a pretty simple room. Not much to it. There was a small corner window with a modest view of the city. My biggest complaint with the room was the bathroom. There was the most annoying humming noise that sounded each time you turn on the bathroom light. Of course when you're taking a shower and trying to do your hair and make up and get ready you can end up spending a lot of time in the bathroom. The sound was frustrating to deal with. For our one night stay the Sheraton satisfied our needs but overall didn't get a lot for the money.

This hotel is in an interesting part of town. On the edge of Chinatown and some good old fashioned Canal Street grittiness. But it is clean and quiet. I asked for a room on the back side of the hotel and was accommodated, albeit w/2 double beds instead of one king, but it was worth it. Good deal on Priceline - about $200/night. Can't do much better than this in NYC.

Purchased 2 nights here from Priceline where you must pay before you find out where you'll be staying. Having lived in downtown NYC for a combined 20 years between my husband and me, I was surprised to learn there was a Sheraton on canal. The location can't be beat for walking into soho and tribeca, and all major subway lines are accessible within a couple blocks. The staff were sweet and friendly and our room was very comfortable by city standards. Starbucks in the lobby is a bonus, as is the 24 hour deli directly next door. The staff were all incredibly friendly with our 3 year old daughter, with Eddie being the standout. This man takes serious pride in his job and it shows. Club level is lovely, views are fantastic. We can't wait to come back! Gave 5 stars everywhere except for regard to the rooms I gave 4. Reason is simply to bill yourself as a 4 star hotel, I'd expect higher quality and slightly larger towels than the standard thin jobs, and I wished they'd have offered robes, but that is nit-picky and for sure it gets an overall 5 for experience. This is our new go-to spot in NYC! Great place if you have a family and you're not hung up on trendy, boutique-y places (like we were pre-kids!)

Booked this hotel through points. The reviews were good so we went with it. Started weird. Our cabbie didn't know where it was and ended up dropping us a couple of blocks out. It's literally tucked away between the Canal st post office and a smoothie shop but once you find it, it's a welcoming site. Rooms were small but like all in NY space is a premium. The weirdest/coolest thing would be the half double doors leading to our 'closet washroom'! They made good on the small space as a full sized door would have been awkward. The place is prime for food (Pepolino Italian is highly rated on yelp and just around the corner), subway (between 2 train stops that give you quick access uptown if you need) and shopping (broadway has all your brand named shopping destinations). The only caveat is dont fall victim to the tons of street folks trying to pawn off fake LV, GUCGI, etc as they're right outside your door!!!!

Nice hotel at a perfect location for first timer New York tourist. Important notice: Upgrading to lounge level is both pleasant, cheap and conveniant. Breakfast with a view included. Free beverage and Wi-Fi 24-7. Light meal in the evening. All in all a bargin.

I like this hotel because the location is convenient and its one of the cheaper spg hotels in NY. I almost always check in late, rarely am up in time for the breakfast and am gone the next day. This past time was no different. I reserved the room the day of, as I tend to. We got the hotel after 1 am so checking in should have been a breeze. There was some issue with the computer system which was not their fault so it took quite awhile. Given the time, I was tired and just wanted to go to sleep. Since it was taking so long, the front desk clerk changed our room, saying I would "really like it." Given I'm a gold spg member, a basic room upgrade is expected anyway. When we got to the room, it seemed to be exactly the same as all the others I've stayed in there. Maybe it was a club floor, which I should get as a gold also. Either way, I wasn't impressed with how the delay was handled. The rest of the hotel was lovely. Clean, updated, as expected. The hotel bar looks nice, although I've never been at the hotel when it is open.Overall, I would recommend this hotel. The location and value are very good for NY. Maybe they could improve a bit on service, but at least they are trying.

This hotel is supposed to be a four star place, but feels more like a 3 star at best. Compared to other Sheraton Hotels or Resorts I have stayed in it feels like the poor relation. The hotel itself is almost brand new, but the decor and feel of the place are very dated. I did not get to meet the famous Eddie that everyone is raving about in previous reviews, but I personally found the staff lukewarm and with a touch of New York attitude. The booking form stated Bliss toiletries but they are in fact Sheraton toiletries. I'm still waiting for my promised checkout receipt by email.I did not have a good experience here and was completely stunned at the way I was treated after check in and very disappointed with the way the staff resolved the issue until a more senior manager was called (the security guy had a major sulk when I complained, and believe me I had good reason to), but trying to look at some plus points for the place, it is in a good location, close to transport, the rooms are clean, it's nice to have the Starbucks in the lobby. The only reason I stayed here this time and would suggest anyone staying here is due to the cheaper price compared to other hotels of the same rating in the city if you are on a budget. Personally I will be paying more next time and staying round the corner at SoHo Grand or Trump SoHo which are far nicer for not much more dollars.

This is an acceptable choice in New York but nothing more. The Chinatown location provides an alternative to the tourist-congested midtown neighborhoods. It's safe to walk around during the day but I wouldn't after dark. The lobby compares to other Sheratons but the sleeping rooms are furnished as a Four Points Hotel rather than typical Sheraton. Still it's clean and recently refurbished. The best part of the hotel is the club lounge with an outdoor patio overlooking the city.

I gave this property 2/5 about a year ago when I stayed here on business. After another stay, this time I give it a 3/5 - only for the super helpful bellmen. The rating didn't increase because the hotel has become a better value. But after staying at a number of other hotels in the city, I realize that you don't get much for a lot of money.Helpful tip: the Tribeca Deli next door has so much more variety and is 10x cheaper than the hotel when it comes to breakfast.What I did like this time- The bellmen out front worked hard to get the guests cabs. Awesome service.What I didn't like this time- There are only 2 check-in positions, so if you get behind a large group, you will be waiting for a while.Everything else was pretty average and unremarkable, thus 3/5.

On a recent trip to New Manhattan in February, my wife and I stayed in the Sheraton Tribeca on Canal Street. I don't think I have ever stayed in a hotel in New York City where the service was so good and the staff were so helpful. Anything we needed for the room, spacious by New York standards, and any directions or reservations were immediately taken care of. The location is perfect as all the major subway lines are within 200 yards of the hotel. A great location - walking distance to Brooklyn Bridge, China Town, and Greenwich Village. Could see the Empire State Building out our window. Best to book the upper floors and pay extra expense for the Club Room for breakfast and evening drinks.

Stayed for two nights in mid-March. Room was very clean and a decent size for the price. Front desk staff were always very helpful and accommodating. Didn't eat in the restaurant or visit the bar so can't comment on those. The location is both good and bad. Good in that it is on the south or SoHo and north of Tribeca so makes visiting either area just a short walk. Bad in that it is on Canal Street, which is a major thoroughfare so rush hour traffic noise can be loud (even on the 17th floor). Traffic noise subsided by late evenings so didn't impact sleep. One hint: If you are traveling uptown via cab from the hotel during the day, cross the street to catch a cab. There is a nasty intersection to the east of the hotel, traffic moves slowly and it is hard to make a left hand turn to go uptown so you will burn meter time just sitting. Whereas if you catch a cab across the street, one right hand turn and you are on 6th Ave. If heading downtown, walk left out of the hotel two blocks to Varick, which is one-way downtown.

This is a review of this hotel's management. Management fall way short of Starwood properties quality!I've stayed a couple times before at this property without issue. A little below most Sheratons I've stayed at but nice and friendly staff, especially in the Lounge. But then recently I had to request a change to my 4 nights reservation but was told I would be charged 1 night's fee even though I was still planning to stay 3 nights for the change. Didn't make any sense to me and my Starwood Ambassador agreed with me saying this property was known to be "difficult." So we change the reservation and I ended up with a new reservation at the Westin Times Square. I fully expect to take the 1 night charge, fair enough. But here is the issue. That was almost two weeks ago and I'm still trying to get a simple folio of my one night's charge. Both my Ambassador and I have requested the folio numerous times without results. Finally today I get an email with a folio dated 3 months earlier than the date requested. I'm not sure who is running this hotel but clearly it is not Starwood quality. I'm going to be Lifetime Platinum in about a year and not once over the last 10+ years have I ever had any issues even close to what I'm having with this hotel.

Had a great 4 night stay at this hotel with my daughter. Hotel is great location as very short walk into Soho, Chinatown, Little Italy, Ground Zero. We walked straight up Broadway to Times Square but subway just around the corner only takes 10 minutes. Rooms were a reasonable size and beds very comfortable. Staff really friendly and helpful, especially porter Eddie. Lots of places to eat nearby and Starbucks in hotel lobby. Would definately recommend!

I stayed here for the first time because one of my colleagues recommended it - and I'm glad did - it really changed my impression of the Sheraton brand which I considered properties that were old-fashioned and a bit run-down. This hotel is more like a Westin: modern design and features and a very comfortable bed! The location is great on the edge of Soho - easy to get a cab anywhere and within walking distance to some of the best shopping on the planet. The hotel lobby is compact but functional with a bar, work areas and thankfully, a Starbucks. My studio room was well appointed with a table for four and king bed and large desk. Met my key other criteria as well: lots of electrical outlets conveniently located, good shower as well as a large amount of counter space in the bathroom. I was on the club level - the breakfast in the club room was excellent - looks like there is a rooftop patio to enjoy in the warmer months. Very clean and well maintained property - I will be back! I rarely rate any property on Trip Advisor "Excellent" - but in this case, I think the property deserves it - the stay certainly exceeded my expectations.

Eddie, David, the Housekeeping Staff and Front Desk staff really work hard to make staying a great experience. So they get 5 stars! However, for the value, the hotel cannot completely deliver. The Club Room is not always perfectly clean and the furniture is worn and outdated. The rooms are fine, but for example when the bathroom fanlight is on the noise is deafening. The halls are super, super bright so it can be tough to sleep at night without eye shades. And the lobby is very low end Sheraton. If you drop the price by about $75 bucks a night then you have an amazing value and I would rate it higher. But as it is now, I can call it average.

I am currently staying in the Sheraton property in Tribeca and I have to commend one of the staff that really does an amazing job. His name is Eddie. Eddie has a warmth that makes every guest feel like a friend. He always has a big smile on his face, a warm greeting, and is quick to handle any task. Eddie reminds me of a book I read recently called Fred 2.0. The book is about a mail man that delivers amazing customer service and is loved by all the people on his route. It's a great book and Eddie has all the characteristics outlined in the book. If you're going to New York stay in the Sheraton Tribeca and you'll feel like you are staying with friends. Thanks Eddie for the great service.

Great location. Good service. Good sized rooms. We arrived late on a Saturday night and were given a room on the front of the hotel and told we could change it the next day of we found it too noisy. You could hear road noise, but it didn't bother us and was defintley worth putting up with for the view of the empire state building from the bed!Room was a lot bigger than other New York hotels we have previously stayed in and perfectly big enough for a weeks sightseeing and shopping.No pool or spa - there was a gym but we didn't use it - didn't eat in the hotel and only had a couple of drinks there. Free internet and printing in the hotel lobby was a nice touch though!Reception / conceirge were helpful.Good location near to 2 different metro lines, although road is a bit crazy to cross. Have previously stayed in Time Square and found Tribeca much calmer!Only slight issue was housekeeping - they seemed to clean our room at about 6pm each day which was odd. Often forgot things like toilet roll or cups. All fixed quickly by reception, but annoying to have to ask, especially when you come back late at night.

Very central location, friendly staff. We traveled with twin babies and needed two cots and they didnt make it a problem, its true that the room became a bit tight but it was good as we just went to the hotel to sleep.

The Tribeca is in the Soho region of New York, so very close to great restaurants and bars and quite a lively area. The hotel is excellent and the staff can't do too much to help you. I was at the Tribeca for business and had everything I could need, a good size room, comfortable bed, nice bathroom, Starbucks downstairs and good quality WIFI internet. Expensive hotel, but recommended.

A quick shout out to the excellent, friendly & helpful Doorman . . . most especially Eddie and David! Thank you for your advice throughout our week long stay. The location of the Tribeca Sheraton is perfect for walking to the Village, SoHo and Lower East side.

The rooms here are so small you'll have to leave your suitcase by the entrance. I realize that real estate is at a premium in Manhattan but that's also why hotels charge a premium price for otherwise average hotel rooms. This room was tiny as was the initial one I was put in which was directly above the gym. I could hear people running on the treadmill at 10 pm. It took a while and a sympathetic staff member to get moved.The Sheraton has lost it's appeal for me. Their prime was in the 80's, early 90's. Now this property giant feels like a fancy box of very plain chocolates. Meaning, it'll do but if you want something truly satisfying, look elsewhere. Try the NoMad.

Great location at downtown Soho with many good bakeries, delis and Dunkin's donuts with free wifi. Service was good, always ready to help me out with bags, travel adaptors and just general information.

Stayed here one night. Didn't expect much but this hotel and its staff impressed us in every possible way. First, front desk paid good intention on our preference. She even read our request out to make sure we got what we requested 100%. Secondly, the housekeepers were so friendly. We got ' hello ' with smile every time if happened to meet them in the hall way.Thirdly, the breakfast at the club floor was great in value and service. The quality was the best rank. Way better than many fancy hotel in town.In addition, you have Starbucks coffee in your room. Free wifi in the public area.The bell man was so nice and polite to assist you on direction, on luggage storage.On our departure date, we asked if we can have 30 mins late check out. Guess what, the front desk offered 1 hour, so we can relax for catching our transportation.Our heart was stolen by every little things they did to make you feel home, when you away from home!And we canceled other booking and book this hotel again when finish our work in Washington. Please do keep impressing your guests and keep such good service attitude and standard!And thank you ladies and gentlemen for such wonderful 23 hours stayed at your hotel.Finally, one suggestion for management team: if you have future renovation, do install double glasses window because it could be noisy in the early morning for busy traffic with trucks on canal street.

The service at this hotel has been excellent. I appreciate the early check in, the good housekeeping, and the front desk service. The location near Tribeca, Chinaton, and Soho is very good. Do not accept a room on the second floor. They are near the workout room and you can hear every step on the treadmill.

We made reservations via Travelocity-and arrived very late on a friday night. The people could not find our reservation-but I did have an e-mail response from my connfirming the reservation. The people could not have been more helpful and encouraging. Took care of it-without a worry. When we found that the restaurant was closed they helped us with local options that were perfect-even given the late hour. Everyone there was most polite and helpful. Now, being in NYC is not a common event for me-I live in rural Washington State--but I felt like we were well taken care of!BTW, Deon made our stay the best! He greeted us on arrival, and helped us out in early morning to find our way to the airport!

I was in town for business and the company requested that we stay at the Sheraton. Typically I stay at the Trump but this was for a special work function. The location is actually not bad, it's just not on a picturesque street. Chinatown is a few blocks east and Soho is right across the street. This is sort of a dead zone between neighborhoods.Rooms are small with no mini fridge or additional amenities beyond soap, shampoo, conditioner and lotion. The lifts are very slow; there are only three. Lobby is light and spacious and the staff is very nice and helpful.Now, here's the part that I think is very important. I became seriously ill the first night that I stayed at the Sheraton. I later learned that I had contracted Norovirus before my trip. I was so desperate that I called the front desk at 3 AM and asked if they could connect me with a doctor in the morning. They found a doctor to speak with me immediately and he advised me on what I could do in the meantime. I mean, it was literally the middle of the night and my only option at that point was to go to the emergency room. The doctor suggested I get the Sheraton staff to help - I called downstairs and James, who had connected me with the doctor, went out and fetched me a couple of items from the deli that the doctor recommended. He also asked if I wanted to be taken to the hospital. I declined and he came up and dropped off my things which did help get me through the night. In the morning, I visited a walk-in doctor who the front desk also recommended. I ended up cutting my trip short and flying home. My point is - they took care of me, specifically James. I was in serious pain and agony and I know the Sheraton staff would have brought me to the hospital if that's what I had decided. Huge props to James - consider Sheraton Tribeca your home away from home.

The hotel is located in a great location...SOHO, Little Italy, Chinatown. I drove to NYC for St. Patty's Day weekend, had no difficulties finding parking on a side street near the hotel. Upon arrival, the staff was very courteous and helpful. The lobby was amazing, definitely one of the standout amenities of the hotel since the room left much to be desired. In the lobby, there's a free internet lounge and a restaurant (we used neither service).The room itself can be described best in one word: SMALL. For the price, this was one of the tiniest hotel rooms I have ever stayed in. I've stayed in several hotels in NYC and particularly the SOHO area, and the room size undoubtedly failed to measure up to others. I would say that the room was really clean, had a large tv, and large windows, which let lots of sunlight in. Also, this room had a rather large, "chic/hip" bathroom, although, I would give a few square feet of the bathroom to in order to allow me to walk freely in the main sleeping quarters. I had a large king-sized bed, and it nearly took up the entire room.As others have noted, there is $10 fee to use the hotel's internet service inside the room...this struck me as very odd considering the price.Overall, this was a nice hotel, although, I probably would not stay here again considering that I've had bigger, better and cheaper hotel stays in the same area. This was a last minute trip, which unfortunately, did not leave me with many options for such a busy weekend.

What is a huge disappointment. The Room: so tiny. Facilities are all of pretentious timber and shoddy quality. Bed linens are hard. Shampoos and bath gel are among the worst supplies of their kinds. Shower area is spacious for 1 medium-sized adult only. The commode is so tiny and uncomfortable. Before turning you back in the bathroom, exercise caution so that you do not knock your elbow onto the wall. The View: stayed in a higher-view room. The promised view was offered, but not so impressive at all. New York, as a city, does not live up to its reputation at all when observed in reality. This city only appears beautiful on pictures. Forget the SOHO area (which is just opposite this hotel. Oooh, you will understand what a shabby neighborhood the real SOHO is. Don’t buy the hypes about it on travel magazines. Pretentious, hollow, themeless are the very adjectives for the real SOHO). The Services: almost non-existent. Made a phone call for some fork, but waited almost an hour to receive nothing but a rhetorical question “Did you ever request that?” on my following-up call for enquiry. Sheraton: train you staff twice, please. The Staff: 75% of them are impolite. Talking to each other all the time. Giggling foolishly in front of checking-in guests for no reason. Making exaggerated gestures by hand in the air during nightly shifts (some brown-skinned lady in an ill-fitting suit). The Lobby: just crammed and disagreeable. The Internet Surfing Area suffers heavy draughts all the time from the door, which is opened from time to time because of the human traffic flowing in and out. At a winter night, it is a suffering to be sitting over there to check emails online. The Conclusion: this hotel is, in reality, a 2-starred property (at most!!!), despite of its 5-star price.

Stayed here for the Big East tournament and a hockey game this past weekend. We wanted to stay somewhere different in the city so we choose tribeca/soho area. We love this part of town being walking distance from the trade center, soho shopping and restaurants it was great. The A,C,E trains were a block away, the 1 train was maybe 2 blocks. That made it easy to head midtown to Penn Station and go to MSG. The only problem I had was the first night we were there we had gone to the hotel bar late after the Georgetown game on Friday. The bartender was the worst. We asked him if they were serving food still, he turned and told us the kitchen was closed and walked away. A few minutes later he's putting pretzels and peanuts in front of some other people. Where the hell was our pretzels, I wasn't asking if the kitchen was open because I was curious. I had to pretty much throw my empty glass at him for him to get the clue that I'd like another. Needless to say, no tip for the amateur.Besides the bartender, the rest of the hotel was nice. The rooms were small but the bathrooms were really nice, great showers. Cleanliness was great and the beds were pretty good too. Kitchen closes at 11 p so if you want something to eat, you need to go elsewhere. Price was typical of a clean modern New York hotel. Parking is an issue, there is none. We took the Metro North train in so we didn't have to bring the car. There is paid parking everywhere and the hotel does offer valet for $50 a day but if you show up during the day on a weekday forget trying to park the thing. Canal street is a little busy. I would recommend this hotel to stay for a fun weekend in the big city.

Stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca for 3 nights this week. Was generally disappointed with the stay... nothing bad about the place, per se... just nothing special, either. It's decidedly "eh" in just about every aspect.Price we paid was quite high, though its NYC. For $300+/night I'd expect better.Check in was fast and painless. Desk staff, though not overly friendly, were helpful enough by NY standards. Doormen were helpful in finding taxis, though I thought it was interesting that they were always quite quick to push us towards using a private car, which was almost always parked nearby... I'd have to think they have a "relationship" with the drivers of the private cars.Room's tiny. Only hotel room I've ever stayed in that was smaller was in Hong Kong. It was pretty much walk in, trip into bed. Barely room for much else. I barely spent any "down time" in the room, because it was so tiny it was either lay in bed, or don't be there, realistically.Club lounge is a joke. Not sure if it's domestic and/or Sheraton, as I've spent lots of time in Marriott lounges, but it was tiny, and the appetizer offerings were essentially a small plate of cheese and some crackers. Beer, wine, cocktails were all charged for, not complimentary, as in other lounges I've been to. It does have a nice view, though.Downstairs lounge is okay - a "business center" (more like a internet cafe in the lobby). Have to be a registered guest to use internet at $9.99/day. Lounge itself is kinda open and jammed right off of the lobby, meaning its bright, loud, and not great for unwinding with friends or colleagues at the end of the day. Bar staff are effective, though not remotely friendly or engaging.Hotel doesn't have 24 hour room service. When returning late one night from meetings and asking for a menu, I was told I could walk down the street and get something on W. Broadway.But its the little things that make or break a hotel. Over a 4 day, 3 night stay, the hotel didn't once replenish my bathroom amenities. A little bar of soap only goes so far, and so by the morning of my last day, I was squeaking by on a tiny sliver of soap, wondering what I'd done to make the cleaning staff mad at me.In short, I'll be staying elsewhere next trip, and will probably reconsider staying at Sheratons again...

The Sheraton is in a wonderful location – on Canal Street. Walking distance to a fabulous shopping district. Plenty of bars, restaurants and cafes right on your doorstep.The hotel is clean, nicely furnished and with very nice complimentary toiletries in the bathroom. My only issue is the lack of a minibar. I like to keep a supply of drinks, fruit, nibble etc for the late night jet lag pangs of hunger but there was no fridge to store anything.Lack of mini bar aside this was a good price for a decent hotel and an excellent location.

I was over in NY for work and do not usually stay at the Sheraton but my usual hotel was fully booked and the Sheraton did not let me down.The hotel is clean and welcoming, the room was of average size and the bed pretty comfy - which is just what I needed after a day of shopping and drinks.The concierge was extremely friendly and helpful - definitely a credit to the hotel as he was happy to advise on a number of areas to go. Unfortunately not all of the staff were that friendly. I watched one of the receptionist start an argument with a guest - so obviously not a great first impression.All in all though, the hotel is fine to stay in and located in a great area to explore the sights of Soho/ Tribeca and it is right next to the subway to get all over the city.

Sheratons are Sheratons - this one is no different from others. Except: its location is great, near Soho, Tribeca and financial district, in walking distance to great reataurants and Chinatown. Staff is not overfriendly, but ok, food is nothing for gourmets, but fair enough, and if you can argue hard enough for a good deal you get a decent hotel for a decent charge.

I have to say that the clerk at check-in was quite friendly. As we didn't mind a street view room (which she warned could be noisy), she upgraded us to a deluxe king. It had a beautiful view of the Empire State Building and cityscape. The room was not very large even being a deluxe but that is to be expected in New York. The room rate from priceline was $139.00 so it was very inexpensive by New York standards. The hotel was in decent condition and was overall average. My issue was with the location of the hotel. It really is kind of off the beaten path. You really are not near anything of interest and have to walk a number of blocks before you get to something interesting like Little Italy. Overall it was pretty decent and I would stay there again if price were an issue as there were no issues with cleanliness, etc. but if price were not an issue, my personal preference would be to stay more in the thick of things. When I'm in the city, I want to be "in the city".

Easy access to soho, little Italy and Chinatown! We stayed 3 nights in room 512 overlooking a neighboring condo. It was quite and pleasant, we did wish for a bathtub, but other than that, the room was well appointed. Small, as all standard rooms are in Manhattan. If you've seen Times Square and Midtown on your first trip here, it's a good spot to go on your second trip to NYC. Right on Canal street, it's easy to get just about anywhere by taxi or subway too. Lots of great restaurants within a shirt walk thought, and higher end clothing in soho. Prices at the bar are crazy high though. There's a more reasonable pub around the left. TriBeCa Bagel store right around the corner is also a great spot to get beer and of course - great bagels!I would stay here again without hesitation. Another great Sheraton Hotel.

This is a wonderful, jewel of a hotel bordering Chinatown, SoHo, Tribeca. Great neighborhood. The hotel itself is excellent--reasonably priced, well cared for, easy to navigate, and perfect for business traveler. The staff is terrific, in particular Mike Valentin is one of the best bellman--helpful, arranges car service, cabs, luggage, and he always makes you feel very welcome. Michael the manager also excellent--he to makes you feel at home. I find all of the front desk staff particularly welcoming and helpful, and that is true of the bell staff as well. Housekeeping terrific. Overall this is a great property and a worthwhile value hotel in New York, in a very fun neighborhood.

I appreciate the kindness and professionalism of all staff: a true team spirit to customer service. I arrived 1 hour earlier than the check-in,Yvonne at the front desk asked to deliver my room faster and came to meet me several times to see if waiting does not bother me .. . I've forgotten my phone charger , the smiling and effcient Eddie found one for me in less than 10 minutes . The dynamic Asian doorman gave me back me a gift that I have loosed for 24 h ... The bartender prepares cocktails with great seriousness and remade the world with you. Organized for my return a bit in a hurry,Michael found me a kind of limo to accompany me to the airport for almost the price of a taxi ... My room was quite spacious for NYC with a beautiful view of the city. The bedding was of very high quality. There is a Starbucks in the lobby, very convenient .... The quality of this hotel is undeniable, but you can have the most beautiful hotel in the world if the staff is not efficient, benevolent and smiling ... it is just a place to sleep. Here, there is a multi-ethnic team which has obvious pleasure to work together and is proud to do its job to satisfy fully their guests. It's to live moments like this that I love NYC! Thank you for everything and see you soon at the Sheraton Tribeca.

I stayed at the Tribeca Sheraton for a couple of days last week and though I got it for around $200 ( which is pretty amazing for NYC) I can't help but feel that the property has almost zero characterThere isn't anything really negative to say but the property seems to typify the direction Sheraton's seem to be taking.Dull.Functional.Reasonable location.A "Hotel by numbers".The room was small ( but hey its NYC), and clean but felt completly anonymous. It could have been a Four Points. In fact the Four Points properties in the city ( the Chelsea property comes to mind) have far more character: better bar, more engaged staff and a bit less of a suburban industrial park vibe.If you stay at the Tribeca, you'll get decent value for NYC but not much more than a functional place to put your head down.My stay is already vanishing from memory.

Whenever someone visits New York City, I always recommend that they stay in a hotel on the island of Manhattan. It makes a big difference! And this hotel is a good option for anyone wanting to visit NYC.The only complaint I have is that there isn't free Wifi in the rooms, only the lobby. But that's not a huge deal.The staff was very friendly and the room was very clean and comfortable. We had no problems at all.

We got this hotel for under $150 on a Saturday night. It is right on Canal Street, but literally around the corner from the Soho Grand. I thought of it as a Soho hotel at Chinatown prices!!! We only stayed one night, and didn't experience many of the amenitites because we were more interested in going out in Soho. The staff was very nice, but the reception area could use a redesign. There were a few people checking in and the way the line works it blocks the front door. Besides that everything else was excellent. The room was nice, and what you would expect from a Sheraton.

This hotel was great. The staff goes out of their way to make you happy! They upgraded me to the club floor which included free wifi, a full breakfast, snacks in the afternoon, free bottled water and soft drinks/coffee all day. They also sent me a bottle of champaign and a cake for my birthday. The room was clean and comfortable, shower was great. I would defiantly stay here again. I had been a bit concerned about the Canal St address but it was safe and made it easy to buy some cheap pocketbooks : )4

This was the first time I stayed this far downtown. Not everyone will like it, but it is close to my favorite parts of New York-China Town, Soho Greenwich Village.The rooms, while not big, were larger than many that I've had in NY. The service was excellent, everyone was very friendly. I even got a hand-written thank you note from the room attendant, Jackie, for leaving a tip.The only reason I didn't give a 5 was that our room was right across the hall from the elevator and one could hear the people getting on and off- also the street noise was loud on Saturday night until about 1:00 am.I got the room through Hotwire- I would definitely stay here in the future.

I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking to find some of the real treasures in lower Manhattan. This is perfectly situated, easily accessible to Chinatown and Little Italy. The Club Lounge is great with stunning views. A large informal group of college friends just got together at the hotel and everyone loved it!! Great job!!

This was my first trip to NYC and I did enjoy the area where the hotel was located and it's access to subway was pretty close.The hotel room was designed exceptionally well with all the amenities I'd want in a hotel room! One of the key metrics for me is clean room and the Sheraton gets a 5/5 there! The room is well appointed and the bed was super comfortable plus the hotel staff were super efficient and friendly with all interactions!The only downside I'd suggest was the room was one of the smallest hotel rooms I've ever stayed in with the exception of a trip to Hong Kong!

I loved staying at this hotel, it is just a very confortable hotel, with great services, a Starbucks inside, also a bar for happy hour drinks in the lobby. The location is great for travelers who wish to be away from the busy Times Square and hang around SOHO, that's the reason I chose this place, and was very pleased with my choice. Bad news is that there's no free wifi in the rooms, only in the lobby, and breakfast is not included, but that's kind of common for NY City right?

I stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca over the Presidents Day long weekend. I got the reservation through the name-your-own-price feature on Priceline.I was impressed by the great customer service. The staff were all very friendly. I really appreciated that the management followed up by emailing me after I requested my room to be cleaned but had accidentally left the do not disturb sign on the door. It was really above and beyond what they needed to do.The location is also quite convenient. There are tons of restaurants and bars in the immediate Tribeca and Chinatown areas. It is also a short walk to the A, C, E, 1, N, R, Q and 6 lines.The are a little small, even for New York. But, they appear to be recently renovated and very clean. The bed was quite comfortable. The single king room I had, though, did not have a tub, just a shower stall. Also, my room did not have a refrigerator.All in all, I would definitely stay there again.

As a frequent guest of the SPG group worldwide I have become a bit sensitive about level acknowledgement and basic treatment. As I checked in on Saturday past I asked what kind of room would be given to me, since there was zero status recognition at the front desk. I was assured that I was getting the best room on hand...that basic (!) room just happened to be on the 9th floor, no view and exactly across from the elevators! As a platinum member I decided NOT to accept that room and went back to the front desk to hear that there were just "too many platinum members (!!!)" and no upgrades were possible. I enquired about a room away from the elevators and was made to to wait another 30 mins. (!) ,without as much as a complimentary drink or apology. I got another basic room, no. 1514. I checked on the net and saw that at least the patio rooms were available, but not offered! At that point I was upset enough to decide that this property would be added to my NYC-SPG blacklist! There was absolutely no reason for me to reconsider this hotel, save Corey the concierge and the lady that checked me out yesterday morning and seemed to care whether I had a good stay or not! To add on to this my wife realised that she had left her flat iron in the room, that had still not been given to lost and found. We called, spoke to Kevin and were informed that should it turn up, the shipping/mail cost to Harlem would be debited to my credit card on file....how helpful...cannot account for it, but ready to bill it!

We did not stay at this hotel but had a very disappointing experience while trying to, thanks to the night manager, James. After missing the last train back to LI and not being able to get a friend's car out of a closed parking lot, we found ourselves searching for a hotel room at 2am. James reported there being no rooms available, refused to let us use the bathroom until we begged, offered a room at a ridiculously inflated rate 20 minutes later as we pondered our misfortune, rescinded that offer when we refused that rate, and then instructed his staff to stop looking on the computer for alternative lodging options. No one wore name tags, so we did a little research today to find out but perhaps this is the mentality of this Starwood location- no need to be helpful, honest or accountable. VERY DISAPPOINTING!

We love SoHo and needed a weekend getaway. We booked this hotel via Priceline and was nervous bc it was the lowest amount we ever paid for a NYC hotel. We read the reviews and felt good about it. When we got there (during a blizzard) the staff was extremely happy & helpful. The check in area and lobby were basic but very clean and likable. There was a business center in the lobby that had free computer use and free wifi. The bar looked very nice but we did not use it. The room was perfect for what we needed. I am used to NYC smaller rooms and I felt this was bigger than most. They were very clean. The bed was super comfy. I appreciated the blizzard views from the huge windows. It was a very quiet hotel with no sound coming from the room above or the hallways. We had to stay an extra night bc the roads to get back home were closed due to the blizzard. A simple call to the front desk fixed that with another reasonable rate.As far as location goes it was great. Greenwich Village, China Town, Little Italy and all the SoHo boutiques all within walking distance. Perfect access to subways right on Canal with an easy ride to the Flatiron District. Plenty place ps to shop, eat , drink and be merry. I think the price along with the great location will mean more overnights in Soho in the very near future.

We had a room on the 18th floor, which looked towards the west. We had nice Hudson River views and could watch the traffic landing at Newark pretty easily. The location was nice for access to the stores and restaurants around downtown, including some places we went like "Blue Note" and "Comedy Cellar". Also highly recommended nearby is the International Culinary Institute.The hotel itself has a small lobby, but it is functional with a bar and Starbucks. There is a deli next door if you want a bagel for brekkie. The room is a tight squeeze. But it is functional. The bed was extremely comfortable. There was a safe in the room, and the shower had ok pressure. However, it was only and overhead with no handheld. The staff was very helpful and very nice and we did not experience any problems. But a friend staying at the hotel around the same time did. Also, note that the rooms are cleaned late in the day, so if you are in and out, you may not see your bed made until much later.The price of the hotel (a prepay off the Sheraton website) could not be beat. And for the overall value, it was quite a pleasant stay. We stayed for a whole week.

We stayed at this hotel and upgraded to the club level. The view was nothing to speak of, but the too was nice. We did stay there 4 nights and had to request our room to be straightened 2 of those nights and the last day we got to the end of the toilet paper roll with no replacement in sight. The staff was great, very friendly, but all the advice we got from the concierge and doormen was bad so don't ask for food, attraction, or transfer advice.

Went to NYC with my husband for my birthday this past weekend and booked this room about 3 moths ago through Priceline. After a while, we were a little worried about some of the complains here about how small the rooms were, etc, and thought: "Oh well, we had a great deal and don't think it will be that bad." We just want to say we loved our stay! The lobby was very nice, warm and clean, we were greeted by the staff immediately and even though we got there about an hour later, we were in our room in less than 10 minutes. The hallway was really quiet the whole weekend, even though it looked like it was packed. The room was on the 9th floor, it was clean and the size was perfect for the two of us, and I have stayed in smaller rooms in previous visits to NYC and pricier than this one. Looooved the king super comfy bed! We even found a sweet note from the maid which we thought was a very nice touch. Staff gave an excellent service and were super friendly. The hotel was really accessible to the subway, shops and restaurants. We do recommend this hotel and would stay again next time we visit!

Stayed here over MLK weekend (Sat & Sun) for $160 per night booked directly. This place is in a great location, tippy top of Tribeca on Canal Street. Small hotel, small lobby, small hotel bar and restaurant - not a "scene" type of place which suits me fine. The deluxe room was very nice and stunningly clean; I was not prepared to be so impressed! Quiet!! The front desk staff and doormen were helpful and pleasant - I valeted my car. Walking distance to tons of great restaurants and places of interest. I visited the 9/11 Memorial. Will definitley stay again and would highly recommend.

This is a good option in the Tribeca area, within walking distance of stacks of restaurants and shops. Reception staff were friendly and the room was clean and well maintained. We were on quite a high floor and the room was nice and quiet, and got warm quickly when we escaped in from the January cold. The room wasn't massive but big enough for a long weekend and great value.No free wifi in the room but free computers and wifi in the lobby were an acceptable option. All in all a good option that I think we are likely to be returning to.

I recently spent three weeks at this hotel to attend an education program intensive at NYU Stern and to conduct a week of business. Walking distance to NYU, local shopping delights of Greene Street, Mercer and Broadway and restaurants. A short cab ride to the meat packing districts. Canal Tube Street is only one block away.They also provided a comparative group hotel deal for my Class that provided us with a convenient location, discounted restaurant, free wifi and gym access throughout our stay. Late bookings and transfers were kindly provided by Nicole and her team for fellow classmates. Quiet Rooms were provided away from noisy elevators and close to our class colleagues for late night study sessions. Their security service is excellent and the team received a number of international packages for my work and provided safe delivery to my room. A convenient location for client meetings against an intensive study schedule and a friendly and warm front desk and concierge service greeting you throughout the day and providing necessary directions and recommendations for local restaurants, entertainment and shopping districts. Grub hub provides secure delivery of a wide variety of local restaurants to your hotel room. The in room dining experience is average but Starbucks certainly makes up for that in terms of quick bites and decent coffee from 6.30 am-8pm.The only downsides are that late night services can be very slow. I would highly recommend Sheraton TriBeCa for anyone seeking great service, convenience to NYU and close locaction to night life and the local fashion districts.

Been in many of SPG properties in the big Apple in the last year , W Times Square , Element Times Square , Sheraton Times Square and passing by the Four Points in the city I will Conclude ... There is a good atmosphere , and relatively tidy rooms , when you return it feels good compare to the other SPG properties I mentioned. (If you like the area)It is not the perfect place , front desk people don't count so much if you are Platinum member , and if they will , the suites are not attractive .. I would recommend to ask for a room in High Floor with good view . (they have few rooms with floor to ceiling windows)Concierge staff are really nice and make you feel very welcome .The lounge Breakfast is reasonable , but in the evening they will charge you for Alcohol (Apparently something common in NYC).Overall I had ambivalent feeling to that hotel , but after visit his "Brothers" I run back and felt good.

The staff at this hotel was so friendly, they made me feel like a celebrity! Upon check in, they upgraded my room for free, just to be nice. ( Thank you Esther ! ). What's more, they let us check in early and because my wife was slightly ill on our check out day, allowed us to check out late as well, with no added cost. After we checked out, they also let us store our luggage for the day so we could enjoy the city.

The location at this hotel is great. It borders Tribeca, Soho, and Chinatown. Canal Street is always busy, and as a single woman walking alone at night I didn't feel threatened. The subway is just around the corner, and the deli directly next to the hotel is 24-7 and pretty decent. The staff is super nice, the rooms are large for NYC, the hotel lobby is clean, the beds are very comfy, and the city views are wonderful. Heating and cooling is good, and city noise is minimal. My only complaint is that my bathroom smelled like a sewer: I think the drain in the tub was hooked up to something deadly - it was clearly coming from the shower. Aside from that, it was excellent. I would stay again.

This hotel was awesome. And, to put it into perspective, we travel to NYC frequently and stay at many hotels. This one was in a terrific location, well connected to subways and nearby canal street (Chinatown, little Italy, and Soho shopping!). It was also a short walk to the fabulous Broadway shops in Soho that I love so much. The lobby was beautiful and clean, with some free computers and a starbucks to give you that little pick-me-up at the end of a day filled with exploration. Staff was kind and concerned; as soon as you walk in the door, everybody's smiling and greeting you. I also got a courtesy call from the front desk, asking me if I happy with my room. Speaking of which, the room itself was surprisingly big for a New York hotel, and the bathroom was also large and clean. I felt that it was a sophisticated, well-equipped room. Despite this hotel being in the center of all the action, we found the room itself to be completely quiet, even thought we were only on the 6th floor. I slept like a baby and woke up incredibly well-rested the next morning. I highly recommend this hotel and would be happy to stay here again.

We stayed for one night to attend a wedding. Excellent service, nice room - not too big but not too small either. People are very nice. The reasons I gave it 4 stars instead of five were: wifi in the rooms is not free (although it is free in the lobby); housekeeping people were a little too loud in the morning, and valet parking was too expensive with no in-and-out privileges.

This hotel really has a lot going for it. It's in a great location, walking distance to tons of great restaurants and shopping. If your SPG platinum they have a wonderful club lounge on the 21st floor that overlooks Midtown. The appetizers and breakfast they serve are at least as good as other Sheraton club lounges. The staff that works the club lounge is very engaging and eager to help you with anything that you need. Unfortunately being right on Canal St, the rooms in the front of the hotel can be very loud, however these rooms also tend to be bigger and are also the rooms with a view. The rooms in the back of the hotel are very quiet, however they are some of the smallest hotel rooms I have ever stayed in. They also have a view of a building across the street making them very dark day or night.Overall this hotel is alright, if you can get a good price and aren't planning to spend time in you room doing anything but sleeping it can truly be a great place to stay

I took my mom to NYC for her 60th birthday. It was a blast. My mom is a shopper, so roaming the shops in Soho was equally as much fun for her as passing all the street vendors on Canal. We took the subway everywhere except to the airport. We hopped on the subway for quick transport to various midtown attractions. The club lounge served as fueling station as we viewed the city and mapped out our day. The hotel was perfect for us. The only drawback is deserted streets at night. We were safe, but erie when few people are on the street. The N/R line is two blocks from the hotel, so quick and close.The ACE is closer around the corner too, but we rarely used it.

I have stayed several times at the Sheraton Tribeca, always in a business travel. It is a very nice hotel, quite small for New York standards, with a superb location if you are looking for staying around downtown, Soho, Tribeca, Chinatown or Village. The rooms are very clean, and small as many of the New York hotels. There is only one restaurant, but plenty of excellent dinner choices nearby. Being such a small hotel in a big chain, gives you a sense of more personnal attention, distinct of the huge Sheraton hotels in midtown. It is a very nice choice to stay in south Manhattan.

If you’re a looking for a good hotel in midtown, this is a good spot with a great value (for NY).You are just minutes away to Tribeca, Soho, Chinatown and little Italy. Of course this hotel isn't the newest one, but your get a good room, for a reasonable price.

Nice hotel. Best part was check in with Ivonne (think that is how its spelled). Upgraded and given club service. Made the night and next morning extra special. View was amazing and the service at the hotel is top notch! Again a sincere thank you to Ivonne and all else there. Would absolutely go back as the location is fantastic as well.

Generally one of the least expensive of comparable hotels. Has a club room with complimentary heavy appetizers (evenings) and breakfasts for those with Starwood status or staying in club level rooms. Friendly staff, accomodate early check in. Reasonable walk or short subway ride to financial district. Very close to subway. Approaching from the west the neighborhood may look a bit sketchy. Good Japanese restaurant right around the corner. Have stayed here several times and will be back.

This hotel was in a great location. We had a great 5 day stay from 1/12/13-1/16/13. The staff was super friendly. If you're not familiar w/ NYC prices, be prepared for $$$ at the bar. We got a deal at $160 per night. The little deli out the front door to the left is VERY good...$1 for a bagel.

The entire staff of this hotel is first rate. Friendly and helpful. The lobby was nice. Our room was nicely appointed and very clean. It was quiet at night. The subway is close by. For NYC the room price was not out of line. Here is the only negative, this hotel may be technically in Tribeca but the neighborhood is Chinatown not Tribeca. You can walk to Tribeca shops and dining, but when you walk out the door of this hotel, you are in Chinatown.

I stay at this hotel frequently for business. It is a great location right on the edge of SoHo and Tribeca. Very accessible to transit. Great shops and restaurants are plentiful and Little Italy is a quick walk away as well. Staff is always friendly and helpful every time I pass through the lobby. Nice resaurant and bar on site and a little bodega is next door if you forgot anything. Not always the cheapest but if you hit it at the right time, totally worth a little extra.

Stayed here Dec 29-Jan 4 as part of honeymoon trip. The location is perfect as it is away from the noise of the big city. To get into the middle of the lights & noise is only a $10 cab or a train trip with the subway just around the corner from the hotel.Customer service was very good in all areas. Upon check in we were provided a complimentary upgrade to a club room on the top floor of the hotel. The front of house staff were very accommodating in looking after the needs of their guests. I will put this down to the "tipping factor". We did tip when we believed we were looked after very well. In turn the service was exceptional and the front of house staff were happy to stop and say g'day to us when we went in and out.I'm sorry, if people review rooms and say it is spacious. We had a club room and to have room for the luggage and to walk around the bed, we had to leave clothes in suitcases to get by. Hate to think what size their standard rooms are. I won't call it a negative, but just bear in mind it is just a room to sleep in and to get you out and visit the city, which we did.Ask for an upgrade to a club room but you work out if it will be value for money. The views from the top floor were awesome early morning and late at night. You have access to the club lounge which provides complimentary coffee, light snacks and non alcoholic drinks. You will be paying for your alcoholic drinks. I'm no alcoholic, but I believe that if you are paying for club privileges, you should be provided the courtesy of a complimentary alcoholic beverage or two seeing as you are going to pay a higher room rate. Room size is also not great for a club room. I will say the complimentary in room wifi and complimentary breakfast went a long way in making our stay in New York awesome.For a city like New York, the price we paid for our stay during maybe the busiest time of the year, we did get value for money. Would I go back and stay? Yes, based on inexpensive stay in clean room.

Are you an unpretentious traveler? Do you like to stay in the part of the city that is hip and near the new pulse, rather than an old heart that is solid, still ticking, but from another era? This is a great hotel. You can walk anywhere. Long hauls? The subway is around the corner. Really, a great place with excellent management. You may need to press a bit to get what you need, but the young staff is all too willing to accommodate your needs.

Great location and very accommodating staff. Dog friendly.Rooms are spacious and clean, nice property. Valet parking,coffee maker in room. Free Wi-Fi in lobby & Starbucks coffee. Definitely recommend !

Just did a girls trip to NYC and really enjoyed our stay at the Sheraton Tribeca. Our room with double beds was more spacious than what I've come to expect from most NYC hotels, very clean with super comfy beds and pillows, floor to ceiling window which helps in smaller spaces, didn't hear noises from other rooms and when you put out the "Do Not Disturb" sign, housekeeping will not be knocking in early a.m. Great location to just head out the door and explore, a few minutes to Chinatown, Little Italy, Greenwich Village & SoHo-barely scratched the surface of the surrounding area in 3 days. Subway station is very close so easy to access and convenient to hotel. Would definitely stay here again!

nice size room, clean, very good bathroom. great location- 1 block to subway. walked all around tribeca, soho, little italy, chinatown which is easy to do in 1 day from this location. excellent staff, helpful concierge. internet costs but free in lobby- lots of computers and a starbucks. concierge level breakfast worth it. ate in the area, just like a local, and took subway to midtown.

good location, near to my favorite places at NYC, soho, Tribeca and west village, must visit meatpacking and chelsea. recomend this hotel because of relative fair cost and locazation. need to have free internet at rooms.

We stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca during a post-Christmas getaway this winter. The hotel is newly remodeled and nicely appointed. The location is fantastic, being just a couple blocks away from great restaurants in Tribeca and great shopping in Soho. The hotel room was small by most standards, but for Manhattan it seemed luxuriously large. Our room was right by the elevator, and we were worried about the noise, but it didn't seem to be too big of a problem. My only complaint was that the air conditioning seemed to kick on when you lowered the temperature in the room. Had this been July, I would have understood, but this was January.

Booked a night for a Saturday and unfortunately got the flu. I attempted to cancel 36 hours prior to check -n. Somehow I was booked (unbeknownst to me) in a non-refundable room (I thought that only happened with airfare?). I called a plead my case to the staff and I was told no. It wasn't a 'very sorry' type of no. It was "this is your fault because you booked a non-refundable room'. I have stayed in hotels all over the world and I have never encountered a more unfriendly or stranger hotel situation EVER. I am honestly shocked by the whole experience.

The TriBeCa area is described as "lively and bohemian" which I now know is estate agent speak for an area which is noisy and where drugs and knock off goods can be purchased freely on any street corner. During my walk from the Canal Street subway station to the hotel (approx 5 minutes dragging a large suitcase) I lost count of the number of times I was approached with the word "Rolex?" There were either 10 guys or just the same guy going round and round in a scene reminiscent of the Bagpuss chocolate biscuit factory (Brits in their mid thirties should get this reference).The hotel itself is fairly new and the room was nice if somewhat small, but then that's New York for you. I was quite disappointed with the toiletry haul - only shampoo, conditioner, moisturiser and soap. No sewing kit or bonnet de douche as Del Boy might say. After all, a girl can never have too many shoe sponges.The room I was in (210) was fairly noisy, being positioned next to the lift, and from the sounds of it, directly above the set of Jumanji. The jungle drum noises I heard between 8 and 9pm were either over enthusiastic workmen, or a couple with a lot of stamina - if that's the case then sir, I salute you. Between 9pm and 2am I was treated to the sound of the lift doors opening and closing sporadically and several conversations held in loud American voices. A special thanks to the man who thought 1.30am was an appropriate time to have a chat with his mates directly outside my door. His review may mention the wild haired harridan who threw open the door demanding he keep his voice down. Quick note to new couples on a romantic getaway - the double door to the bathroom has a large gap in it which could let unwanted smells and sounds filter through - not ideal on a first minibreak together. Also there was no bath in my room which was slightly disappointing, having been washed onto some coral the week before in the Caribbean I was hoping to soak my wounds. However, overall the hotel was nice, the staff were helpful, room service was good although I made the mistake in my post US Immigration shell shock of tipping twice on room service as I didn't check whether tip was already included.

Rooms here are what New York is all about----closet sized but clean and comfortable. The room barely fit the queen sized bed yet I didn't feel too cramped. Not sure how it would be with 2 people though as it could be a tight squeeze. While the bathroom was a decent size, I did not like the "no tub/enclosure" shower which basically was almost European style in that it was in a corner of the room with no tub, just a drain. That meant that if you were not careful, the rest of the floor could easily get flooded.The location is the key here for this hotel and you are at the edge of the "action" in TriBeCa with a decent number of restaurants, bars and nightclubs all just a street or two away. Access to the subway is only a couple of blocks away and you can pretty much get anything you want within a short walk or subway ride away.I wouldn't pay more than $200 a night for a room here (yep, even in high season) as I don't think the rooms are worth it. Yes, you get a nice bed (the Sheraton Sleeper) but the room size is small and there really isn't anything else compelling to choose this hotel over another other than the price.

We stayed here the night of Dec. 26, 2012 and it served all our needs. We had a cozy bed to sleep on in a clean room for 1 night. Within walking distance of a bunch of different neighborhoods and dozens of cute bars with decent happy hours.Rooms are your average NY small, but we didn't feel cramped, though I imagine if I were staying for a long time, it might. There's one free bottle of water your room and one that'll add a charge to your room, so make sure you double-check before opening. For the price we paid on Priceline ($139/night) we feel we got a great deal and would stay here again.

I stayed here in November/December with my Mum and Sister. The rooms were small and there was no fridge ATALL which was quite annoying as we were staying there for 8 nights. The room service was also quite awful but you are in New York so there is no real need for Room Service and this shows in the quality. The wine prices are really reasonable though so that was nice! Apart from this the stay was great. The rooms were quiet and warm, the service was great, the front desk and concierge all lovely and the location perfect for us. Trendy area, great food, best coffee in new York 1 minute walking around the corner on Church St. I would definitely stay here again, thank you for a lovely stay!!

I stayed for two weeks for a business trip (working on Wall Street), so the location was relatively convenient. That said, it is on the 'edge' of the nice part of Soho, Tribeca.I'm a gold Starwood member, so was given a room on the corner of the building on a high floor, which was good. The room itself was quite small and felt a little bit like a dormitory. To be honest, the hotel didn't live up to the Sheraton brand in my experience.Having said that, rooms were clean, the bed was comfortable and the staff were pleasant enough.Annoyingly, there was a mix up with a special Starwood points offer which required emailing to and fro...finally got it sorted, but this isn't the sort of thing you should have to fight over.Having said that, rooms were clean, the bed was comfortable and the staff were pleasant enough. Would I choose to stay there again? No. But if you get a good deal, I'd potentially consider it.

We made a reservation to spend 5 nights at the sheraton and had to cancel it. We called the hotel and they confirmed that our stay was cancelled but never sent an email. (the cancellation was made weeks before the indicated deadline)One month later we received an email to inform us that they would debit 1721$ for no-show!!! They now pretend that we never called and accused us of lying!! Sheraton Tribeca is a shame to the Sheraton group.

My husband and I travel to New York at least once a year and this year we decided that we would explore other areas, aside from the major tourist points, like Tribeca and Soho. The location of this hotel is awesome. It is walking distance to Chinatown, where you can get some really affordable and great tasting eats. Little Italy is also there, but beware of being fooled into going into the restaurant without consulting the prices in the menu! The subway exit is also quite close.The hotel is very clean and modern. The room is pretty spacious, considering New York standards. We were especially pleased with the size of the bathroom. Very spacious. The service from the greeters at the door, the front desk staff and the barista at the Starbucks were very friendly.I would definitely consider returning to this hotel. There is a pizzeria just up the block that has a special for 2 regular pizza (cheese only) and a pop for only $2.75! THAT IS AN AMAZING DEAL!Don't worry about eating out, there are plenty of affordable food places around.

I just think some people who work the front desk 'GET IT' and the others...just need to learn from those people. The back story: We checked in on Friday night, Dec. 21st about 10pm coming in from Chicago. We are Starwood people and are here to see some family in Manhattan (See the tree and the windows, etc) and then we head upstate to see the rest of the family. We had a 2 night stay.We decided what we would do was get a regular room on points and the next night, upgrade to a Jr. Suite at our expense. James saw us coming in with 3 pieces of luggage (full of gifts!) and all I can say was he was very pleasant. He noticed that we had a smaller room 1 night and a little larger the second. He said 'Let me see what I can do about not having to move you guys at all.'He informed us that there was a Jr Suite available but on the 3rd floor...that just means no view. We gladly took it because he was honest and said 'you guys, with all your luggage, will find the regular room to be too small so lets get you in the suite'. I'm not in touch with this small room thing or what the difference with floor levels but he explained that you start to get a view of the skyline past floor 14. He said to go check it out and if we liked the third floor room, we can stay both nights but if we wanted a view, he would do whatever he could to get us higher than the 14th floor. We went in the room, unpacked a few things and then headed back down. For me, the room was fine, no view of anything but good enough. We were having a glass of wine at the bar and James came and asked what we thought. My wife, being the New Yorker wanted to try to move the next day and go for the view. James said he would see what he could do. The next morning we went for a walk and came back and talked to the front desk. Here is where it pays off to be as polite and respectful to the staff (TIP: lack of manners gets you a big fat ZERO in the hotel business!) He had ALREADY blocked us a room on the 19th floor that he knew a Starwood Platinum member was in and leaving that day. Already had our name on the room and notes in the computer. The guy was off work but had gone to the trouble to make sure we were taken care of with notes for his fellow coworkers at the front desk so they could follow his wishes. We had a great room with a great view and that makes for the start of a great trip.What I can tell you about the staff, the hotel, the location and the neighborhood.....Staff: Covered most of it but from the bellmen, doormen, bartenders and even the guy who came to our room and removed a bottle of wine that was in our new room (wasn't for us and boy did he feel bad for taking it back!) they were all EXCELENT!!! Hotel: Lovely, newer, clean, comfortable. Rooms a little on the small side but if you stay in NY hotels, you know what you're getting. But the BED....fugetaboutit! It is the best bed I've been in for a long time. Location: Tribeca is tough with the Holland Tunnel right there, Canal street isn't the prettiest part of town but you are just a short walk to the best I think NY has to offer, SOHO. And you try to stay in the dump hotels in SOHO!! Stay here and make the walk or take the cab. You wont be sorry if you stay here.In conclusion, all I really wanted to do was recognize James Wong. He probably doesn't even realize that he went above and beyond, it's probably second nature to him. He deserves to be looked at by management, if not so already, as a leader and mentor to others. Good job James- Merry Christmas!!Adam L.

This hotel is the reason why we joined starwoods rewards and soon after, Amex spg cards I live in manhattan on uws, in a manhattan sized apartment ... Sooo when my parents visit its nice to splurge when I can find a good deal and book a room so that we are all comfy got the room via priceline and was orig. Scared upon reading the canal street location ... All I could think of was us walking out of the hotel and being pushed into buying a fake chanel bag or folex watch ..... COULDNT BE FARTHER FROM THAT IMAGEThis location is IDEAL ... you literally walk a few blocks in any direction and you are in the prime hoods (Soho, tribeca, bowery, Chinatown obvi.) you are also a stones throw from the express 2,3 and local 1 train ... Again, perfect Hotel is fairly new (I think a little over a year?) clean and modern ... Computers if you needed right in lobby etc. We upgraded to club floor our visit and was worth every penny ... They have one of the BEST terraces I've ever seen in a hotel that was all your own! Clublounge was great to grab water and to order a class of wine and sit outside during happy hour ... This is how we learned about spg through the lovely server in the lounge and signed up right awayThe rooms are clean, bright and quiet ... A bit small but it was king room and it's manhattan ... But with the lounge on our floor you really didn't care The clincher was that they say they are dog friendly and ACTUALLY ARE! we brought our adorable, gorgeous choco lab Lola with us and the staff not only fell in love with her right away (duh, she's amazing and well behaved) they encouraged her to be social and gave her treats :) awesome awesome awesome staff from check-in to check-out We are returning to the hotel Christmas night for two days, this time as Gold spg members and looking forward to our stay as spg "family" Take it from a local ... This hotel is the best deal in nyc

There is nothing wrong with the Hotel. The staff are really good and helpful. The situation is really convenient for access to everywhere and is much more interesting than uptown NY. I chose the hotel in particular because of the ease of access from Manhattan to The Prudential Centre in New Jersey, some nine miles and the need for a very early return to JFK the following morning. The purpose of the visit was to see the Rolling Stones in USA after having seen them twice in London. The plan, to make everything run like clockwork. It depended on my collection from The Prudential Centre and return to the hotel before leaving at 5.00 p.m. to get to JFK. Thus I rented a town car with driver to take me to the venue. Pick up agreed 5.30 p.m. The car did not show. Despite continual checking throughout the day all was on schedule. The company had no drivers, the concierge could not get a replacement and it was all beginning to go pear shaped. I had travelled over 3,000 miles booked an expensive hotel, car and driver. The only piece left in the puzzle is the last nine miles.. Eventually some cab drive that was illiterate took me, no idea where the venue is just arrived. Shabby car and a driving license he must have got form a Christmas cracker. I reluctantly got in the car after express confirmation from the concierge the driver would get me there and he did. He got lost, took over one hour to cover 9 miles did more u turns than any living or dead politician.The Rolling Stones were great, best ever show, I been to a few and I took a call for my return driver who had been dispatched by the hotel to pick me up and I arrived back safely. I spoke with the duty manager Mr. James Wong, a most courteous and polite gentleman. He was horrified, immediately agreed to pay me back the $100.00 for the outward-bound trip and pay the return on the house.It went from very bad to better all because one man got his act together and sorted it our and I am most grateful to him. He then bought me a beer on the house. Travellers note the concierge service in these hotels is often out sourced and the doormen run the management of matters like cars etc. Be aware as they are all on kickbacks and totally unreliable when something goes wrong.My few hours’ sleep was excellent, albeit asked for an alarm call it did not happen thankfully my iPhone did the job well.

My friends and I ended up at the Sheraton Tribeca becuz of its fantastic location. If you need to be anywhere south of 23rd, and on the west side of the island, this is a good choice. Once you walk outside, to the left is Broadway and the Meat Packing district, to the immediate north is a better shopping district than 5th ave, and to the right is China Town with its top notch, albeit underrated restaurants. The rooms are fairly average hotel rooms and the lobby is cute but sparse except for the over priced and out of place snack stand that is only open during prime hours. The downside, for me, were the smaller things that probably wont affect most vacationers but for me were an absolute deal-breaker. having to carry my room key with me everywhere i went in order to access the elevators, the gym, and even the doors at night is a little bit like having to carry a 'hall-way pass' in middle school. Even in middle of the afternoon you cannot access the elevators without your room key. Its juvenile. The staff is helpful, but a little too helpful for my taste. I dont like insinuating questions like "can i help you?" when i am milling about the lobby waiting on friends. My thinking is that if I needed help I would've asked for it. Again, these are more my own quirky preferences and wont likely affect most travelers. -Arik Katzenberg

What makes this hotel stand out is the friendly,helpful and efficient staff.From the reception by Maria with a smiling welcome to the attentive bellhops and the efficienthousekeepers provides a rewarding environment certainly not expected in NYC.

Tribeca has become THE place to be in NYC. My son goes to school at NYU so we wanted a hotel with a national name, good value and convenient location downtown. This Sheraton meets those criteria. Located on Canal it was a quick walk through Soho to the Village and Washington Square. When entering the lobby of the hotel you will find a very inviting vibrant atmosphere with a central computer area, and a nice bar/lounge and comfortable seating areas. We were hungry for some snacks and the bar menu is pretty good. For breakfast, the buffet is also a good pick for a decent selection and good value. The room was clean and neat with a modern bathroom. The king size bed was comfortable and we even had a very nice view (of Canal St) out of our 11th floor window. I did't get to use the fitness room, however, I was impressed with the number of machines. The staff was very friendly and attentive in the lobby, giving the feeling of a neighborhood hotel. The only complaint I have is the the shower door tended to leak water on the floor. Overall, this hotel is a good stay in the Tribeca area of NYC>

the hotel is ok, nothing special but if you are looking for a good place around tribeca and you don't want spend so much money, this is ok. near everithings so you can walk around the area that is safe.the rooms are clean and also the staff is friendly...you have to bars for breakfast(to pay) and also internet and also gym room.next time in tribeca anyway i want to find out some more fashion hotel, beginning to be quiet old hotel!that's all falks

We stayed 2 x 1 week stints in Manhattan. Chose Sheraton Tribeca mainly on price and recommendation from my brother. The hotel is standard modern design and nothing flash. Clean, good value and convenient to subway. Free wifi in lobby.

I stayed there 3 days, 4 nights. Came back with painful, itchy bed bug bites all over my arms, legs, and feet. I reported it to the hotel, and they denied it came from my room.It is not worth the risk to stay here!

First time in New York and it was great. We stayed on the 18th floor. The room although not large in size was more than comfortable. The king size bed was fantastic. We slept like logs every night after spending many hours exploring Manhatten by foot and subway. The staff were friendly and bent over backwards to make our stay enjoyable. The hotel is close to the subway and there are more restaurants within walking distance of the hotel than could be visited during our 5 day stay.
