The only complaint, if you can call it a complaint, is that the 3 elevators in the lobby are very slow.We will return to New York again however I think we will stay at a hotel a little closer to Times Square and Central park. If you want some distance between you and all the major attractions then I would recomend the Tribeca.

Just got back from a few days in NYC, great location I got the subway 6 express to MSGTo catch the game Friday night (10 mins)Rooms are clean and a good size with all you need including coffee maker.Breakfast Buffett was good quality and good price.I have stayed at lot of SOHO hotels over the years and would return to the Sheraton.There are a lot of good bars and places to eat on Church Street.Good for SOHO shopping

I think that the title sums things up pretty much. I stayed here for 7 nights, for a business (and a some pleasure) trip at the end of November 2012. Where the hotel is situated is ideal for great walks, bus rides or subway journeys to all that New York has to offer. It is ideal for Chinatown, Soho, Little Italy and the Financial district. It's very close to Broadway, which is perfect for shopping, and central for most of the major routes on the subway (although I am still trying to figure out the subway system)!The hotel itself is clean and very presentable. Upon arrival the foyer is bright and warm, and check-in was quick and easy. There is a bar, Starbucks, restaurant and media centre all located on this entry level, as well as bell service and information. There were maps and leaflets available in the entrance-way to give some great ideas of where to visit.The elevators to the floors were a bit of a pain, I normally use elevator journeys as time to try to find my room key in the midst of my bottomless bag, however you need to have your key to use in the elevator to actually get to your floor... and sometimes the keys were temperamental to say the least! Often having to ask strangers to use their key to press your floor button!The rooms were small but perfectly formed. Absolutely nothing wrong with them at all, and if you have ever stayed in a Yotel (there is one on 10th Ave) then you will know that these rooms are huge in comparison to some others that are out there!The bed was comfy, there were plenty of lights, the furniture wasn't battered and beaten, a nice comfy chair and a desk chair (but this tended to be used as a clothes holder!) It had a safe, a hairdryer, flat screen TV and a coffee maker (with Starbucks coffee).The bathroom was ideal, with a lovely walk in shower, and plenty of light to do your hair and make-up. The only drawback with my bathroom was that the fan was very noisy, however it worked wonderfully well and even after a hot shower the bathroom was not misted up at all! So I lived with the noise of the fan - it's not like it is on constantly.The view from my room (14th floor) was pretty boring overlooking the brick building opposite and looking down onto W Broadway junction, and I don't think you would ever really stay here for the views. The street noise can be loud at times, and of course this is New York - there are police and fire sirens all day and night! By the way - the same can be said of your hotel room neighbours, they too can be noisy...and it is easy to hear what is going on in the corridors, and the doors do tend to slam pretty easily. I found that hotel to be ideal for my purposes, I found staff to be very friendly an accommodating, the rooms were spotlessly clean, the bed was comfy and it had what I needed (OK so I had to pay $9.99 per day for wifi - bit of a pet peeve of mine) and all in all I found it to be a pleasant stay and I would return here again.

Typical Sheraton, very clean, room was very small (as you'd expect in Manhattan) but well set up and very comfortable. Staff is super nice and helpful. Best part: location is great. Is on kind of an ugly corner on Canal, but only 1 block S to Tribeca (10 min walk to WTC) and 1 block N to SoHo means everything is close by, plus multiple subway lines connect w/in a block of the hotel.Worst part: have to pay for internet in the rooms. Really, Sheraton?

Great location, clean, large rooms with safe , tv, king bed, coffee & tea in room.Starbucks in lobbyLounge and restaurant downstairs Subway stations close by, usually a 1 to 2 minute walkClose to China town and little Italy

This particular hotel was great. While the neighborhood isn't gorgeous, it is close to everything; walking to Little Italy, walking to Chinatown, walking to the 9/11 Memorial and within a block of all the major subway lines. The lobby was nice, the room was fabulous and we had a great view out of our window.Service was stellar at this hotel.However, because we had orginally reserved a room at a different Sheraton, we were doubly charged. The sad part is Sheratons don't share systems or information.Be warned ahead of time! Doubtful I will stay with this group again. There are plenty of other good hotels in NYC.

We stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca on our way home from Dublin Ireland. I am a SPG Gold Member but used HOTWIRE to secure a room at this location on Canal Street next to Chinatown, NYC.We arrived by taxi and checked in immediately with no wait. There are bellhops at the front door who can assist you with baggage and flagging down taxis. The front desk clerk gave us an enhanced room with a view on the 15th floor because they were out of double beds that I requested. I grabbed a free copy of the New York Times Sunday paper on our way up to the room.The room was spectacular—big room for New York with luxury bed and linens and rainfall shower head in the bathroom. The HD Flat screen television had real HD programming to watch. Multiple outlets throughout the room for phones, laptops etc. And a grand window view of Canal Street and Chinatown!! It all made for a super night in Manhattan. I have to say again that Sheraton has the best beds in the industry for deep sleeps.We walked east of the Hotel to Chinatown for some late night Asian food. And we strolled through Little Italy on Mulberry to see all the white linen tables waiting for customers. The entire area was flooded by Hurricane Sandy but we could see no sign of the disaster during our stay.Before retiring for the night I used the free business center downstairs to print my flight itinerary. Use of the computers and printers is free for all guests and not just SPG Members. In the morning a free copy of USA TODAY was left at our door.I would stay here again without hesitation.

This a decent hotel. Very small rooms and the carpet and style show the age and wear. The location is great and so are the porters, but there's no free wifi, you have to wait for a long time for a hotel computer as 2 are broken, and the front desk staff is surly and snarky.

nice clean hotel at a great location: walking distance to Soho, Chinatown, Little Italy (what's left of it), Washington Square and battery park. A 30 second walk to the subway. Staff friendly and helpful. If you can get the right price, this is a good option.

This was my first stay at the Sheraton Tribeca. The location is convenient and just around the corner from the A-C-E Canal Street Subway station. The Club Lounge had breathtaking views of the city and good offerings for breakfast and evening hors d'oeuvres (except for the scrambled eggs, which looked awful - please improve this offering). My room was comfortable and located on the top floor. It was average size for NYC but had a large bathroom and a great 37 inch HD TV with a wide selection of channels. Internet was fast, too! The only negative thing I can say is my room had no view (except for an office building across the street). I had some minor glitches - had to make 2 calls to get a refrigerator, but Front Office Manager Steven Lamour more than made up for it with a complimentary tray of snacks & beer. Thanks so much for going above and beyond, Steven! All the staff members were friendly from the front desk to housekeeping to the club lounge. Service does matter and it's fantastic here, at least for us SPG Platinum members. I will most definitely return!

If your primary interest is in SoHo or Downtown this is a convenient option. But Canal Street is not the most beautiful place in NY. The traffic is really bad and you are surrounded by stores selling cheap products. But cross the street and you are in SoHo with nice stores, restaurant and bars.The hotel is comfortable, relatively small and looks new or renovated. The rooms are small. At you can hear at doors bumping as I read in other reviews.The service was also Ok, but I had problems in the check in.All in all it looks overpriced for what it offer and its location (at least considering the rate I got it).

Hi this is LONG ISLAND CHICK here with my new review on the Sheraton Tribeca.If this is going to be your first trip to New York City then welcome. If you have been here before, then you will have some ideas on what to do and where to stay. The most important thing to ask yourself would be, what do I want to do?, where do I want to eat?, etc. I live on Long Island and come into NYC all the time. The Sheraton Tribeca is in an ideal location. if you are driving in, the hotel staff will park your car overnight for you. All you have to do is pull up in front of hotel. Yes they charge a fee, but what parking garage in New York doesn't? You will be so close to the subway (across the street) you can go anywhere. To top it off Little Italy and China Town are within a hop, skip and jump away. I love to eat at DaNico and DeGennaro and go shopping at Step Up Boutique on Mulberry Street. The hotel staff is great and the place is immaculate. They have a nice sit down area for free WiFi, bar, cafe and a small deli like stop for coffee and take out breakfast etc. And if your an AMERICAN EXPRESS STARWOOD member then check it out for cash & points. There is no better time to come to NYC then during the holiday season. Everything is in full swing with lights and decorations. Plan ahead and you will have a great time. There is also the Discount Ticket Booth at Times Square. Don't let the long lines fool you as they move quickly. 50% to 60% off some broadway show is not a bad deal. Yes. you have to see a show. How could you come to NYC and not see a BROADWAY OR OFF BROADWAY show? This is NYC after all. Have fun and most of all be safe and be aware of your surroundings at all times.

I arrived only a few days after the power was restored to Lower Manhattan. Other than a few locals still seeking refuge in the hotel along with their pets, there was nothing to suggest there had been any disruption. The room on the 18th floor was cosy rather than spacious, but the views were great and everything works.The location is excellent - even an A train subway station around the corner that connects to the JFK Airtrain. I would stay again.

I stayed here 2 nights this week with my wife, and it was very convenient for the proximity to her work events. It's a standard Sheraton hotel: professional staff, clean and well-run, and the rooms are small but have what one needs.We didn't dine in the restaurant/cafe so can't review that aspect, but there are many local options close by.

Hotel was clean and welcoming. Room (delux king 18th floor) was almost perfect, needed something for clothing storage for our extended stay of 4 days. Room was acomfortable, clean, and relaxing when we were there. The Sheraton Tribeca Hotel staff were excellent, professional, helpful, and honest. The Concierge staff were the BEST. Information they provided about travel around the city was accurate, helpful, and cost effective. Thank you to Corey and the "Michael's" for ALL of your help and information about NYC. Corey provided more accurate information about the UpTown 6 subway to Bronx than the NYC Subway Termial operator. Upper floor room is the way to go (either side of building) just to get a view of the city at night.

Well I was here during sandy hurricane, beautiful soho view from my room, nice and cozy. But everyday I need to leave a note to room attendant what needs to be replenish. Have coffee maker but they won't provide any stirrer, have towels but they won't replenish toiletries . I stayed there 1 week kind of frustrating, You need to pay wifi $10 for 24 hours. That was not my expectation of Sheraton groups.

I stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca for five nights in a suite. I was upgraded from a studio suite to a suite, although I don't know how much I gained...the suite was great, though.The hotel kind of lacks the character that many older or boutique hotels in New York have, but for a longer stay, I'd rather be comfortable than feel cool. I was very comfortable and for a reasonable price (despite paying for a studio suite).I didn't try breakfast in the hotel or use room service. There is a 24 hour deli next door which was extremely convenient. Bottled water was replenished each day.I was not looking for the typical Midtown tourist experience and the Sheraton Tribeca was perfect for seeing a different side of New York (having lived in Hell's Kitchen years ago, I wanted to stay downtown for a change of pace). If you are interested in seeing more of the small businesses and boutiques that are unique to New York, I definitely recommend the Tribeca/Soho area.

So I stay at the sheraton canal/tribeca all the time and love sheraton's in general .. staff here are great .. hotel is nice .. but as a business traveller paying $450 a night, 5-6 nights a month at sheratons in ny and another 5-6 nights a month in other cities I expect good service .. especially when there are problems which is the only test of great service i know .. whimpy of me i know !! However in last week's NY storms I found out what happens when they are under pressure .. staff were nice .. still love the location .. cant help it if the manager acted like a jerk .. after trying to get my reservation amended for a week before arrival with Sheraton corporate and 1-800 reservations telling me that Sheraon had me covered as a premiere Starwood Rewards Member the hotel happily billed me $450 for a night i didnt stay and when i raised the issue the manager told me basically it was my fault because his corporate reservations folks didnt send the emails they said they did to cover me .. so my fault his corporate people lied .. doesnt matter to me .. it is water under the bridge .. i am just a customer .. who cares about paying customers .. I am "hilton people" from now on .. it is only $20k or so a month or $250k a year to sheraton .. which for a $5b corporation doesnt matter .. maybe if 20 of us moved they might wake up .. aye ..

There is very little to speak about this hotel. This did not feel a high-end hotel, nor lower end. My room was pretty small and had barely any light coming in from the window that overlooked another building 20 odd feet away. Bathroom was good, but again, small. There was a Starbucks in the Lobby, which opens around 7am. Free Wifi in the lobby, with Wifi in the room costing around $10 per day (better than many places). Room was clean and had all the necessary facilities, but was a little depressing with darker woods, curtains, etc. With such little light coming in the window, the colour scheme should have been brighter. The location was good, close to great restaurants - however, being on Canal, so close to the entrance to the tunnel, traffic was often very difficult - you have to be careful of your route choices if coming in by car or cab.

I am giving this hotel five stars for several reasons: 1) incredibly clean 2) duvets on the beds instead of bedspreads so you get a fresh bed and the mattresses are comfortable) 3) the staff is so friendly 4) the bathrooms have fans that actually work, and they are acceptable in size, and 5) room service was excellent - cheeseburgers were delicious. The rooms are very very small, but that didn't bother me. The things I mentioned above are the most important things to me in a room. I personally loved the location of the hotel. There are great affordable restaurants and fantastic shopping within walking distance. If you want to experience NYC, this is a great area because you are a stone's throw away from Chinatown and near many subway entrances. Learn to use the subways; you will save so much money. We got to our hotel at midnight and went to a Chinese restaurant on Bowery St., and we felt totally safe. By the way....noise doesn't bother me so I can't comment on that. I hope this helps.

Since it was important for us to stay in SOHO, the location fit the bill. Nothing to write home about other than that. We had a city view room which was ok. The room was clean and the bed was comfortable which is paramount. Wasn't looking for much else on this visit so not much to report. Price was competitive.

This hotel is ideally situated on Canal st in the heart of Soho/Tribeca area. The room was nicely furnished but the standout for us was the welcoming staff and the great bar area. There is a fitness room but no pool, which is the only missing ingredient to what is otherwise a very nice hotel.

Me and the girls took a trip to New York and it was a blast.. We partied every night and had a wonderful time. But what made it more fun was the hotel staff that was so hands on with us. It was wonderful. The fact that we partied hard every night. We was so greatful to have there staff. The night time house keeping(JamellMartin) made sure every night that we were safe. That we made it to our room. Made sure that we as a group were tooken care of more then just of us as just guess. He made us feel like we were home. And to that, that was more reason for us to want to come back to this hotel. We have checked in/out much hotel but this was by far the best we ever. The staff was wonderful...

We had two rooms for our group during our stay, all booked through Priceline. We were pleasantly surprised at the great room value considering this is a prime location in Soho/Tribeca. Everything was so close - shopping, restaurants, etc. and we were very comfortable either walking or taking taxis around town. The subway is only a short walk, so also very convenient. The room was clean, but as expected in NYC, the closet was tiny and the bathroom was small. It was much better than we had expected, though. The hotel has a little Starbucks stand on the main level and that was convenient. There's also a little deli next door and an amazing late night pizza place on the corner. I would definitely stay here again and the price was super reasonable.

The Sheraton on Canal Street is a great base to discover SoHo and Tribeca, away from the busy tourist area's around TImes Square. The staff is very friendly and helpfull and the Starbucks is convenient. But come on pay for WiFi in your room, it is 2012! Free Internet was available in the lobby.Room was big enough but a bit old, same for bathroom. We didn't eat in the hotel as there are so much nice restaurants and bars nearby.

We stayed here over the past weekend. The front desk staff is extremely friendly and helpful. We had a standard room with a King bed. It was very small, which we had read about before getting there. This is the usual case in NYC. The bathroom was also small, but suitable, although it had an extremely loud bathroom fan. This hotel is located to some cool shops in Soho, and we had fun shopping there. A couple of things to keep in mind: if you want to go uptown or to Times Square, it is hard getting a cab. We asked a staff member to help us get a cab and he said it would be better if we walked up a block and tried to get one ourselves. We did try and no one would pull over, and when someone finally did pull over he said it was "too far" for him to go and pulled away. We had to walk back to the Sheraton and flag our own cab because the doorman didn't have much interest in helping us. It was an overall pleasant experience. Since there is always something to do in NYC you aren't spending much time in your room, which is a good thing here.

I had a wonderful experience at this hotel. The front door men espcially, and the front desk staff were so professional,helpful, and truly friendly. My main reason for writing this review was because i appreciate how welcoming the staff was at the hotel.My room was clean, and modern... nothing in there was too dated. The size didnt seem too small for 2 people, although we were out most of the day anyways. The location was great, it was easy for us to walk to alot of the shops,did not have a problem catching a cab.On nights that I did stay in there a cool bar in the lobby, cocktails were great, plenty of space to sit back and relax. Overall the hotel had a very pleasant vibe, I'd definitely stay here again.

My wife and I visit NYC routinely and have previously only stayed in Midtown. Looking to spend more time in Lower Manhattan this visit, we selected the Sheraton in Tribeca. The location, even for a first-time NYC visitor can’t be beat. A five minute walk to the north and you’re in Soho, five to the South and you’re in the heart of Tribeca, five east and it’s Chinatown and one a couple minutes more to Little Italy. Add to that, the A, C and E lines are 2 minutes from the lobby and the N and R are just a few minutes away and you can ride the subway to anywhere, including a quick trip to Brooklyn and Chelsea (visit the High Line!). Best of all, you’re in the middle of non-stop action, superb restaurants and fantastic, shoppable shops and less pretension than Midtown. The hotel itself is very nice. Even if you hesitate staying at a Sheraton, as we did, this will exceed your expectations. It’s on par with more upscale large hotel chains. The room is comfortable, understated and adequate and normally-sized for NYC. The staff is excellent and quick to assist with any need. We were on the 16th floor and it was remarkably quiet for NYC. Possibly the quietest room I've ever stayed in here. I would happily recommend this hotel to friends and family and I suspect we’ll stay here again.

Small noisy room. Overpriced. Bad location on run down part of Canal Street.Near subway. Great front desk staff.Good neighborhood restaurants within walking distance.Free Internet in lobby.Good fitness center.

I have traveled extensively and cannot recall having stayed in such a small room, my wife had to sit or lay in the bed for me to be able to movearound. Otherwise, the property is modern and nicely kept, staff are very courteous and friendly, location is good with easy access to subway and major freeways.

We had a very pleasant weekend at this hotel. The room was a little small, but typical for Manhattan. Everything about the hotel was very clean, (rooms, lobby, elevators, etc.)But what made this place a little better was the staff. They were all very friendly and helpful. The location was pretty good too. Soho and Little Italy were within easy walking distance. Right outside the hotel was a Dunkin Donuts, (convenient for morning coffee) and the subway was right on the corner.I would stay at this place again, and I would recommend it to anyone.

First of all, truth in advertising: this hotel is on Canal Street which is the northernmost edge of Tribeca (and southernmost edge of SoHo). Canal Street is not at all sophisticated or gentrified; feels more like Chinatown than anything else. Having said that, the location ends up being rather perfect. Two different subway lines are easily available. Great shopping and restaurants are a short walking distance.The hotel itself has a small but perfectly nice lobby with computers and free wi-fi access. The bar is great -- good bourbon selection -- and they serve food at night. Very friendly bartenders/waitresses. Didn't have breakfast in the Cafe, so I can't comment on that. Stayed on the 18th floor (a very friendly front desk person upgraded me for being a Starwood member) and had great views of the NY skyline. If you can, upgrade to the Club Level: the terrace facing north has simply spectacular views (and there's free breakfast, evening reception, and wi-fi).The room itself was small -- it is NYC, after all-- but it was modern and clean. At least the bedroom was very good-sized and outfitted with modern appliances. Very comfortable bed and pillows. As someone else has commented, the apt. doors do slam very loudly and that was annoying early in the morning! And even on the 18th floor I could hear the traffic trying to get to the Holland Tunnel. It didn't bother me, but not recommended if you are a light sleeper!

Recently stayed at the Sheraton TriBeCa with my family. Staff very friendly. Great location. 5 minute walk to 3 subways which gives you easy access to every part of New York City and Manhatten. 24 hr bagel/fast food shop right next door with good food options for breakfast, lunch and tea - takeaway, variety from fast to healthy. Located on Canal Street with good shopping options. Only negatives - rooms are small and no fridge.

The location is pretty convenient, but to be honest when you book a hotel in NY you usually pick a hotel near to whatever you need e.g. Shopping, business, sightseeing etc. just do a little homework before you arrive. So convenient for trendy TriBeCa - sure. The hotel entrance is small, but the staff were very helpful and super efficient. Checked in within 3 mins. Brilliant. However, the room was ridiculously small. I had to side shuffle round the ,albeit clean and comfortable, double bed. The ensure shower was efficient, but the ventilator sounded like an aircraft taking off and made me feel guilty about getting up early and having a shower, a it would have definitely woken up other guests nearby......but hang on....why should I feel guilty as they woke me up 5 times in the night! Who needs ice at 3am? Why can people not shut the door quietly at 12am. Do you really need to shout at your mate at 1am?Ahhh!!!!The rooms are so small and so close together you hear everything. Doesn't matter about the thickness of the walls.

This hotel is in a very good location, close to Tribeca (very trendy) and Chinatown. Good restaurants everywhere. Rooms are small but very clean and with flatscreen tvs. No refrigerators or microwaves. The bathrooms are very modern and updated. The lobby has a great bar with several computers for public use. Wi-fi only in lobby or paid internet in rooms. The gym is very good.

My 2nd stay at this hotel was kind of amazing. They REALLY have it together! Things I LOVED:- Friendly front desk team- Clean, spacious room- They point the showehead towards the wall so you don't get sprayed when you turn it on to warm it up- Starbucks kiosk tastes just like every other Starbucks (in a good way)- Room service was tasty & delivered by lovely peopleI will definitely return and/or recommend this hotel to anyone

I've been to this hotel several times while staying in New York for business.The staff are always friendly and my room is alwats spotless clean. I find rooms smaller than the usual standard but I hardly spend any time in them. The bed - usually a King size - is super comfy and the views are often iconic for the Tribecca/Soho area. The room has an iron and ironing board and a coffee machine. The hair-drier in the bathroom is pretty OK - although I hardly ever find a decent hair-drier in hotels.The last time I stayed I was upgraded to use the lounge on the 21st floor and it makes a huge difference, so upgrade if you can. You have access to a free breakfast and evening buffet - the breakfast one was pretty comprehensive with lots of healthy options. if the weather allows, don't eat in the inside area (which is not very stylish) but go out to the amazing terrace with stunning views. Drinks are also cheaper here than in the ground-floor bar plus you get free wi-fi in your room - otherwise you have to pay for it.Another thing is the ground-floor bar is always very lively and open until late (and the drinks are strong!) and it also has a Starbucks shop.Price wise I find New York quite expensive, so I find this hotel expensive but for the city/area, it's not too bad.

I know this is Manhattan, but, given the price, the room was tiny. We were woken up almost every night by doors slamming in the corridor. (The doors close very loudly and I'm sure something could be done about this). We were also annoyed by our maid, who kept fishing for tips (which we were not inclined to give given the standard of cleaning and service). The hotel is on a particularly dodgy part of Canal Street and walking near the hotel did not feel safe. We would not stay here again. I am sure you can do better for the money.

the one and only downfall of this hotel was the long process of checking inn, we booked off of booking.com and the receptionist took extra long to "transfer our reservation" whatever that meant. other than that the room was large for nyc standards we stayed in room 1014! extremely clean and modern fixtures! the room was moderately quiet considering it is right on canal street! the location for this hotel is great for people that want to go out and experience the real NYC instead of staying in time square.. there are great restaurants nearby we eat at Dos Caminos and Abe and Arthurs both were delicious and 15 minute walk from the hotel. Afterwards we went to Miss Lily's a great little bar not too far from the hotel. it is in a great location for fabulous shopping ( anthropologie, tiffany's, louis vuitton, DASH.. etc.. ) are all walking distance from the hotel. also their is free WIFI in the lobby as well as a bar. i heard this hotel was regularly 400$/night we got a deal off booking.com and only paid 150$/tax inc. overall great experience at this hotel my boyfriend and i are looking forward to return to it.

We enjoyed the location of this hotel overall as we have been to NYC several times and have stayed in Midtown. The hotel is located in a not-so-great area but is close to many areas of interest in terms of shopping and restaurants.The room was spacious enough for a NYC hotel room. Room amenities were standard. The bathroom was clean and roomy though I found the carpet to be dirty and by the end of our 1 week stay my slippers were sticking to the carpet as I walked. We dined in the restaurant only once for breakfast. It was average. The server was not detailed enough to bring utensils, cream. We had to ask for many things as he simply forgot to bring them. The bright spot was another server in the room - I think her name may have been Jessica - she picked up where her forgetful colleague left off and provided us with what he missed. As we were waiting for our meal, I was looking around the room. The side of the room where the buffet is located has floor to ceiling mirror. What struck me is that the top half of the mirror was filthy dirty. The lower half was however clean. It was as if the person cleaning just did not care enough to finish the job correctly. I wondered what else the restaurant did not bother to care about since the could not perform the simple task of cleaning. It bugged me enough to speak to the restaurant manager about this. When I spoke of the filthy mirrors, I was met with a defensive tone of "I am surprised at this because I had the staff clean the mirrors last night". I indicated that if she was doubting me I recommended that she step inside the restaurant to take a look for herself. She apologized to me in effort to just shut the conversation down and get rid of me. I was not looking for an apology. I was just pointing something out that maybe she should look into. Perhaps she was taking it personally as the filthy mirrors would be a direct result of her lack of managerial ability to follow up with her staff to check their work the following morning if in fact they did work on them the night before. If the restaurant manager is not going to care about cleanliness than most assuredly her staff will not care either.Our stay was fine overall but given the sheer amount of choice in NYC in terms of accommodation, we would probably stay elsewhere for our next visit.

I called the hotel operator and asked for a wake up call at 7am the following morning. The phone rang at 5am waking me up. I called the operator and explained that the wake up call came in at 5am and not 7am as I requested. No "sorry" or anything that sounded like an apology. I asked for the 7am wake up call and tried to go back to sleep. I woke up around 8am with no wake up call as requested at 7am. I had no time to shower, shave or even have breakfast or I would have been late for my meeting. I left three messages for the manager to call me. No phone call from the manager or anyone else from the hotel.

We stayed here 2 times with an overnight tour away in between the first 2 nights were terrible - we checked in at 9pm and then had to wait almost an hour for the room to be cleaned - (they did however give us a complimentary drink voucher for the bar which was good) also had no double rooms so they "upgraded" us to a suite so we could have separate beds - it was awful extremely noisy with some sort of fan going off all night from the bathroom and extremely cramped and uncomfortable with the foldout couch all the way out the second stay which was for 7 nights was much better quick checking to a double room which tho small (which u expect in New York) was much quieter and more comfortable. They have free wifi in the lobby but also free computers with free printing for guests which we used often. Also good from them was they held our luggage the night between our stays. Easy access to subway as well.

Let me start by saying I am a seasoned traveler and have left predominantly positive reviews for hotels on this site. I realize that hotels can make mistakes, but so long as they act with integrity and fix their mistakes I just overlook them. In the case of the Sheraton Tribecca they made a mistake, but it went downhill from there.I booked my hotel room over 2 weeks in advance and paid the full amount for a room that was non-refundable. When I got my Visa statement I saw that the hotel had reversed the charges, and recharged my Visa after checkout resulting in an additional charge of $80.I contacted Sheraton which resulted in a response from a manager at the hotel. His first response was that this was normal practice and had to do with incidentals. This did not make sense, and I told him so. He then wanted to see copies of my Visa statement which I sent to him. Despite assurance that this would be dealt with in a matter of days, a week went by with no word. I then called several times, e-mailed, but got no answer. After a couple of weeks I contacted Sheraton customer service again, and found that my file had been closed by the hotel manager. No refund, no response, nothing from the hotel!Sheraton customer service explained they could not help me as their protocol required simply re-opening the file and waiting for the hotel to respond. I called the hotel again, and again the manager was not available, so I left a message that if I did not have a response from him within 24 hours I would escalate this matter with Sheraton corporate.I have to say that closing the file without a refund, without notifying me, and without even responding to my calls/e-mails after 2 weeks is deplorable. I have spent far too much time on long distance phone calls, e-mails, and just generally being frustrated with this hotel's management.If you stay at the Sheraton Tribecca you are taking a chance. You might get lucky, or you might be in for an unpleasant surprise. My advice: there are lots of nice hotels in New York City, don't take the chance at the Sheraton Tribecca.

We were a group of 3 and stayed at the hotel at Canal street, this is a busy road and can be a bit noise at night. But the location was great and the hotel is good value for money and recently renovated. Many shops and restaurants nearby and also the subway. This is next to Soho.

This is sometimes a Sheraton and sometimes a Four Points...Some details in the room, like room size, a lot of plastic make hotel looks cheaper...Its location is very good, if you walk in the right direction...service not bad, and good sleeping quality. Very EXPENSIVE Valet Parking service...its better to park on your own..

Stayed for work and was a good distance from the office. Didn't eat or make use of facilities so only commenting on room. The room was fairly small but functional and clean. Bathroom was small and a bit grubby and tired. bed was comfy enough but the windows didn't stop the city noise at all. Lots of traffic noise from early morning.

The hotel itself is good but once you step out of it do not turn right because the scenery changes completely and you find yourself in an area not to be expected near a four star place .The internet service in the lobby is good.The restaurant is expensive .

We used this hotel before and after an Eastern Discovery Tour in America. The first night we were in a room overlooking the financial district with fabulous views, on our return we were put in a smaller room at the side of the hotel next to an office building - not so good. There is an excellent coffee bar and comfortable lounge/bar area, also internet facilities in the reception area. Did not eat in the restaurant which looked a bit deserted. The reception and portering staff were very helpful. Not the best of locations if you want to visit the miain attractions (Midtown) but perhaps a little quieter.

Stayed here on the first and returned on the last night of a Virgin East Coast tour of USA and Canada. Had booked two beds in the same room since travelling with my 19 year but they had allocated only one. Spoke to the same receptionist on both occasions and was left feeling she was doing me a favour by getting a more appropriate room. Her body language and tone of voice was rather awful and she informed that next time I stayed there I needed to book properly. Given Virgin holidays organised the tour I explained this was their responsibility. That said I won't be staying there again.The room was comfortable and great views of the city. Conveniently located. Just a pity about the receptionist - must have got her on her worst two days hence low scoring.

Stayed here on a recent business trip to NYC. I was going to an office in the Wall Street area of downtown, but this was a reasonably priced hotel not too far away. About a 20 min quick walk to where I was going, or a brief cab ride. I got my room on a bargain website, and got a good price for the room. However, there were some things I wasn't super happy about.The room itself was very small... A queen bed + a few feet around each side to get by, a small wardrobe and an average sized bathroom. Small was not unexpected, but it was well appointed (modern furniture, fixtures and TV). Although it was generally a clean room, there were some concerns which I didn't love. I found a few hairs not just on the bed, but also in the bathroom vanity and bathtub. Not huge, but I'm detail oriented and it's little things like that which annoy me. ("If they didn't catch this hair in the sink, what else didn't they catch??")The lobby is not huge, but nice and modern. The front door however is completely invisible unless you're standing next to it. I was getting dropped off by a cab from the airport and the driver wasn't even certain the hotel was there. Looking down the street, you can't see any Sheraton signs, banners, flags, etc. until you're right at the building. Not a big deal, but just so you know. In my brief stay, I didn't do a lot of exploring... but I didn't notice too many local restaurants or convenience stores within earshot of the entrance, as I'm accustomed to seeing in NYC. Maybe they were right around the corner?
The staff was super friendly and helpful. Location wasn't too bad as we were near the financial district and close to the subway lines.

My husband and I stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca for two nights this past weekend, using my Preferred Planner points. The hotel was conveniently located on the same block as the ACE subway line. I personally do not like Canal Street so the immediate area around the hotel was unappealing to me. However, we were in a good location to catch the subway anywhere we wanted, and if you just walk across Canal St. you are in SOHO. It's also about a 10 minute walk to Little Italy. The bed was comfortable and the room was a decent size with a very nice shower. Our room was directly across from the elevator,though, so we got very little sleep Saturday night between people standing outside our door talking and the sirens from ambulances going all night. Bring your ear plugs! The lobby was small and unimpressive but had a little kiosk with coffee/snacks which we did not use but seemed convenient. Since this was a free stay for us I enjoyed the stay, but I am not sure I would pay to stay. It was a good hotel, just not luxurious or grand in anyway. But it was comfortable and clean, which is all you really need!
Good: Fantastic view from the room and a super location.Bad:Being forced to pay for Internet is very badPaying for things in the Club Lounge is not part of good service

This room, by Manhattan standards, was spacious. It was clean and comfortable. Nice bar area and good breakfast. We enjoyed our stay. Easy access via Holland Tunnel. Good restaurants nearby. Price was comparable to other area hotels.

This Sheraton is very conveniently located on Canal St between Wooster & West broadway. It is one of the newer SPG Sheraton and therefore, the hotel lobby and rooms do look somewhat new. The service is good and better than the nearby W downtown, which I stayed the previous week. Keep in mind, Canal St is busy almost all day with crosstown traffic congestion due to the holland tunnel access. So it may not be for everyone! In addition, Canal street isn't one of the pretties street in NYC. On Sunday early mornings, it can be quiet but that is when you see all the litter. Otherwise, the hotel is perfectly located minutes from centre of soho and within walking distance to WTC and 9/11 memorial. We walked to brooklyn bridge from here in 15 min. If you wish to avoid the crowd and Chinatown activities, exit the hotel and cross Canal Street into Wooster or West Broadway for a more pleasant walk. Avoid walking along Canal St. We had to request for a room change due to noise from the traffic on a lower floor. The upper floors do have a remarkable view of midtown depending on which side the room faces. The wifi Internet is good in some rooms but can be spotty on the corner room away from the routers. Bring your own router to connect to the Ethernet cable and off you go at blazing speed. We didn't dine at the restaurant but the breakfast buffet option for $14.95 seem reasonable. The beds are comfortable. The rooms size are reasonable for NYC. Some reviews complained on the size and noise. This is NYC and not the adirondacks. I wouldn't eat anywhere along Canal St. Walk a few blocks into soho on Prince St. or Elizabeth St. for better options. I would stay again if the rates are reasonable and if there are deals.

Stayed here for 5 nights due to its proximity to Canal St but I wouldn't stay here the next time I visit New York simply it is located in not nice neighborhood. Also, the hotel alone looks new but not well maintained though. The staff was friendly, at least they tried but you can still sense the forcefulness of the staff trying to be friendly. It's better but you need to hire more staff that's friendly in their core character. But anyways, the room is typical Sheraton but I was surprised with the lack of sports equipment when I used the gym. Again, I will choose another starwood hotels the next time I visit New York.

Tiny, hot air conditioning was bad and noisy, they forgot to do our room a few times..It was July last year sorry I could not find the right month in the drop down menu! Position is food although outside is full of abusive sellers in the street that disappear once police comes!

We (2 adults, a 2yo, a 4yo) enjoyed this hotel. It really is in a great location, right on Canal St. The subway is a couple blocks away in any direction.Pros: Friendly staff, clean hotel, amazing location.Cons: LOUD (obviously, it's NYC) but we were on the 20th floor and it still sounded like we were outside, small and awkward hotel lobby (there is a huge pole in the middle of the lobby and the cafe area makes it awkward to walk to the elevators without bumping into someone), the person checking us in said they gave us an amazing room even though it was only one bed. I'm not sure what was amazing about it. Maybe the view of the apartment building next door?! Also, please note: when they say the valet will take 45 minutes to get your car...THEY AREN'T LYING!!In conclusion, we would probably stay here again mostly for the location. Close to the Financial District, Chinatown, Little Italy, West Village, and easily accessible by subway. It's also a couple blocks from the Holland Tunnel and West Side Highway for easy access in and out of the city.
Easy to book caused problems before the trip with writing emails, that I would have problems with my Mastercard. I contacted the hotel in front and it was not true.A lot of trouble for nothing.

I preferred to locate in Tribeca because of a work assignment. I got a great rate on Priceline. Took the subway from Penn Station and walked to my meetings. Free internet on many computers in the lobby. Nice bar/lounge. I did not use the restaurants. Elevator service a bit slow. Well-trained staff from front desk to housekeeping.Very clean.Room was small but ok for NY. High floor and pretty quiet for Canal Street. Good week in NYC.

I stayed at the Sheraton Tribecca for 3 nights in August. I picked it because it was the only hotel I could find in NYC under $200 and that was centrally located. I was a little skeptical going there but it turned out to be a pleasant experience! The hotel is on Canal St. right at the edge of SOHO and Tribecca. There are great restaurants and shops in walking distance, as well as many subway lines. The hotel was clean and the room was a reasonable size for NYC. In addition, the gym was well equipped. For the price I paid, this hotel provided good value.

I was very happy with this hotel. The staff was great and the rooms were modern and very nice. I was upgraded to a king with city view. Right on Canal so minutes from great shopping and restaurants in SOHO.

I stayed at this hotel for 8 nights and chose it primarily because it was close to my work sight. The staff were AMAZING! First night I got in, the wonderful lady at the front desk agreed (very easily) to upgrade me to a higher floor. Not only did I get a higher floor, but it also allowed me access to the very cute club lounge and outdoor roof top. Everyone in the hotel was friendly and helpful! The location is fantastic; A 30 minute walk to the meatpacking district and a short cab ride to all other attractions. The room had a gorgeous view of the city. I was proposed to on the rooftop terrace and I'm glad it was at this hotel because I will definitely be returning to the hotel! The housekeeping staff even left a sweet handwritten note in the room for me! Absolutely a wonderful place to stay!!!!!!

I was in NY in August at the Sheraton Tribeca. My experience was good because the hotel is clean, quite central and very comfortable. There are several subway stations nearby and a ten minute walk away is the World Trade Center. The only drawback the price is not exactly cheap, especially the breakfast. However I would recommend it, good experience.

The room was small. We requested double beds but only single beds were available. No pool, no hot tub, no sauna. Very good lobby area with a large number of computers with big screens for free use, with free printer for black and white (but $1/page for color). Location is good, in the north of Tribeca with easy walk to SOHO, China Town, and LIttle Italy. Subway entrance on the same block.

This hotel isn't up to the standard I would expect of Sheraton: The rooms are very small, there is no fridge or minibar (annoying), no free wifi, the rooms are noisy, you hear other guests coming and going.I was really disappointed. There are so many better options. The location is ok albeit in a slighty rough part.

Stayed @this location, which btw is pet friendly, for several days while visiting NYC. The location is perfect, near to Chinatown, Little Italy, TriBeca - great for walking! Staff was very friendly, very helpful. Comfortable beds! Smaller boutique type rooms. Will def book again!!

Clean functional NYC hotel. Well downtown so along way away from most of attractIons. Room size good and bed comfy. We moved uptown later in our stay and room much smaller. Wifi free in lobby but $9.95 per day in room.

I spent one night at the Sheraton Tribeca and have nothing to complain about, it was a mostly average stay. The hotel is clean and has attentive staff. I was assigned a handicap accessible room which was not my first choice but I was only in NYC for one night and looking for something cheap and easy in Manhattan. I would only book this hotel if you received a special rate, it is not worth the rack rate or any other premium price. Although there is a subway stop around the corner, the area is not the best - I understand you are in New York but I would have preferred to be more centrally located or at least have a better surrounding area. I have stayed near the Financial District before and have not minded the distance in exchange for amenities and appealing neighborhood - but unfortunately the Sheraton Tribeca does not stand out in either category. It is an average hotel and I would not pay more than lower than average prices. If you have business to attend to in Tribeca then by all means this would be very convenient. If you are looking to spend time as a tourist or anywhere else in Manhattan search elsewhere as this property may not be worth the stay.

I need to state that I've stayed here twice but it's always been paid for my by work, so I'm not sure what they paid for the room each time. With that, I will say that I've stayed here a total of 5 nights throughout the last year and have not been disappointed.Check-in process each time was very smooth and welcoming. The staff has always asked if I needed anything and they have made sure I was taken care of.The bell staff was great as well as there was one time when my baggage was late from the airline and they made sure to update me regularly with the baggage they had.I took advantage of their wireless internet service the last time I stayed there and had no problems. Granted, you are going to pay for internet at this hotel, but I never had any problems with it.The location is probably the best part about this hotel. I loved being close to SoHo since I had to go there to shop for clothes after my airline lost my baggage for 2 straight days. There are also plenty of places to grab a drink or food nearby.I would highly recommend this place if you happen to be staying in the area.

I read all the reviews prior to our stay, and didn't know exactly what to expect. Hotel was conveniently located on canal street, about 2 blocks east and west of 2 subway stations. This made it convenient to travel to and from the hotel, even with the subway work that seems to go on every week in NY. Rooms are nice, good size for NY hotels, clean and modern. Didn't have a view from my room but, didn't matter. Also, no problems with noise from the streets affecting sleep. Standard amenities (i.e. tv, iron, etc). Would stay again on another trip to NY.

This hotel was a fantastic surprise in my trip to New York. I booked it using my starwood points and it was one of the cheapest. For this reason I did expect a nice place but nothing special. Instead I was very positively surprised. First of all the room was of a reasonable size (consider in New York the space in a hotel room can be very limited), but most important of all I had a wonderful view on the Manhattan skyscrapers. I could even see and take photos from my window of the Empire State Building. The bathroom was new and spacious and included a large shower. The location was very convenient on the border between Soho and Tribeca with a subway station just on the corner and a couple of other stations at walking distance.The service was simply perfect. Nice, professional, ready to help people at the reception and wonderful concierge personnel that provided many good advises, bookings and support for everything including the car to the airport (obviously more expensive than a normal taxi, but easier to catch!!!!).Overall I think that this hotel has an exceptional price/quality ratio for that area in Manhattan and I would highly reccomend it to anyone going to Manhattan. I believe you can not spend less for a similar service!!!!

A friend and I recently stayed here for a girls' weekend. We loved the hotel. Upon check-in (at noon, so early), my room was not ready. They said it would be ready around 3pm and because I was on the club floor, they let me wait in the Club Lounge. At 2pm, a gentleman brought me a key to my room. I didn't even have to go back downstairs. He was friendly, answered my questions about which subway train to take and offered to take my bags to the room. Our room was small (as most are in NYC), but clean and in the usual Sheraton style. Sweet sleeper bed, desk with lamp and plenty of outlets (how many times is this a problem for you?). We were on the club floor, so we had access to the Club Lounge which had the most amazing rooftop patio. 24 soft drinks, water and coffee, a computer with internet access and a printer and hor devevores at night and breakfast in the morning. Granted, get there early for breakfast because things go quickly.The hotel is on Canal street and was easy walking to Little Italy, SoHo and Washington Square. There were 3 subway stations close by anytime we wanted to go further. Anytime we had a question, the staff answered us and offered suggestions.This is one of my new favorite hotels in NYC, just for the convenience, cost and ease of location.

The pros: The views of lower and middle Manhattan were amazing from the both our rooms and the terrace, lovely part of town, in stylish Soho and only a few blocks away form little Itlay and Chinatown.The cons: DISINTERESTED staff didn't interact with customers, (One word answers), The terrace was quite like a zoo, kids running everywhere, it seemed that the terrace was just another lobby (not a club), there was no fruit, which was annoying ( seen as though i like to watch my weight). Cheapest towels, small rooms. Key cards were DISCRACEFUL, working ONCE than having to get a new key because it WOULDNT work, after leaving my room forgeting my camera, i tried to open the door, but the key cards wouldnt work then having to wait 5-10 minutes for the lift to come, getting a new card and waiting for the lift again, 20 minutes had gone past since i had forgotten my camera in my room. Overall: good location, nice veiws, but basic, cheap, unhelpful, as annoying.

There were three of us and we stayed in a king room.We stayed 8 nights and it is great value and a lovely hotel in an amazing location. We couldn't fault the staff and service. Everyday we had a number of extremely helpful staff giving us directions, suggestions, or just wishing us a good day. Thanks Corey for getting us great theatre tickets and making us laugh.

I frequently travel to NYC -- and there are very few areas of the city that I do not feel safe in. While the hotel is good with great views form the Club Level and a fun vibe, I would did not feel comfortable with the neighborhood. When I was dropped off by the cab -- and asked him if it was safe to walk around, he hesitated and said, "it's ok". You know that hesitation of not wanting to say something bad. I then got a call from my boss who was in the cab with me when I got dropped off that said, "you definitely should not walk around this neighborhood by yourself." She is a lifelong New Yorker, so I trust her judgement.

I recently stayed here for the weekend with my husband. We were in town for a concert and some sightseeing. I booked this hotel through Priceline's Name Your Own Price for $150/night. Here is the breakdown.PROS:-Very good location if you're interested in Soho. Walking distance to lots of great shopping and restaurants (try Dos Caminos for dinner/drinks and Le Pain Quotidien for breakfast!)-Close to several subway stops-Staff is VERY friendly and VERY helpful!-We had a great view of the city.CONS:-Parking is AWFUL. $55/night (this may be standard for NYC) but it took an hour for them to bring us our car. When they brought it, there were pop cans in it that were not ours as if someone had been joyriding!!! Hotel said they rented out a service, but in my opinion, they are still responsible for my car!!-Room seemed clean, but the carpet was sticky... It didn't complain as we were only there for a short time, but we had to walk around with our shoes on.-EXTREMELY little bathroom counter space for toiletries.TIPS:-Ask for a room on a high floor and away from the elevator to avoid noise.

As a native NYer, I never expected to stay in a hotel in the city but an opportunity came up to leave the kids with grandparents and enjoy a night out! My husband booked the "deluxe" room through his Starwood Preferred member plan. We were focused on staying downtown and near South Street Seaport, Ground Zero, and LIttle Italy/Chinatown. This was the perfect location. The room was small but having traveled all over Europe (and my husband, the world) we found it perfect for the two of us. Unlike, Europe, the bed was extremely comfortable! My husband could not find a valet to park the car upon arrival so he found a lot on the corner. Easy to walk to, no big deal. We were awakened by an obnoxiously loud "girl" early in the morning complaining about the hotel but otherwise it was quiet. The view of the Empire St. Bldg was very nice. We had some tapas across the street and walked around, finding a nice wine shop down the street. In the morning, we picked up some muffins, fruit and coffee from the mini Starbucks in the lobby and hjeaded out for our day off from parenting! It was a good value, modern, clean and convenient.

Booked the Sheraton Tribeca on their website. Subsequently found a better deal through Kayak, which normally should be honored by Starwood's best rate guarantee.Starwood didn't want to honor the lower rate, as the hotel had meanwhile also adapted their rate to the lower price. And the fine print is: the rates have to be available at the same time -- not the time the customer is checking, but the time SPG is checking. This makes a lot of sense, if rates at competitor websites disappear, but it's a clear breach of trust, if it's actually the Starwood hotel that adapts the rate to the lower one. SPG recoginzed that and made two (interesting) recommendations: 1) Never make an actual reservation, before a BRG claim is approved... well, does that make business sense for them? I'll let you decide.2) Contact the hotel directly, as they are (still) offering the lower rate even to walk in customers. They should typically match it. Well they didn't: The assitant FO manager was insulting me, because I was making "illicit" claims and the General manager, even confronted with the threat that I would take my following 3 nights elsewhere wasn't smart enough to see, what kind of havoc he caused, by insisting on his lousy 40$ (which he wasn't getting from any other walk-in customer, but insisted on collecting from a loyal SPG Platinum...) Congratulations, 3 nights of revenue lost, definitely will never come back to this hotel, and now that I requalified for Plat (in July), will bring up my stays with Hilton & Intercontinental.... Hopefully the guy is not paid by any kind of economic results of his franchise or SPG.Let's be clear: BRG is just an annoying marketing feature, they shouldn't be offering it, rather honor Platinum privileges, no matter the channel.Oh yeah: the hotel. Modern lobby, location next to subway station, the rooms (was Platinum upgraded to what they called a Junior Suite: a 4th floor room with a sofa, next to the lifts and a view through dirty curtains onto a inner courtyard wall about 10 feet away... really not worth it. The Platinum lounge has a cool terrace (closed evenings though), the staff seems to have been snatched away from the local fastfood outlet or a drycleaner without any training... In the 45 minute I was there (8:30am) they subsequently ran out of plates, cream cheese, orange juice, preserves and then the lady broke the espresso machine while trying to put some beans in there.... no way to replace either of that in a decent breakfast time frame.A once in a lifetime experience... exactly once, and please: DON'T GO there, it's not worth it.

Stayed here for 4 nights with family in a two double bed room. The rooms are small and tight. It was quiet though and clean. Also relatively new. The service was v good. The staff were friendly, helpful, happy. They gave out water, snacks, umbrellas when it rained. The level of service was a pleasant surprise and appears to be how they differentiate themselves. The computers in the lobby can be freely used for a long time. That was great. A great location - head north to soho or south to TriBeCa. Heaps of great restaurants close by. Close to subway lines.

The rooms are small, as others have mentioned, but that can be expected in Manhattan. However, I would expect a little more for the price they charge. I was not hoping for much; I needed a one-night stay for business in the area, so I was just looking for a decent night's sleep and some room service for dinner (after a long day of cross-country traveling). Unfortunately, I had some unpleasant experiences. First of all, they have a club lounge on the 21st floor with some food and drinks -- the same floor as my room. Problem: the building is a very tall and narrow building (22 floors) with only 3 elevators, which turned out to cause severe elevator delays when I was there. On one trip up to my floor, people from seven different floors got ON the elevator on the way UP to get to the 21st floor. (I'm not sure if this was just random chance, or if the hotel actually upsells club lounge access to those staying on non-club level floors; if the latter is true, then the hotel is unfortunately causing the elevator delay.)Second, when I got to my room (late in the evening, around 11:00pm or so), I found there was no room service menu. I decided to call room service and ask them to read me the menu (most hotels have a very limited menu for late night dining, so not a big bother to just read me the options). The person insisted they would just bring up a menu to my room and that it would only take 5 minutes. 5 minutes go by. Then 10; then 15; then 20. About 25 minutes after I first called, I called back and the same person told me "oh, we think we delivered the menu to the wrong room." When I asked them to bring up the menu, the person told me that it would take too long because the kitchen would be closing in 15 minutes. To his credit, he then told me he'd read me the menu (why didn't he just do this in the first place?!). I ended up getting a $20 chicken quesadilla (not bad, but $20 for a quesadilla? with no sides? I was hungry after a long day of traveling...). I do give credit to the person for making it all happen (with quick delivery) in the end.Third, I was awakened very early in the morning to the sound of crashing plates/dishes coming through one of the walls. I'm not sure why/how, but this was not a pleasant surprise.Fourth, the front desk, at check-in, did not offer me my Starwood elite amenity choice. I was too tired to realize this until I had already made it to my room.

This hotel is well-appointed and well maintained, and the staff is generally friendly and helpful. One nice touch is several free internet computers are available in the hotel lobby, and they let you print for free as well, which we appreciated and utilized. And our view of Midtown and the Empire State Building was to die for!The hotel is located close to two different subway lines (A/C/E and 1/2/3), making it easy to get Uptown for shopping and shows. While the area outside the hotel on Canal Street seemed a wee bit dodgy at night, we never felt threatened by it or gave it a second thought when returning late into the evening. Just around the corner on Broadway are many great shops, cafes and restaurants, making for a pleasant stroll. They could have better stocked the room with more towels and bottled water, foam pillows, shower gel and a hotel services directory, all of which had to be requested from Guest Services and sometimes more than once or unsuccessfully. The three elevators are small and perhaps inadequate for a hotel spread over 22 floors as it would often take 5 minutes to get up or down to our room on the 20th floor.All and all, I'd stay here again, especially on a great special rate like this time.

Well located but that's it. Rooms are small, poorly decorated and furnished, in rather poor conditions, tiny bathroom needing a few repairs, towels of the lowest quality. Breakfast was disgusting, organisation and service below standards. A few staff were OK, but not all. Terrace put forward as a key feature was not accessible, etc... This is not my first bad experience with sheraton, I think they simply get it wrong and are far below their competitors with a few exceptions around the world, but on average they are below average !

Stayed here for 6 nights with my family. The location is perfect with walking distance to many tube-lines. The rooms are spacious and clean. There is no refrigiator on the room (but can be rented). Had some trouble with wireless connection in the room, but it worked well in the common area. There were also several PC's and a printer which the guests can use.The staffs are friendly and helpfull. When we was in the city there was a heatwave and we were offered a icecold bottle of water (for free) when we left the hotel. We found a staff that was willing and able to meet most of our request such as change of rooms in order to stay close to our kids, giving us access to the club area.Even though the hotel is very close to the highly trafficed Canal Street we were not bothered by the noise in the rooms.

First time staying at this side of manhattan. It was a rediscovering experience for me regarding NY.I'd say... basically, forget about going upper, specially during summer. Incredibly packed with turists (like me), very annoying. Stay down there, where you can find great interesting art galleries, restaurants, etc.The hotel? Nice big rooms. Not so great front desk.

We pricelined the room for $150 a night so already we were getting a great value. I had called ahead to get a double room but when I arrived they said none were available. After trying to charge me a $75 a night up charge I produced my Starwood number and was swiftly moved into a double bed room. The rooms are small, about 285 sq feet but we were able to fit four people comfortably. The rooms are extremely quiet. We heard no street noise and no hallway noise even though there were people i'm rooms on either side of us. We also got no noise complaints even though we were up late and were very loud. The hotel is in the best location to SoHo, the west village and the lower east side. The only draw back is the roof deck is reserved for platinum members. A huge plus is the 24 hour tribeca bagel bodega. The had great sandwiches, bagels, water and beers. I will stay there again.

Took my mom to NYC for her 80th birthday. The Sheraton Tribeca was a great, convenient location! Subway access is a breeze. Staff at front desk, concierge, bell staff and club level were all superb. Extremely clean rooms and superb housekeeping staff. Club level was outstanding. From the food to service to view. Afternoon happy hour on club level (21st floor) can't be beat. Only negative was boisterous children at breakfast one morning in club. They were extremely loud and really bothersome to all guests. Staff should have mentioned to parents to quiet them down. Otherwise- great weekend and would highly recommend the hotel to friends.

I've stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca several times for work trips and am always satisfied with my stay. The location is great as my office is in Soho and is centrally located for downtime visits to Soho, Chinatown and Tribeca. The rooms are clean and the gym has all the basics for a decent workout. There's a great deli next door that has amazing fresh juices to order and there's a coffee bar in the lobby of the hotel. Looking forward to my next stay there.

Couldn't have done it without Tom "The Mgr" and Justine "The soon-to-be-assistant mgr." I cant thank you enough for helping me last night. Its people like these that will bring me back again and again. That being said.....Sheraton Tribeca is very nice. Its modern and chic, well staffed, well appointed. DO NOT HESITATE TO BOOK THIS PROPERTY!!! And dont miss the view from Floor 21 Club. Great bar...Great Time!!!Thanks again Tom and Justine !!!!!!!!

The hotel is in a great location to walk to many downtown areas, and it's a standard Sheraton with comfortable beds and clean bathrooms. The room was decent sized for Manhattan (about 275 sq. ft. but felt bigger), and the staff was very friendly. The first floor lobby feels kind of cramped, but it's not a big deal and doesn't detract from the stay or the experience.I'll definitely stay here again and would recommend it for people who are looking for someplace to stay in the area.

My son and I arrived by car on Thursday the 12th of July, 2012 for 4 nights. We actually came up a day early, looking forward to our time in NYC. In the four days we were in Manhattan the only rude, discourteous experience we had was with the front desk staff at this hotel- management no less. The rest of the staff was apologetic and accommodating and tried to correct their errors, but couldn't do so without the management's authority. My hotel arrangements were made on my behalf through a 3rd party such as this site. My room was paid for in advance. $128/per night- supposedly a savings off the rack rate of $226/per night for a 4 star in TriBeCa. I will first say that the hotel is clean and neat and what I would expect for a 2 1/2-3 star accommodations, Otherwise, it fell short on amenities and service, especially service (no concierge or club level service that I could see, no refreshments, nothing and I mean nothing complimentary to make you feel welcome). I gave them my credit card at check in for incidentals, only to be charged $621.00 for my stay although I had already pre-paid. I was also given a king room to share with my 20 yr old son, and refused any other accommodations although I offered to pay the difference. The manager on duty was snarky and proceeded to lecture me about going through third party vendors for my accommodations, as they can't guarantee the room type for that price. I reminded the manager, I was only asking for TWO beds, and I was wiling to pay the difference. I was told there were no rooms with two beds, not even a suite (not even a sleeper sofa), and that they were oversold and couldn't accommodate the people coming in. She proceeded to make calls to another Sheraton hotel at my proding to see if they had a room with two beds, but I was have to pay the difference in price I was told. After she started to go through the list of hotels, I dismissed her effort as I reminded her there was a purpose to our trip and we couldn't be delayed any further. There was no empathy for the position we had been put in- in fact, she acted as thought she was doing us a favor to let us stay there. Her behavior was the most HOSTILE I have ever experienced from someone in the hospitality industry.To add insult to injury, we ordered chocolate cake from room service on July 14th of our stay and became very ill. We could hardly leave our 10x10 cell of a room. When we did leave, it took several phone calls and trips to the front desk to get the $621.00 cancelled out of their system, although they "claimed" they had contacted my bank the day before to do so. LIE. I spoke to my bank at the front desk, and was instructed that all the hotel needed to do was cancel the charge out of THEIR system, which they had not done. My bank would update the balance in 48 hours. The money was NOT the point, the point was UNAUTHORIZED charges to my card. It's called FRAUD. When we left on Monday the 16th and my car was brought to me, there was a large splat in the center of my hood that was rust in color. It appeared something had dripped on my hood wherever they had parked my car. There were scratches along the driver's side door as if someone had tried to get in the vehicle. My back up camera no longer works and the manual hood latch is disabled. I have tried on several occasions since Monday to contact Lowell Bebe-Center to no avail. I have been told he is "away from his desk". I have been told a manager on duty will contact me. We'll see, but I'm not waiting to take action. The only souls on that front desk who showed a pittance of kindness was Andrea and Giselle. BTW- I am a Starwood Preferred Guest, but I've never seen it as an advantage, so I've given up trying to use it. I recommend staying away from the Starwood Brand. Go Marriott or Intercontinental if you want a real 4 star experience.

This hotel is right on Canal Street, so you can also pick up a knock off designer handbag from guys who whisper the names of their wares as you pass. Our friends got a deal on this hotel through priceline, so we decided to stay there as well for convenience. Honestly, the rooms are fine. The bed was actually really comfortable and we slept very well. It's a short walk from Soho for shopping and about a 30 minute walk to Meatpacking District. Here were some down sides. 2 of the 3 elevators were broken so there were lines that would form to wait for them. a woman next to me told me that she and her husband just started getting a drink at the bar to wait them out because sometimes it would take 45 mins. that was pretty annoying since our room was on the 16th floor. I think others have mentioned this. valet parking is $65/day, so we did street parking and just left the car parked the whole time we were there and walked and cabbed everywhere. No minibar, which i guess is the case in many corporate hotels? Canal street traffic is a bit of a nightmare. I know it's NYC, but this was really crazy. It's just such a great city and there are more enjoyable neighborhoods to stay in my humble opinion. Probably wouldn't stay there again, mostly because there are so many great options.

My Wife and I were in town to visit family. The hotel was in the perfect location for everything we wanted to do----Little Italy, China Town, Wall Street, 9/11Memorial etc. It provided us with the perfect jumping off spot for our daily walks and activities. The staff, from the front desk to housekeeping , was very helpful. We were on the club level which gave us the opportunity to sit out on the roof top (21st floor) with a drink in the evening and take in the NY skyline and for breakfast to watch the sunrise--beautiful and relaxing.

We really enjoyed our stay at the Sheraton Tribeca. It is centrally located to areas like Greenwich Village and Soho. The hotel staff was great, in particular the bell staff. David was a particular favorite of ours. We would definitely stay here again!
I almost canceled after seeing other reviews. Location was perfect, no problem with long elevator waits, room was spacious an clean, and staff was helpful. Short walk to shopping and restaurants.

Apart from being vastly overcharged for show tickets by conceirge (double price than tickets are sold at the door) this was an excellent hotel.The service was good, although our complaint (regarding tickets) was handled very slowly by the manager.Rooms were clean and location was very good.Very good value considering all other 4* hotels in area are a lot more expensive.

I spent the weekend here with my family, and I couldn't have asked for more. Great location, service and accommodations, and a great value on the weekend.We had a club suite plus a king room for our family of four, and the club lounge was amazing. Great patio with a view, hit breakfast and evening snacks and cocktails.Can't wait to return.

The furniture is VERY boring and run down. We asked for a suite, and they gave us a hotel room with a couch. There is little closet space and no dresser. Yes, the rooms are comfortable, but I would never pay this much for a room of this quality. The TV has virtually no channels, and the amenities seem to be scarce. I won't stay here again. Holiday Inn looks with a Westin price. Ridiculous. Also, Canal street is quite possibly the ugliest street in the city. Every street surrounding the hotel is charming and pretty, Canal looks like a tacky version of venice beach with graffiti.

I booked this hotel through priceline and was initially skeptical about the location/quality of the place. But the hotel turned out to be very convenient to reach. There are a lot of subway stations with different lines nearby, making the whole of NYC accessible without very many changes. Wall street and Freedom towers are also within walking distance. The shopping area of Prince street is also very very close. You can also check out the hustle and bustle of the Chinatown which is practically next door.The room we were given was comfortable and cozy without being extravagant . The bathroom was spacious and spotless and the bed was great after a hard day touring around NYC. The wifi is free in the lobby and you can get free B&W printouts. The staff at the front desk was sufficiently helpful. I would recommend this hotel for stay near downtown NYC if you can get the cheaper prices online.

This hotel is great for staying one night, that's it. I am a preferred guest for Sheraton so I stayed in the upper levels. The waiting time for the elevators is horrible. Trust me. Everyone is always complaining about it. I was on the 24th floor (or 22) and I had to plan at least 15 mins ahead. because I had to wait for the elevator which you can imagine takes a while, and then when coming down, picking up people as well. HORRIBLE!In terms of the room, it was clean. Service so so. Valet parking expensive. TIP: If you cross the street you can park overnight for $10-15 dollars less.
Great location but rooms are small and they have a smell that does not go away.Gym is small with minimal weights but adequate treadmills Over all it's a good stay when it is a bargain price

The location of this hotel is great. However, we booked on Priceline ($125/nite) and called twice to confirm that we would get two beds instead of one. When we arrived, they wanted a confirmation # for this request. We were not offered one and did not think to ask. The manager told us he could switch us the second nite. Great. When we asked for our new room # on the second day, the front desk staff said there were no rooms w/ 2 beds. Luckily, one of the staff was there when the manager talked to us the day before and found one for us. Such a hassle. The hotel gym has good equipment (3 treadmills, 3 ellipticals, 1 bike, dumbells, 3 swiss balls,cable multi-station) but the machines need to be wiped and the floor is dirty.
