Beds are very comfy, 4 down pillows. So much potential at this hotel. (David, the doorman was very helpful and the one bright spot.)

We stayed in this hotel for one night only as our ATI coach tour started from this hotel. After staying at the Park Lane hotel on Central Park South for one week this was a shock. What a difference a hotel makes especially when you pay the same rates.The reception girl was very rude, she ask me to provide a credit card to put on file, but as it was I had misplaced my credit card and I suggested that I instead put down a cash deposit, but she said to me that if I did not produced a credit card I could not stay. Now I had this happened before in other hotels and a cash deposit was readily accepted, so I proceeded to empty my suitcase near reception and go through all my belonging to find the misplaced credit. We proceeded to our room which was tiny, overlooking the rooftop of the building next door, nothing special and for $322.00 for the night it was a rib off.Canal street where the hotel is situated is very dirty with sleazy people trying to sell you things on the footpath, the shops in this area are down-market.The only consolation was the hotel was near Little Italy which we had a nice meal.Finally I could not recommend this hotel to my friends or family, you can do so much better for the price elsewhere.

We stayed at the Sheraton Tibeca only as a convenience as our bus tour was departing from this hotel. The cost was excessive for the basic facilities that were on offer. We stayed one night prior to the tour and upon checkout our friends had a dispute with the female receptionist regarding some phone calls. The receptionist was extremely rude and when we asked to speak to the Manager she said he was not available. Only again because of convenience and we had prepaid we stayed at this hotel one night at the completion of our tour. We encountered the same receptionist as our first visit. She was difficult to begin with and then recognised us so her attitude changed immediately to being very helpful and friendly. All other staff we encountered were helpful.I would not stay at this hotel again but for those that choose to it is close to China town, Little Italy for all the fabulous restaurants and Soho for shopping.

I booked on priceline.com I called and asked for 2 beds instead od king size, the lady on the phone assured me that she will reserve it for me.When I arrived they told me that all rooms are sold out and I cannot upgrade even if I paid extra. I checked online on sheraton website and priceline website and they still had rooms availableSo when I confronted the manager, he claimed that they are overbooked however if someone bookes the room online then they will get the room!!!!Basically since I booked on priceline they didn't want to do anything..I also asked for fridge and all their fridges were sold out as wellOn second day we waited 45 minutes for elevators and finally we took the stairs....I stay in sheraton hotels twice a month for business however I would never stay at tribeca again!!!

I frequent Starwood properties, and as I had a meeting in the lower part of Manhattan, I decided to stay South this time. The location on the street of the hotel is only OK - you don't feel like you're in the best part of town while walking to the property. Once inside, the staff was nonchalant with my check-in, and I went straight upstairs to bed. I grabbed a cab the next morning to head to my meeting, but because the property was on a side street, hailing a cab, even with help from the bell-staff, was difficult. All in all, I wouldn't head back to this Sheraton because of location.

I was placed in this hotel after winning it on priceline. More than exceeded my expectations. The room was very very clean and new. It was quiet even on a party night in the city. The wireless is free downstairs and you can even PRINT! Plus, there were two models checking in at the same time. 100% recommend! Great area too, walking distance to Soho Grand where there is a great bar, and walking distance to Ben's Pizza.

Stayed at three hotels on this trip to NY (Marriott Marquis and Hilton Long Island) and this one was by far my favorite! The hotel seems very new and modern. Rooms were on the small side but well laid out and had clever storage. The service here is outstanding! We received a warm welcome when we arrived late in the evening. We unfortunately just got to stay one night here but they accommodated our schedule by giving us a late check out. I am quite particular and I would definitely return to this gem in Tribeca. Great value as well.

I decided to drive into Manhattan since I was travelling with a senior citizen and two teenagers. We visited the Statue of liberty via New Jersey and it was so simple and fast. No long lines and I did not book ahead. We took the Holland Tunnel and then Canal street to the hotel. I had looked for parking via Bestparking.com and found one at 311 West Broadway which was half a block. I you use the coupon at best parking its only 40 per day which is cheaper than the hotel rate. Note parking in the area is free after 6pm but no overnight. The rooms were great. Not too big but comfortable and could not speak more highly of the beds (super comfortable). I loved the area since there was plenty of shopping, bars and dining options. I would definitely return with the girls to go shopping and dining. We left sunday night and it was easy to get out of New York since we were close to the tunnel and traffic was not that bad.

Room was small but clean. Within walking distance to courts. Rudely awakened by housekeeping staff in the morning. Didn't mind the initial knock on the door but it was followed by a phone call at 9 am, complaining that I wasn't cooperating with housekeeping. I explained that checkout wasn't until 12 noon, and flying in from LA, I didn't appreciate the intrusion. Also, windows were not well sound insulated, making for a noisy night.

Coming from Texas, I was always told to beware of New Yorkers because they have a chip on their shoulder. I'm going out of my way to review quite the contrary. My family's stay was very enjoyable at the Sheraton Tribeca. Services, amenities, and room accomodations were excellent. I personally had a great experience with the doorman, Michael Valentino. He was so helpful in every way. Starting with the parking, he always conducted service with a big smile. He also gave great suggestions for places to see and eat. It changed my perception of New Yorkers entirely. My family felt very welcomed staying there.

Not quite Tribeca but location on Canal St between TriBeCa and Chinatown would be a good fit for business and leisure travelers wanting to be off the beaten path a little bit - the neighborhood just seemed to be a bit more quiet, a bit less crowded which I liked. Since I traveled for work and the office was in close proximity, I felt the location was very good. Hotel lobby is modern and brightly lit, and visitors seemed to make good use of the bar and computer workstations nearby. Room was OK - for the most part clean though I noticed a lot of smudges and scratches on the walls that probably could be addressed in a more thorough cleaning session. The outdoor patio was nice though - I think there are only three rooms that have this feature so request it if you can. These rooms are on the second floor only. Fitness center is just a room converted into a workout room with some various cardio and exercise machines. I'd recommend to anyone needing to travel for work in the SoHo area or anywhere south of there, but that's about it.

The stuff does not know how to treat customers.Disrespectful, unhelpful, by phone they tell you something and when you arrive there they tell you another.The worst service i ever had.I thought Sheraton was other thing..

I was surprised to find this hotel so pleasant. Everyone was kind and very service oriented; ready to help in any way. We got there a bit early and immediately held our bags and asked if we needed anything (since our flight was a late one they also kept our bags until departure time). The room was comfortable; the maid wrote me a note each day wishing me a good day. The location was the only thing not great for me, but for anyone wishing to go shopping at canal street they would love it. I did love that we were walking distance to Soho as well as many great restaurants and subway.Palm Beach resident

After reading some of the previous reviews my partner and I were worried about the location/ area of the hotel. This could not be further from what we actually found once we arrived! The hotel itself was very comfortable- one of the best beds I have ever slept in. In true NYC style the room was a bit small but you don't go to NYC to stay in your room. The housekeeping staff were fantastic as were the front of house staff. They were very knowledgable about local restaurants and nothing seemed to much trouble. The location could not have been more diverse and cosmopolitan, right on top of Canal Street and Chinatown but at no point did we ever feel unsafe. My next visit to NYC i will be staying here again. A little tip would be dont pay for breakfast in the hotel as it costs a fortune, just pop next door to Tribeca Bagels. it is open 24 hrs a day and the breakfasts such as bagels, pancakes and fruits are amazing and so so cheap!!!

I have to start out my review by saying that I prefer SPG (Starwood Preferred Guest) properties whenever they are available because their loyalty program (with affinity AMEX card) is great. I usually stay at the Le Parker Meridien or the W Union Square but I wanted something a little cheaper this time and needed to be downtown so I gave the Sheraton Tribeca a shot.I was really impressed with this hotel, I think it gets major points for being new and fresh, that puts it above a lot of hotels in NYC. It isn't a St Regis so you have to compare it to other similar star level properties, but it really excelles in all areas when you do.The staff was really nice, the doormen/valets are friendly, always offer to help, but never insist (I had no problem carrying my own bag, walking to the subway, etc). The check-in process was fast and efficient, it took about 2 minutes at most. The lobby is fairly small and doesn't have a big open feel, it's somewhat narrow, but it's pleasant. The Sheraton Link is a really nice amenity. I was able to get a ticket for MOMA, print it for free, same with my boarding pass. The log-in system they use works really well with your name and room number, it allows a certain number of free B&W prints per day etc, all really easy to use and a very nice little amenity.There is a coffee bar that is Starbucks branded, a bar, and a restaurant. I had the brunch buffet one morning, it was nicely stocked, clean, had lots of options, wasn't anything amazing but was really nicely done, the staff again was friendly.The guestroom was nicely done, I had a standard King room without a view, on the 10th floor. The elevators are key-card locked which is a nice safety touch. The hallways are bright and well air-conditioned. The room is small but smartly designed, the king bed in comfy, there's a chair, dresser, desk, desk chair, TV and clever little shelf by the corner to keep your keys and phone on. The TV is nice, gets HD channels, but there is no in-room movie service (probably cheaper these days). There is also a connection panel for HDMI, iPhones, etc so you can bring your own content. The bathroom is small but has a real shower (so much nicer than a shower tub), shelving by the sink, everything was clean which is the most important!Overall if you want to be in this part of town the Sheraton Tribeca is a great option as long as it's price is lower than the higher end options. I wouldn't hesitate to stay here again.A note for people not familiar with NYC, the Sheraton Tribeca has a great macro location but not a very good micro location. You are a few short blocks to SOHO and 1-3 blocks from most of the subway lines, but there is literally nothing within a stone's throw of the hotel, you can't go downstairs and find a charming little cafe, you have to hoof it for a couple blocks. I didn't mind that but could see it being a negative for some. A side note, after a 6 hour flight and 1 hour car ride I was really hungry, I went to the sketchy looking $1 pizza place a block over and (unless I was just really hungry) it totally hit the spot and seemed legit, so worth it if you want to save some $ or are just really hungry and need food ASAP.I can't think of anything the hotel needs to improve on, it's really nice for what it is, and certainly meets and likely exceeds the Sheraton brand standards, good job to everyone working there!

There have been some mixed reviews on this site, but I was pleased with the hotel. It is one subway stop (A/C/E) from the WTC, which was helpful for me.Good: Lobby is excellent. Staff was great to me. Bedding is better than Westin. Bathroom was good.Okay: Room size (but it's NYC). Noise from Canal Street (my room faced Canal and was on a lower floor).Bad: Elevators were very slow in the early evening (5p-6:30p).Recommendation: for good dining and shopping close by, walk north towards Houston Street. It can be a bit of a walk, but there are a lot of cool places to get lost and find a good meal (I ate at Lure).

The Sheraton Tribeca completely met my expectations for a 4* hotel. It's a newish building, a very nice and bright lobby, clean rooms that are decently sized for NY, and has friendly and attentive staff. I was on the 15th floor just in front of the elevators facing east and I was nervous that I'd hear the elevators all night long, but I heard nothing. Also, didn't hear any noise from the city below. The bed was very comfortable, the desk was a good size, there was an arm chair also if you wanted to chill and the armoire was a great place to store clothes.Regarding the area, yes Canal Street is not the ideal STREET on which to be situated, but you cross the street and you are in Soho and you walk 100m around the block and you are in Tribeca. Fantastic location almost directly in between the Tribeca Grand and the Soho Grand!The only negative, and this is a stretch to find one, was that the chambermaid knocked on my door 9:30 Sunday morning to ask when I was checking out so she could clean the room. Although she was very pleasant and smiley, I thought that this was a bit 'off' and made me feel a bit like my meter had run out.That said, I would totally stay here again.

We came in from LGA (SIDEBAR: $33+tip for Carmel car service - took them from and to LGA & will definitely use again). I agree with so many others on the following points: 1 - the surrounding area is not the nicest BUT the hotel is close to the subway so it’s very easy to get around. 2- the staff we dealt with were not friendly at all WITH THE EXCEPTION of the cleaning staff who in addition to being very, very friendly, left little notes in our room. 3 – rooms are small, not a problem for my husband and I though because they were well laid out and (most importantly) clean. We could definitely hear street traffic from our room on the 10th floor but it didn't bother us. 4 - $10/24hrs of WIFI in the room and although it says free WIFI in lobby, it looked like they only allotted 45 minutes per use (not sure what happens after the 45 minutes are up bc I was done in 25). Regarding the lobby WIFI – it is RIDICULOUSLY SLOW – think dial-up slow – took me 25 minutes to check in for my flight, something that would have taken less than 5 at home. In addition, as it was my first time in NYC, my husband called ahead to see if it was possible to get an upgrade on our room (hoping to surprise me with an awesome view). NO DICE!!! (see pic) He asked again a few days later and was told there was nothing available but what bummed me out the most was when I was sitting in the lobby later that day, I heard the lady at the front desk give an upgrade to another guy. ***eye roll***Also, after reading what some other people paid I am just disgusted that we were charged almost double per night (over $400) with no access to the club lounge or complimentary breakfast (or as I mentioned above, even a decent view), so I would not stay here again or recommend it to any of my friends. HOWEVER, if you can get a “good deal” and just want a clean room with no special amenities you probably won’t have a problem with this place….

We stayed at this hotel on the basis of the reviews on Tripadvisor. Yes, the area is dingy, turn left out of the hotel to Chinatown and Little Italy and it is dingy. Turn right and you are in SoHo which is great. The hotel reception staff were not very friendly when we checked in after a long flight. The rooms are small, the bathroom is only big enough for one person at a time. No WIFI in the room unless you want to pay $10 per day. We had a problem with our flights and needed to stay an extra two days in New York - the hotel quoted us $500 per night consequently we moved hotels which was quite inconvenient. Next time we will stay mid town.
the has a perfect position, you are directly in Soho, China Town and little Italy, the subway station is not far away....we enjoyed our stay in NYC and in this hotel

Very flexible staff. Late check out, early check in. Upgraded on checkin. Good location near transport and the nice part of Tribeca but also located near canal street which is a little shaddy. Would not recommend 100% to older people for that reason.Only thing I could want is free wifi in the room not just downstairs + internet is too slow. Overall great.

Perfect localization: near Soho, Tribeca, Meatpacking. Nice place to go out at night. Much calmer than Midtown/Times Square. And near all the best shops, such as Zara, Sephora, MAC, Desigual, Uniqlo, Victoria Secret and so many... But if you like to be in the middle of chaos and tourist place, so Sheraton Tribeca is not your place.It doesnt have frigobar, neighter wifi in the rooms. These are the negative points. Staff is great , specially Steve Lamour. We had a huge problem with the checkout and he helped with all his patience.

We stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca over the weekend and were very pleased with our stay. We booked a club level room and stayed on the top floor (22nd).Location: If you’re not familiar with Canal Street, it’s the road that splits SoHo from Tribeca and Little Italy from Chinatown. It’s busy, crowded and yes, even a little dingy, but it’s very much NYC. If you want an upscale Madison/5th Avenue atmosphere, then this area is probably not for you. If you come from a quaint village and the lead article in your local newspaper is about Mrs. Wiggle’s cat getting stuck in the her tree, this area might not be for you. If you like dive bars, restaurants with whole Peking ducks hanging in restaurant windows, hip art galleries and street vendors selling everything from used copies of Kerouac to tacos al pastor to fake Rolexes, then this neighborhood might be for you. The hotel is walking distance to almost everything in SoHo, Tribeca, Chinatown, Little Italy and the Village. You can catch most subway lines along Canal Street, so other places in the city are easily accessible by public transportation. The area is also a foodie’s dream with lots of great places to eat just a few blocks away. If you’re not up for exploring Chinatown, I would recommend just waking up and down the streets between Canal and Washington Square. You can find Indian street food (kati rolls) and Japanese curry dives, Mario Batali’s low end restaurant (Lupa), high end French pastries (Payard) and on and on. If you are going out to dinner, be sure to make reservations, especially on the weekends. Opentable.com comes in quite handy for that. I’ve read reviews complaining about the dearth of taxis on Canal….well they’re right. And most New Yorkers don’t try to catch taxis on east-west streets like Canal. You have a much better chance of finding a taxi on the north-south avenues. So if you’re headed north, walk over to 6th Ave. and if you’re headed south, walk over to Broadway. Also, you should know that most taxis change shifts between 4 and 5 PM, so no matter where you go in NYC, you will not be able to catch a cab easily. Rooms: I found our room to be on the small side, but the view from the 22nd floor was nice (see picture), even if it was only a view of the roofs above Chinatown and the Lower East Side. The king bed takes up most of the room, but at least it was very comfortable. It’s a fairly new hotel (opened 2010), so you can expect all the latest features – flat panel TV, lots of outlets, ergonomic desk chair, etc. The bathroom has no tub, but the step-in shower was large and water pressure was decent (see picture). The sink counter, however, is very small, which was a real issue for my wife with her small arsenal of toiletries. Also, you should be aware that there is very little closet space (see picture). So, if you bring a large suitcase, you will have to leave it out in the room, which will make the room seem even smaller. Room Location: As you already know, the Sheraton is located right on Canal Street, which is a very busy road, day and night (see picture). From the 22nd floor, we didn’t hear any street noise, but sirens were clearly audible. I’m guessing the noise might be a bigger issue on the lower floors. I walked around some of the floors and it looks like the rooms are arranged in the following way. Rooms ending in -9 and -11 are right in front of the elevators. The lower room numbers (-1 to -4 and -6) are at the back of the hotel overlooking the much quieter Lispenard St. Rooms ending in -19 and -20 face due north and I’m guessing on the 10th floor and higher, probably have some of the nicest Empire State Building views. The downside is that they overlook Canal St. Other than the Presidential Suite, I don’t think any rooms on the club floors face north towards the Empire State Building as that space is occupied by the club lounge. If you do stay on the 22nd floor, you should know that the lounge is on the 21st floor. I would recommend just walking down the stairs to the 21st floor, because it’s much, much, much faster than the elevator. Just remember to take your key as you will need it to get to the 21st floor.Service: In general, service was friendly and professional. The check-in and check-out procedure took only a few minutes for us, but at times, I did see some pretty long lines. The people in the club lounge were especially diligent and worked hard to make the guests happy. The cleaning staff was also very friendly and accommodating with extra towels and stuff.Miscellaneous: The soap and shampoos were standard and nothing special. Internet in the room was $9.95 per day, but was included in our rate. The connection was fast throughout the day though. If you need free access, you can always go to the lobby. Skip the water in your room and grab a complimentary bottle of water from the big cooler by the concierge on your way out.Public Spaces: The lobby area is a relatively small, but comfortable space. With a Starbucks, a computer kiosk and a bar, it’s often crowded though. My only real complaint about the lobby is that the check-in area is very cramped, especially during peak check-out times in the morning. There are 3 elevators that serve the guest floors. We never had to wait too long for an elevator, but they were often packed with people by the time we got to the lobby floor. We didn’t visit the bar, restaurant or gym. Club Lounge: The indoor part of the club lounge was small and a bit sterile, but the outdoor terrace was especially nice with excellent views of Midtown and the Empire State Building (see pictures). The breakfast was typical American fare, but much better than I had expected – assorted bagels and muffins, croissants, yogurt, eggs, sausage, bacon, home fries, assorted fruits, orange juice, coffee, tea, etc. The afternoon hors d’oeuvres consisted of vegetable samosas, deep fried pork wontons and assorted cheese and crackers (see pictures). There’s also Starbucks coffee, sodas and bottled water. Wine and liquor are extra. My only complaint about the lounge was that there were A LOT of freeloaders – people sneaking up from other floors with club floor guests. At times, it felt more like a Days Inn than a club lounge. If you do come back during the middle of the day, the lounge is pretty much empty and the terrace is a very nice place to unwind. One last note, the lounge got pretty crowded during breakfast time and many people were out on the terrace. I imagine that it must be unbearably crowded in the winter or during inclement weather when the terrace is closed.Overall: We were very happy with the Sheraton Tribeca and were pleased with our stay on the club level. For $250 per night (which included all taxes and fees), we thought we got an excellent deal for Manhattan and would return again.

I've stayed at this hotel about 12 times since it opened for both business and pleasure. It never disappoints. Most of all, I've received great service consistently from the front desk to the club lounge. As a Platinum staying 100+ nights a year in SPG properties this has become one of my favorites and my go to for NYC. One of my favorite club lounges in the country. It's not big but the roof deck is amazing (not many better spots to have a drink in NYC) and always stocked well. Rooms are average size for NYC, even with an upgrade. On several occasions there have been no upgrades available as people have mentioned but it's not a huge hotel and it's become pretty popular given quality and location. The location is fantastic, tons of great restaurants nearby (Peppolino is my favorite) and shopping, etc.
It was a great hotel. David who worked at the hotel did a great job!

My husband has platinum SPG status and we're paying with our American Express platinum card, both and each of which entitle us to a room upgrade. Upon checking in late last night we asked for the upgrade and were told no suites were available. One thing about me, gee call me crazy, I HATE BEING LIED TO.We travel A LOT, so please don't try to game me. That is why we have platinum status here and and Hyatt and Hilton and Marriott. We expect the loyalty programs to matter to the properties at which we stay.After being told that no rooms were available by the front desk clerk Dawn (who also looked at the screen and asked the other woman at the desk Erica) if she could 'do that' to which Erica replied 'no'.I came upstairs to my thimble sized room and looked online. Guess what? The online system showed a reservation available for a suite from 6/1/12-6/3/12. Amazing, huh?So instead of calling the concierge line, which is what I probably should have done, I called the front desk. Another song and dance about how one suite was available Friday night, and then a different one for Saturday night. I said to Dawn, 'no problem, we'd be happy to move from one to another so as not to be in such a small room' to which she replied 'no once you're in there they won't make you move - I'll just leave a note for the morning clerk who blocks off the rooms' - i.e. I don't want to be bothered with you so I'm going to push you off on someone else.We came here because we thought it would be a nice change from mid-town, because guess what else? Apparently the Westin in midtown doesn't want to bother having a club lounge for their platinum members any longer and isn't even open on weekdays for more than a few hours and not at all on weekends.So I think we'll be going back to Hyatts where our status is actually recognized and appreciated. Like many other former loyal travelers, Sheraton Tribeca, we will be staying elsewhere.Thanks for your fabulous courtesy and service. You really know how to treat your loyal guests.
Great location, friendly and helpful staff, rooms very clean and well equipped, the most comfortable hotel bed ever.

As others have said, this hotel isn't in a great location. However, it's very close to the subway and other nearby LES and Soho destinations. We stayed knowing this and had a great time. The rooms are new, clean and what NYC room sizes tend to be! The layout maximized the space and the bathroom was very well done. We would stay again for a good rate vs other more expensive hotels in the area. It really depends on what your priorities are - service and amenities are solid Sheraton - location not so great.

This is a nice NY City hotel in a great location. The rooms are not big (its New York), but they are clean, reasonably priced and the staff is very friendly - plus the location puts you just a few blocks from every major NY subway line. Its about a 5 minute subway ride to the Financial District, 9/11 Memorial and the boat to The Statue of Liberty. Maybe 15 minute ride to Times Square. Add on that SoHo is just a great place to "hang out" and walk around. Tons of stores and coffee shops to hang out at. If you really want to see the true NY, but not be in tourist-central, this is the place and hotel.

Not much to look at from outside the front door, but excellent on the inside. Lobby and rooms are smartly furnished and look trendy and clean. The lobby has a computer station with about 4 computers you can use. NY Times and WSJ available in the lobby daily. The lobby bar also looks pretty good. Staff at the front desk were helpful and efficient.Skip the expensive and rather blah hotel restaurant and walk 2-3 blocks to Soho for better food. Breakfast was not complimentary so I got some fresh fruit and bagels from the Tribeca Bagel store next door (better sit-down brunch to be had in nearby Soho or the Village). Rooms are snug as is typical for NYC, but with nice decor and nice showers. The fan in the bathroom is noisy so we kept it on at a minimum only for showers. Adjustable heating/AC worked well. There is some street noise as you would expect in NYC from cars, but this dies down during the night. There is free Starbucks-branded coffee which you can make with the machine in your room, along with a small selection of Tazo tea. There's also one free bottle of filtered Nestle water (watch out - the small one is free and replaced daily by the maid, but the slightly larger one on the opposite side of the desk is $5). Location is very close to Soho and you will be very satisfied with it. However, the block surrounding the hotel is Canal Street which is less nice, so you have to walk a block to get anywhere good. But this only takes a minute. There is a LOT of traffic congestion right around the area so don't be surprised if taxi drivers are reluctant to take you directly there (this will get them stuck in traffic for an hour right around the hotel) -- get around this by telling them you're willing to walk a couple blocks and that they don't have to get into the traffic.Nice hotel overall. I would come again. We bid on Priceline so didn't know what hotel we'd be getting until afterward, but were happy with the result.

I must say the front line staff at this hotel is probably one of the best I have encountered at any of the Starwood properties I have stayed at in New York. The front desk staff is always friendly and helpful as well as the bar staff who always make a good drink and conversation. With that being said the management personnel of this hotel have managed to diminish all this from my loyalty to their hotel. I have stayed at this hotel at least 50 times since they opened a little over a year ago. I stayed one night after they opened and switched hotels from the Sheraton Towers in midtown making it my hotel of choice because of the location and also the staff made me feel at home. Two weeks ago I had an emergency with my daughter and had to cancel my reservation on short notice. The price I booked was higher than normal at a rate of around $850.00. I have become used to this staying in Manhattan for almost 20 years and understand supply and demand and that it was also a very busy time in the city. I called the hotel as soon as I received notice that my daughter was in the hospital to cancel my reservation at 2 AM. To my disbelief I was informed that I would be charged a 1 night cancelation fee of $850. I asked the manager I was speaking to if he could see my history of stays and my Platinum status and he informed me he could. I asked him if this meant anything in helping waive the fee and the response I received was "We do appreciate your loyalty but unfortunately you are outside of the cancelation time." I have never on one occasion canceled a reservation with this hotel and even this did not hold any merit with them. I was in a hospital waiting room with my daughter extremly ill and I myself was exhausted and I asked if there was someone else I could speak to and I was told to call back in the morning and speak to someone in the sales department, but with this I was told I could try but would get the same answer. The manager I spoke to had absolutlely no sympathy for the situation. I understand this is a business and there is money to be made but treating your loyal customers like this is not acceptable. After calling the next morning and speaking to an extremely rude gentleman in the sales department I was told once again I would be charged (I guess the blunt manager I spoke to the previous evening was right!) I hope the one night of money they made off my canceled reservation is better than the 50 more nights I would have stayed in the coming year. If you are a Platinum Starwood member I would recommend not staying here. Even though I am not a fan of the hustle and bustle of midtown I would choose a Starwood hotel in that area if you would like to be treated like you have loyalty to a brand or more so to a specific location. You are not recognized when you need it here. Luckily my daughter is out of the hospital and we will be staying in New York on a family vacation next month and I can assure you we will not be staying at this hotel.

The hotel was very good. Nice rooms with super beds+pillows. Starbucks coffee in the room. Also a Starbucks in the lobby. David&Mikey were ever so helpful. It only rained one day and they would give you an umbrella. Really good Italian just around the corner. Subway nearby. Get a metrocard you can add money to. Very easy to use. Nice bar with normal prices. The gin&Tonic was good.Complimentary p.c.'s with Internet free for a hour in the lobby. WiFi you have to pay. But since we had 2 smartphones&tablet that was not so bad.

The Sheraton Tribeca is my companies hotel of choice and I don't have many complaints. Its very convenient to the Soho area, has good service, and is relatively well taken care of. The downside is that despite its location there isn't any great restaurants within a few blocks (which I thought was impossible in this part of New York). My last room that I stayed in had some sort of leak such that every time I took a shower a big wet patch appeared on the other side of the room. I thought it was strange that no one else had said anything about it in which case I would hope they would stop renting it out until it had been fixed. Splitting hairs here; bottom line its very good but not perfect.

In NYC, it’s very hard to find good-value upper-tier accommodations, but I would argue that the Sheraton Tribeca has solved the dilemma for now. It’s a fantastic, modern property in a bit of a dodgy area, but access to transportation is excellent.The Sheraton Tribeca is on Canal Street, between West Broadway and Broadway. You are a block away from the A C E subway lines (the blue line), which heads directly to Penn Station (for Amtrak and Newark services), the Bus Terminal (which is just a couple of blocks away from Times Square), and the Upper West Side (Central Park). You’re also a few blocks away from the N and Q and R (yellow) lines, which heads in the direction of LaGuardia. In short, you’re in a hub of subway options.This compensates for the fact that the immediate area around Canal Street feels fairly dodgy. Most of the nearby shops close after 7 pm, and there isn’t a restaurant or a café scene in the immediate area. I’d say that the area is “safe”, but it’s pretty dingy around the neighbourhood at night. This isn’t a huge deterrent, since you really are only a block away from the A and C subway lines. The hotel itself is perfectly safe, with elevator access with card swipes.And, this is compensated for the fact that the Sheraton Tribeca is sparkly new. Rooms are to the Sheraton new brand standard, with modern furnishing, beds and desks, and a clean bright washroom area (my room had a shower only, not a bath). The fitness centre, while small, had modern equipment (treadmills and ellipticals, 3 each, but no normal bike), and the bar “LINK” computer area downstairs is modern. This is much better than other Starwood properties in New York, particularly those around Times Square (with tiny old rooms in need of renovation, see some of my previous reviews).And, surprise, while Canal Street is busy 24/7, my 5th floor room was fairly good for noise insulation. I still recommend earplugs in any big city, but I have absolutely no complaints about the facilities and the service.The Sheraton Tribeca is a fantastic facility in a fairly sad neighbourhood. You are not far from SoHo, which is nicer, but the immediate vicinity is pretty dismal. But don’t let that discourage you – the neighbourhood means that this will be one of the cheaper quality Starwood options, and I strongly recommend this property.

Location is OK - turn left and left for the subway and for Tribeca, cross the street for the boutiques around Mercer Street and left for the tat and knock off merchants on Canal.A nice walk to the financial district but not so nice a walk down Canal St at night - so it's like getting on the plane OK if you turn left not so nice if you turn right.Probably the most comfortable hotel bed I have ever slept in and the staff are very welcoming and friendly. No free wifi in the rooms but wifi in reception/bar/coffee shop is fast and free

I guess I can understand if you have business in the area and need a place to stay. Maybe you're having lunch with Robert De Niro while attending the Tribecca Film Fest. Or you have shopping to do on Canal Street. But if it's anything else, spend the money and take cabs from mid-town. It's just that the location isnt that great. Most people don"t like walking in the neighborhood during the day let alone at night. It's not far fron Chinatown and Little Italy, but far enough that it's a little uncomfortable. The room itself was nice - I had 1720, which had a view of the Empire State Building. Smallish, but clean and newer carpet etc. There is no bathtub in this room, just a shower. No extras either, dont expect q-tips or a shower cap here. Service was spotty. There was not a door-person to help with cabs, and I had to walk ten minutes to find one at a very busy time of day. I also saw people trying to flag down cabs everytime I came back to the hotel. Food was good through room service. Had a problem getting through one night as they must have been very busy and I kept having to call back after they would put me on hold. Lobby is small, there is a workout room on 2, but I didnt try it. Canal is a very busy street, so if your room is located in the front you will hear early morning trucks driving by. I did come down early at 4:00 am the last morning as I had a 6:00 am flight and they got me a cab at that time and said they could call cars. Overall, while they can't help the neighborhood, they should try to differentiate with service, service, service. Needs some tweaking.

I was very adamant about the location, however the reviews from fellow tripadvisor customers glared about the service. Sold. Let me first talk about the location. My fiance wanted to explore Tribeca, SOHO, Little Italy and the Brooklyn Bridge. In a nice circle, we leisurely did all of the above in one afternoon. The service made our night and weekend. It was mine and my fiance's third anniversary. I had sent Lowell (the manager) an email Friday morning requesting if there was any possible way to make our hotel stay the proverbial icing on the cake. I didn't hear back for a day, so I thought my email had got lost in the clutter (obviously a weekend in NYC in the spring season is a busy time for those in the service industry). After arriving at 3pm to check-in and greeted by Eurasia who with a warm welcome congratulated me on my third anniversary. Fully surprised that the email had gotten through, been read and been informed that the room would have a "nice view", I rushed to the room and my jaw dropped as I first set my eyes on the skyline view from the 15th floor. I then hear a knock at the door and to my utter surprise and nice gentlemen delivered a bottle of champagne with chocolate covered strawberries along with a very sweet card compliments from the hotel and their staff. My fiance was flabbergasted by the room, view and everything the hotel had done to my our night in Tribeca truly wonderful. As a business owner, most small business last due to serving their customers needs. This hotel will be around for a long time.

We were so happy with Louis from security really going above and beyond trying to get our daughter's retainers back to us in Canada. Also, the housekeeping department for keeping them for us and not just throwing them out - saved us lots of money by not having to replace them!The hotel was fabulous - looking after everything for us while we were in New York. The staff was very friendly and the room was amazing!! Compared to what our friends had just ten minutes away we were in a very luxurious accommodation at a reasonable price!! The beds were very comfy and the hotel was quiet and very well situated for jumping on the Metro.

The staff was very helpful and pleasant. It was just blocks from the office and also in my old neighborhood. Lots of great places to eat, shop & check out art. The room was comfortable. Look forward to staying there again soon.

A chain hotel on Canal Street would not ordinarily be my first choice in NYC,but this was a very nice surprise. Clean and recently upgraded, the rooms were spacious and comfortable. I was very surprised how quiet they were. The bed was very comfortable and clean, the armoire had just enough room for my hanging items and the must-have safe big enough for a laptop. There is even a robe, which is a excellent touch. The bathroom was not terrific. Better lighting around the sink and more room for toiletries would be my suggestion. I had just a shower with no tub and it looked to be ada-compliant even tho the rest of the room wasn't. The bathroom also had an automatic fan with the light that made it impossible to be in there and hold a conversation or hear the tv. The location is excellent if you want to be downtown. Right on the subway, plenty of markets and amenities nearby, and easy walks to TriBeCa and Soho as well as financial district. For the great rate I got, I'd stay here again in a heartbeat.

A very clean hotel in a very convenient lower Manhattan location. Both SoHo and Little Italy are short walks, and downtown and Greenwich Village are slightly longer walks. Good subway access as well, for excursions to mid-town. Canal Street can appear a bit dreary, so if you must have a nicer street view, move uptown and pay 100-200 dollars more per night. Otherwise, this is a find for a good price.

I took my girlfriend to NYC for a weekend away...and it was a great hotel. We had a room on the 22nd floor, and even as a Platinum member with Starwood, I would highly recommend this property...the staff are great and very friendly and greet you coming and going!

I reently completed a nice weekend stay at the Sheraton Tribeca.The hotel is new and clean. It is located in a busy spot on Canal Street and borders the SOHOand Tribeca neighborhoods, whch are filled with boutiques, art galleries and restaurants. The hotel is also about a mile walk from the World Trade Center / financial district. As Lifetime SPG Platinum, I was well treated and provided with a Junior Suite on the Club Floor.Room size was adequate and everything was clean. The 21st floor Club Lounge is quite nice and has a great outdoor patio with panoramic views of mid-town and the Hudson River / NJ. The valet parking worked out fine. However, you need to provide 30 minutes notice for the hotel to retreive your vehicle from a neighboring garage as the hotel does not have its own underground garage. Overall, a nice hotel in a prime location for covering the trendy neighborhoods in lower Manhattan.

I was lucky to get a room at the sheraton tribeca last eastern holiday. I have been staying in Boston for a while and had the idea to spend my eastern holiday in New York, to stroll around, for shopping and just enjoy the city.The sheraton was really a great place to stay. It s quite central, close to everything by taxi and the hotel itself was really up to standart. From the outside, ur kind of hesitating if you have made the right choice, but after stepping in the lobby u get really great feelig and are just looking forward to enjoy the rest.Great service and great value..Thank you

We traveled to New York City to celebrate a Wedding Anniversary. One of our daughters and her husband accompanied us. We chose the Sheraton Tribeca due to it's location....only 3 blocks from the International Culinary Institute. We were invited guests of Jacques Pepin. We shared a demo there with students of the Institue. This experience was the fullfillment of #1 on our "bucket List"When the Front Desk at the Sheraton learned the reason for our visit, their smiles broke into extra-ordinary happy greetings whenever we crossed the lobby. The young woman at the front desk was exceptionally welcoming and we have determined by the reception given us that we shall look to the Sheraton group first in all future travels...Don and Patsy Hendrickson

My husband and I just stayed here for the weekend and really liked the location. It's at the West end of Canal street so you don't have to deal with all of the vendors if you choose not to. We like to be close to Soho and it's perfect for being able to get to all of the shops and restaurants in that neighborhood easily. Our room was a decent size for NYC and it was very clean. The lobby of the hotel is pretty nice with a business center, bar, and Starbucks coffee bar. We will definitely stay here again on future trips.

Spent two enjoyable nights in this hotel. Modern, clean room with comfy bed. Friendly reception staff. Subway round the corner. Plenty of restaurants and bars nearby (Tamarind, 5 mins walk away, was an impressive, modern Indian restaurant. The lamb vindaloo was wonderfully spicy!) Canal St itself is on the dingy side, but during the day Tribeca and Soho make an interesting bohemian change from areas like Midtown.
Great place to stay in new York !Clise to everything in soho area . Nice size rooms

I needed a hotel for two nights near Soho. $143/night and photos of the view from the hotel sealed the deal. Canal Street is not lovely but the hotel was nice and the view uptown is great. When I stayed there in February, most of the hotel guests were young, international travelers and that gave the place a cool vibe. My room was up-to-date, clean and perfectly comfortable. The hotel breakfast was underwhelming and overpriced, but Starbucks in the lobby was just fine. The staff was very nice and helpful. Early morning walks through the neighborhood were marvelous -- easy access to Soho and Tribeca, as well as taxis to go elsewhere.

We are a family of four and had 2 "deluxe" king rooms on the 18th floor. The rooms are small but well done. I doubt the rooms can handle more than 2 people each.We took the club level option and that made this hotel stay amazing --- the 21st floor terrace has great skyline views of the Empire State Building. Breakfast is included in club access and my 4 thought it was perfect --- scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, hash browns, fruit salads, local bagels, pastries, whole wheat croissants, etc. The evening hors d'oeuvres are very simple but soda, water, tea & coffee are free and the views on the outdoor terrace cannot be beat! if you don't have club access, Tribeca Bagels is right out the front door and open 24/7 - you can get drinks, fruits, smoothies, bagels, sandwiches, etc.Location was great for us. We didn't want midtown this time. Access to the A C E subway lines is just around the corner, but it was well located to walk to SOHO, Lower East Side (Tenement Museum), Little Italy & Chinatown. We shopped at Pylones, Kate's Paperie, Sur la Table, Paul Frank, Vans --- all on foot!Only real complaint --- even on the 18th story (1810 & 1812 are facing 6th -- Ave of the Americas) the traffic beeps and sirens in the evening are fairly constant until quite late. It did not affect our ability to fall asleep or stay asleep but might have if we were on a lower floor.Parking is $55 per 24 hours - no in and out. Call ahead 30 - 45 minutes for your car to be brought around.You must use the key in the elevator to go UP. I saw many people confused with how to do this. Look at arrow on your key, insert it and take it out. You will hear a little beep. Press your floor # and you're good to go! (You do not need to use the key to go down to the lobby.)Priceline "named hotel" option was $229 Saturday then $159 Sunday + 14.75% taxes + $3.5 room fees but included breakfast and club level terrace access. Great deal!

I read many of the reviews on the site before staying at the hotel. I had some concerns about the location but in all honesty it wasn't that bad. If you want the touristy feel to where you are staying then this is not the hotel for you. But if you want a decent hotel at an ok price this is a good home base for seeing NYC. We go to NYC multiple times a year and we love to walk everywhere. This was perfect for walking to the world trade center area and we spent the rest of our time in the meatpacking/soho area. If you have the chance definitely try to get to the end of the high line down in the meatpacking district. It was beautiful. So back to the hotel...it was very clean...the room not a bad size considering we were in NYC...the staff was so nice. We didn't try the hotel restaurant b/c we prefer to find something while we are out and about. Take a walk down 6th street (Avenue of the Americas) and try the French Roast for breakfast, it's probably 10-15+ blocks from the hotel. We also didn't realize how many restaurants there were in the meatpacking district which we will try the next time.I would defintely not worry about the area at night. On a Friday night it was pretty quiet around the hotel. Yes it is on a busy street but we walked from the train station on 34th so it didn't matter to us. There were several parking garages in the area and the subway was very close.
Stayed 4 nights. Good locotion with view to Empire State building from room. The only thing we missed was refrigiator on room, the other things was very good.

This is a really great place to stay. First off, the staff makes sure that everything is great. Managers Priscilla and her assistant Dawn straightened out a National reservation mistake and made sure that we were more than satisfied with the results. The computer system in the lobby is free and good, I used my computer on their wireless in the lobby for free, (in room has a charge). The staff greeted us each time we entered and made sure they helped us if we needed anything. The place is new and clean. Maps and travel info was plentiful and the staff again helped us numerous times with the subway and other instructions. Try the restaurant right next door; great food, reasonably priced, great selection, and open 24 hours. Great location also.

Visited New York for 5 nights in February 2012, and booked the hotel via priceline.com so only paid around £70 a night which, for New York, isn't bad at all.Upon arrival, we requested a twin room (I'd also made the request by email prior to arrival) only to be told that they didn't have any available. Athough my friend and I are good friends - we aren't * that * close and had no desire to share a bed. However after a couple of minutes the receptionist managed to find a suitable room for us and at no extra charge.The room we were given was on the second floor of the hotel and came with a suprisingly large balcony - alas with it being February it wasn't exactly the sort of weather to sit outside although the weather was nice during the stay.The room itself was fairly small, with limited space for 2 people to hang clothes. The beds themselves were very comfortable and ensured a good nights sleep. Limited amount of complimentary coffee provided but not tea which was a shame. Bathroom was a decent size with a very powerful shower and a deep bath. Left a tip for the chambermaid each day and got a nice note in return each evening when we returned which I thought was a nice touch. Wi-Fi in the hotel is not free except in the lobby and quite expensive compared to what I'm used to in the US.Didn't use any of the hotel facilities other than a couple of drinks in the pleasant bar.All in all, a pleasant enough stay - especially given that there a number of subway stations within a couple of minutes walk.

This is the second time I stayed there, and I am amazed, a year later, that the service from ALL hotel employees is still at such a high level. Cudos to the hotel manager, Lowell, who I had the chance to speak with. He is a constant presence in the lobby during busy periods, and the staff reflects his enthusisam for fine service. All are immediately ready to assist - politely approaching guests to see if they may help with a cab, your bags, or any questions you may have. Exceptional service for NYC or anywhere. Paul from RI will be back, Lowell! Thanks.

Although rooms aren't big, they are ok. The gym is good, the breakfast is quite expensive, but they have a starbucks coffee in the reception! Free Internet in the lobby, and 1 block from soho. The hotel is on canal st that it isn't very nice but is not dangerous.This hotel accept pets.The price is very reasonable for being in Soho, and it is brand new.
Fun Hotel that was nice and clean in a great location. All the employees went out of their way but David the valet went the extra mile every time we needed him.
Spacious, clean, updated rooms. Great lobby bar. Only downfall is that it's on Canal street. Overall great stay.

Just needed a place to sleep during 4 nights of fair at the Jarvitz center at 29 st. and still be close to all the parties, and cool clubs.The double rooms are big, clean and the Starbucks coffe maschine made my mornings even better.No problems getting taxies and late check out was no problem on my last day of shopping in nearby Soho

We needed a place to stay for 2 weeks prior to moving into our apartment. We chose the Sheraton because it allowed dogs, was close to several subway lines, was near soho and had a good rate. The hotel has a business traveler vibe. The bar/ lounge area is not hip or trendy and the chair cushions had quite a few stains on them. There is coffee bar in the lobby that serves Starbucks coffee in the morning- big plus if you need coffee to get your day going.Rooms: Clean, big comfortable beds, new modern bathrooms. (No bedbug issues). Placement of the tv was a bit odd- needs to be on a arm so it can be adjusted. We payed a bit extra for a skyline view, which was really nice at night.Location: The area right outside of the hotel is not wonderful- but walk 1 block north and you are in soho or go south and you can find some great restaurants in Tribeca. Easy access to the subway.Staff:Everyone was extremely friendly to us and our dog.

The Sheraton Tribeca is located right in the heart of Canal Street and is a good base of operations for lower Manhattan. The hotel is very clean and for NYC the rooms are a good size. Also the room rates are good, again keeping the location in mind. Excellent options to explore the island by subway or taxi. Free wi-fi is a nice touch. I found the staff friendly and the 21st floor lounge access provides a good breakfast and a wonderful outdoor patio with great views. I did not eat at the main floor restaurant, come on it is New York after all with plenty of restaurant options. About 30 minutes from LaGuardia in good traffic.

This is a very nice hotel - very clean and comfortable with modern decor. There was a fantastic deal online for $169 a night plus tax (a "deluxe room" - a bit larger than regular room - with a king-sized bed) and we paid an extra $10 to stay in a room with a view of the city on the 18th floor. Had a fantastic night's sleep! The hotel was just a five minute walk away from the subway (Canal Street) and also minutes away from some great galleries in SoHo and restaurants in Tribeca. I'd definitely stay at this hotel again.

Stayed here for 4 nights with my mom (she was visiting me in NYC). Overall, the hotel was very clean, in a convenient location and the staff was very friendly. The room was a decent size for NYC. Other pluses: free gym, computers/wi-fi in the lobby, no bugs (I obsessively checked)One things I'd like to state for people traveling with pets -Since I live in NY, I didn't check in with my dog. I went back to Brooklyn and got him so he could stay with my mom for a night or two (he is small - 7 pounds). When I brought him, I let the hotel know and they provided a bed and bowl. The first night, no incident. The second night, my mom and I went to dinner and when we came back to the hotel room, my dog was GONE. There was a note on the bed saying he was at the front desk. Turns out, someone complained that he barked so they removed him. This was pretty disturbing. Again, the hotel staff was SUPER friendly - my dog seemed fine and in good hands. But to remove my dog from the room without my consent? They said we had signed a waiver allowing them to do so, but we were never given a waiver (of course they had us sign one right then). I had my husband come pick up the dog then as I didn't want our pup to be a nuisance nor to be put in a situation like this again, however people traveling with pets from out of town wouldn't have this luxury. Make sure you are clear on this hotel's pet policy & what they will do if your dog barks.

We were in New York for our son's wedding and stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca, where a block of rooms had been reserved. From the numerous calls preceding the wedding to change or add reservations, to the day we checked out, we received nothing but excellent service, friendly staff and pleasant accommodations (the rooms were a little small but the beds were so comfortable!). The lobby included very efficient computer/printer set up and a nice lounge area for gathering with friends and family.All our personal requests were met and I feel they went above and beyond to make our stay the best it could be! Friendly staff from doormen to desk clerks, to concierge, to management and housekeeping. I would recommend this hotel to any individual or group of individuals staying in Soho/Tribeca who want a clean, comfortable and reasonably priced place to stay.

Really nice new hotel with reasonable pricing and small but functional rooms (about normal for NY, though smaller than Le Parker Meridien and other higher-priced places).Rooms were new and clean, with great hookup center for computer/dvd player into tv and nice work desk and chair. Was kindly recognized as an SPG Goldmember and got upgraded to a nice club room with pretty city view. Club is beautiful here, with great views from the club terrace and nice outdoor couches.Biggest issue was the need to swipe your card in the elevator, which sometimes just couldn't read your card, so i (and several others) were stuck several times waiting to have someone else make a lucky swipe, or swiping repeatedly until it worked, while the elevator went around on its own. Although other reviewers complained of noise from Canal Street, we were on a high floor and never heard any traffic noise.Other than the elevators, the bed was great, room and bathroom was great (with cool new shower), and location was great for a funky chinatown pubcrawl/long walk to to the village. Always appreciate the free Starbucks coffee. Will come again.

This hotel needs a company wide seminar on how to treat customers. Customer service does not exist. My husband had a business trip in New York and I tagged along for several days. He left very early Monday morning for work and I was in the hotel room by myself when I realized that the linens on the bed had a stain of poop! Grossed that I had slept on it, I called the front desk. They were neither apologetic nor sensed the grossness of the situation. The front desk notified me that they would be sending someone. They sent one male janitor who came into the room to change the sheets. Again, no apology or anything. About 30 minutes later, still in my PJ's and about to get into the shower, the same male janitor knocked on my door. There had been no call from the front desk so I was wary of opening my door. I opened it and stood at the front door asking what he wanted. He claimed he left his master key inside my room. I told him I had not seen any key but he barged in the room and started searching for it himself. At this point, I was really uncomfortable. Our room was in the corner, I was by myself, and this strange man was basically looking through my stuff. Of course, he didn't find anything and left. I was late for an appointment and didn't stop by the front desk to tell what happened. I came back into the hotel in the late afternoon and asked to see the manager. When I told her of what happened, again, she wasn't very concerned, was condescending, and kept asking me what the big deal the situation was. She referred me to the housekeeping manager who sent me a small box of chocolates to ease the situation. We left the next day. Their valet policy is to call the front desk 30 minutes in advance and they will have the car waiting in the front. (I think the place where they park is actually pretty far and that's how long it takes to walk and drive back). We called it in the next morning at 6am. My flight was leaving at 8:30 so we were cutting it close. We came downstairs after the allotted time to find the wrong car sitting in the front. We informed the front desk that it was the wrong car and they had to call over to the valet deck. Instead of hurrying and trying to get our car back to the hotel, the front desk was more concerned with whose fault they got the number wrong. We didn't care as long as the car got to the hotel ASAP. It took them another 30 minutes to do so. The charge was $49 per night for valet, so my husband wanted to see if they could waiver the last night's valet charge for their mistakes. It has been horrible trying to talk to anyone. No manger has called back. The customer service is non-existent.

Cons: The rooms can be very tiny, and the elevators are frustratingly slow. The front desk ladies can be a little gruff. In the morning, the cleaning staff sometimes chattered in very loud voices right next to the door.Pros: Fantastic location! The room is pleasant and the bathroom spacious; both have updated decor. David T. was very friendly and always extremely helpful -- a gem! The "quiet" room we asked for was *very* quiet -- only heard external noises once, other than the cleaning crew. Excellent business office setup.All in all, very satisfactory stay. Steps away from just about every major subway line, or else a couple of blocks from excellent neighborhoods such as Soho, Chinatown, Little Italy, and Chelsea. So very easy to get anywhere in the City. David T. was knowledgeable and very helpful and friendly. Plenty of computers in the business office, which is in a lively part of the lobby -- very nice to check email and Google Maps. First 5-6 pages print for free. Highly recommend it -- would stay there again, for business or vacation.

We arrived late on a Wednesday and were greeted nicely. The lower lobby was amusing with people chatting and surfing. We walked 5 blocks to Mott St where we had some "Wonton Noodle" dinner. The staff were very pleasant with us, and especially David (Concierge) on our last day helped us by locating a last minute cab to JFK. Allow at least 45 minutes to get there from the hotel. The subway station is just in the corner, as well as a post office and even a notary a couple of blocks out. Next door there is a mini deli that is open 24 hr so you are never short of any snacks or even meals. They have a salad and lunch/dinner bar by weight, so it's very pleasant to have choices.I did not give the hotel 5 stars because internet is not available in the rooms, as is in most hotels nowadays, unless for an extra charge. You already have restricted parking, and the internet is also restricted to the first floor lobby only. Other than that I'd recommend this location to anyone.

We chose this hotel for a 5 night stay in New York because of the good price we found on a booking site and because it was a Sheraton. The hotel location was good in the area of Tribeca. Very close to several subway stations so travelling around New York was easy. The area around the hotel was nice also with shops etc. The hotel is quite small, atleast compared to what we are used to in Europe. Reception area is small and felt crowded even if it was only 10 people there sometimes. Rooms were okey and clean, not so big but what can you expect in New York. Gym was also okey but quite small. Nice with free wifi in the lobby area. The staff was okey but could be better. The concierge team and the reception staff could be a bit more professional and could smile a bit more. They were not rude to us but they were not so nice either, they could be nicer and be smiling more.

Good hotel for both business and pleasure. The rooms are ok sized with a huge comfortable bed and a new fresh bathroom. Excellent location, right by Soho. A good selection of great restaurants close to the hotel.

Manager Lowell Beebe-Center is not just available, he's accessible. And apparently he's instilled the entire staff with a friendliness and service mentality that is downright gracious without being cloying. The sparkle of the fairly new hotel is maintained to a high level of cleanliness. Opt for a room with club level privileges - the lounge is one of the best we've seen.As for prices, very mid-line for Manhattan.And of course, location, location, location. Walk to literally hundreds of restaurants; easy trek to SoHo.We've tried bunches of Manhattan hotels - it is going to be hard to get us to try another one.
This independently owned Sheraton refused to refund us after we had to cancel our trip due to Hurricane Irene. Poor leadership and bad customer service describe my experience with this hotel.

Had a rough time trying to check in due to lack of valet attendants and parking area in front of hotel. We were initially in 2 double bed room on the top floor (22 nd). The room smelled like mold, due to the shower curtain. I got the head of housekeeping who was quite rude although I got her to admit the smell was overwhelming. We were moved to a different room with 1 king with a a pull out sofa which was a challenge for 4 people. Except for the housekeepIng supervisor the front desk staff was friendly. The location was decent within walking distance to Katz deli and several other attractions.

Stayed here for a girls getaway weekend and was greeted by David T. at the front door who was just so friendly and so helpful! He was there everytime we needed something and just willing to make sure we had everything! This hotel is in a great location with wonderful cafe's just around the corner! We will definately be back!

The best part of the Sheraton is the location to 3 different subway lines. You can get almost anywhere in midtown Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens from this hotel in 30 minutes. The hotel is new and updated and the rooms are very good sized for New York City. Our room's only drawback was the lack of a mini-fridge and the 'peek-a-boo' city views from our room on the 17th floor. The majority of our view was the back of the post office. There is great food and shopping only minutes away! Bagel deli next door is much better than hotel breakfast and is open all night!

really happy with this hotel...stayed in May 2011 for a week, 15th Floor with a view of mid and uptown - fantastic...canal st where the hotel is a bit "gritty" but gives you a real sense of NYC...the area around the hotel has amazing shopping in soho, similarly with bars adn restaurants..head south from the hotel to tribeca and again the restaurants are brilliant..well served by the subway a better location i think would be hard to find if you want to see some real New York and not jsut the bits the books tell you see!Room was fairly spacios, good facilties in the hotel including the all important starbucks stand...didnt pay the standard extortionate price circa$20 for breakfast as immediately next door there is a really cool joint thats open 24/7 that does just about every breakfast under the sunstaff in the hotel were really good, the gym was a decent size and i really couldnt find fault with it...Ive been in NYC before and paid a fortune to stay in "better" places but none compared to hereWould definitely go here again

We stayed here overnight for a tiny getaway. We were very happy with the hotel. The room and the view were beautiful. Everyone we talked to were so friendly and helpful –the staff is truly a pleasure! The club level was was great. It had a great view of the Empire State Building and offered great food and drinks. The primary location on Canal St. could have been a little nicer but it is very close to many desirable locations. We would definitley stay again!

Having read other reviews I was a little apprehensive upon arrival especially since we had booked our trip through an agency.... LOCATIONThe Sheraton's location is just ok - on Canal Street which is on the edge to Chinatown (we thought not so nice unfortunately!) but also quite close to the more "in" area of Tribeca and when you walk up Broadway you have nice, though expensive shops to look at and a very nice, clean and safe area when walking further uptown. We walked Broadway (uptown) as well as West Broadway (uptown) even at night and felt safe. However, we did not like walking in the other direction towards Chinatown, as we felt unsafe there - just our impression. But location was the only not so great thing about this hotel. ROOMSWhen we were checked in, we were given two rooms on the executive floor. The rooms were good in size, clean and not too loud - you did hear sirens and a car alarm every now and then but that happens everywhere in NYC!The Sheraton also has wonderful beds! Our rooms had a (for our standards) huge double bed with great clean sheets & more than enough fluffy pillows! This was great for us, since we had to stay in bed more than we had wanted to due to an illness. On our 3rd day I had to contact the front office re a doctor and was told by staff they have a doctor who makes house calls. They contacted him for us and he called us at our room later. He arrived in the early afternoon and was very nice and competent. STARWOOD PREFERRED GUEST LOUNGEWe stayed on the floor where the Starwood Preferred Guest lounge is located and where we got free breakfast, evening snacks and free soft drinks! It was just great! The lounge even has a wonderful terrace - too bad it was winter! There's also a computer in the lounge which you can use for free for a certain period of time each day (I think it was around an hour or less?), but there were also a couple of computers for free use in the lobby. Due to the time change we were up very early each day and always the first ones for breakfast so we got to talking to the lounge attendants a lot! They were all very kind and helpful if you needed any extras! STAFFWe thought the staff was great! From the minute we checked in, we got wonderful and very competent and friendly service, whether it was at the front office, the concierge, housekeeping personnel, the lounge attendants etc. They all went out of their way for us! All in all we would stay there again for sure!

The hotel is located between Chinatown and Tribeca/soho. Very close to blue, red and brown metro trains. The hotel itself is very new, clean and our two double bed room was quite spacious in NYC standard. Some reviewers said it didn't feel safe, but I would argue the opposite. It's sitting at the heart of the New York craziness, so you should expect people to try to sell you things. I will certainly stay again.

Had a GREAT weekend stay Feb 25-27, 2012. The staff could not be more helpful and pofessional. If you want a GREAT location and GREAT staff book this Hotel. Night time can be a bit intimIdating if you are not familiar with the area however I have been coming to this area for 20 years and have never felt unsafe, even when catching a subway train at 3:00 AM to JFK. This Hotel is value priced for New York city and the SOHO area.

Stayed 2 nights here recently. Bid $110 the rooms on Priceline so it was a good value. Great rooms, nice people working there. 100% satisfied with the place. The only thing they could do better is lower the cost of valet parking ($55). I found other parking in lots in the area and was able to print out discount coupons. Paid $29 for 24 hours. Location is at the bottom of SoHo, close to Chinatown and Little Italy.

Great Rooms! The hallways and interiors are a bit cramped; you will hear those in a room nearby if they are noisy. Canal Street is very crowded, if you want to avoid the crowds, west of the hotel is the way to venture. These small issues are mitigated by the rooms and prices, which are very good for a quality hotel in New York City.

Stayed there Feb 7-9, 2012. Very close to Chinatown. Very shady characters at night time. It was a very "GHETTO" enivornment at night. Rooms are decent size with great bedding. We used their limo service which was a nightmare. The driver was extremely rude and refused to drop us off at the VIP red carpet event. Hotel employees handled this matter worse with BS replies. I would not stay there again unless I have business in Chinatown and want to be close.

The hotel is on Canal street. The outside is not attractive at all. The rooms are small(many are in NYC). Service adequate. Either Sheraton's are going in down in class or this hotel should have been a Four Points. There are many cool boutique hotels in NYC for the same price. The roof top bar is nice.

This isn't a Courtyard or Four Points; act like a hotel, not a motel. No one was available to assist with luggage or parking when we arrived, which is clearly essential on busy Canal Street -- we had to go in and dig someone up ourselves. Then we were told on departure that it would be at least a half-hour to retrieve the car. From where -- Jersey? Further, the Coca-Cola branding of the entranceway, lobby, and restaurant is distasteful and ugly. This and service spoil an otherwise perfectly serviceable and attractive hotel in a very convenient location.

Stayed here for 4 nights during New York Fashion week. This hotel might not not be trendy but the location in walking distance from fashionable Soho is a great deal for a long weekend. The rooms are in standard size with nice and comfy beds, it is quite and you can have a great view on Manhattan from the higher floors. Staff is friendly, nice breakfast for a very low price, small Starbucks in the lobby as well.If you are looking for a good hotel in NY for a very affordable price, this is for sure a good pick.

My husband, 17 year old daughter and I stayed at this hotel for 6 nights in February 2012. We reserved a suite. The room was pretty spacious considering it is NY. There was a king size bed, fold out couch and a 4 seater table to dine at if you wanted. The room and bathroom were both very clean. The gym is pretty good- treadmills, cross trainers, free weights and a weights machine. There's a nice bar and a restaurant although we didn't eat in the restaurant. There is a great deli next door for bagels muffins, sandwiches, juice, wine & beer. There's also a Starbucks inside the hotel for your espresso fix if you need one. Overall the hotel was above average. The staff were consistently friendly and helpful. In fact, I can't say enough about the outstanding service. I definitely recommend this hotel.

Everything was ok, but I was expecting much more for a Sheraton. Beside that, the hotel is new and confortable, big bed, nice bathroom and a convenient Starbucks inside the hotel! PS: I really don't think Canal street is a good place for a classy hotel.

just wrapped up a great night at the Sheraton Tribeca. The staff is fantastic, and willing to assist with all sorts of requests. They even surprised us with a nice gift at check-in because I'd told them it was a special trip. Room was spacious & clean, had great views, and a really nice bathroom. We'll be back! Only complaint is that the valet only parking, at $65 for our SUV, was a bit steep... so don't drive here...

I was one week on business in New York, and since the headquarters of the company I work for is located at 5 minutes walking distance from the hotel, is of the hotels we usually use. Some comments:- good location as start point to see NY. I had to stay there because of my work, but if I would have been on vacations, I also see this hotel as very good option. - nice, helpful and friendly staff. Always open and available to support. - room: small, somehow NY standard, but not Sheraton standard. But clean and in my case, I was on a high floor (15th) with a great view to the Empire State building. The sky was very clear, blue, no clouds, therefore a great view in the night.- fully agree with one comment regarding the noise of the air stractor on the toillete. Amazing loud, that´s why I also decided to use the other light and illuminate the restroom.- breakfast only average.....no ham or cheese but fruits and juice. Nothing special, but ok.- two days during my stay, I had business meetings which ended very late, came back to the hotel close to 10:00PM and decided to order food to the room/room service, and my god !!!!! HORRIBLE FOOD !!!!!. The first time I ordered one chicken stake, which was overkoocked, and I felt eating a piece of leather. However, I decided to give restaurant of the hotel a second chance, and another day ordered a chicken sandwich. Another dissapointment. The chicken again, like leather.....in a baguette like gum.....,so bottom line, the hotel is very nice, well located, close to the subway lines which take you in 15 mins to the uptown, also close to soho and chinatown, with some interesting restaurants and shops nearby.......so no issues to stay a the hotel, but pls DON´T EAT THERE. Believe me. No matter if it´s late, go out and buy something decent.

The location is perfect for lower Manhattan adventures. Walk across the street to SoHo or venture a bit to Little Italy. Treck down Church to the WTC sites. Extremely clean and super-helpful staff. We went w/ kids. Next time, just me and the wife.

This hotel is one of the newest in NY, it is a Sheraton and it's in a good location, if you want to be by the Soho/Tribeca, if you want to go shopping in Soho is very convenient.
