Many subway options around and 5 minutes walking from the shopping area.The problem is that this hotel is not at the Sheraton "level" it should be (As someone already said) a Four Points. The rooms are way too small, we were given a "suite"(As I'm Platinum Strwood) and it was smaller than the "current" Sheraton rooms anywhere else in the country, really a joke... of course the bed is one of the best as always in Sheraton, but the rest of the room not. The bathroom was tiny and the extractor in it is too loud, so much that we prefer to be on the dark rather than hearing that noise (The extractor works when you turn the light on in the bathroom)The lounge is on the top floor, having really nice views of the Hudson River and midtown, really nice views, but the quality of the food ofered was very low. also the service in the lounge was bad. When we were there for the Hours d'ouvre the waiter ofered my wife a glass of wine, our surprise was when he came back later with the check for the glas of wine (9$) WHAT??? you charge for a glas of wine at the Lounge???All in all, not our best experience in a Sheraton. I would go back only if I HAVE to stay in that area of the city.

Sheraton Tribeca is a very well located hotel but people make the difference.For us, a 6 people family travelling for the first time to NYC, David T.´s friendship and pro-activiness made the difference.

Let me start by saying that this hotel is in a great location for visiting Little Italy, China Town, Tribeca, and Brooklyn. The area to the right of the hotel is a little seedy, but otherwise it is lively with plenty of sidewalk shopping.The hotel itself is clean and modern with standard Sheraton amenities.On the 21st floor there is a Club Lounge with an amazing outside terrace with an awesome view of the city. I believe Gold (not sure about Gold since the first time we stayed we were not offered free breakfast) and Platinum members can eat breakfast there for free. Food is good, coffee excellent.On our second visit to the hotel in January, we were promised, as now Platinum members, a Suite upgrade. Excited we went to check our room on the 5th floor and were immediately disappointed. The rooms was not much larger than their standard and the view was terrible. The small windows looked out at a brick wall. We then called the front desk, She told us there were no suites available, however we could have a room on the 17th floor with a better view. Of course we took it and it was a beauitiful view, directly across from the Empire State Bldg., but the room was standard, not an upgrade. Upon departure, we did not convey our displeasure due to the fact that they did change our room. However, when I returned home, I immediately contacted Sheraton. I received an apology from them as well as an email contact from the hotel itself with an apology and a promise to do better next time.I am not saying that I would not stay at this property again. It is convenient to visit the above-,mentioned areas for a short trip. We had reservations at Patricia's in Brooklyn which was a short taxi ride away. Patricia's is a great place for good fun and authentic homemade Italian fare. However, I would not choose it if just visiting NYC due to the lack of better treatment for Platinum members.

New hotel - wifi (and computers!) in lobby, as well as a Starbuck's, bar and restaurant. Great staff. Room was average, bed was comfortable. I was surprised that we couldn't hear the street noise (I'd just come from a 4 star hotel on a quieter street, and the room on the 31st floor had noticeable street noise). The biggest issue we had was this: though the room was soundproofed, the door to the hallway was not. It was practically a sound amplifier of hallway noises. Of course we got to hear a bunch of teenagers (hotel guests) fighting at 2:30am. We called the from desk, and could hear every word the security guard said. I'd most likely stay again, the location is great. But I'd be sure to bring my noise canceling headphones.

The rooms were nice enough, modern and clean. The bathroom was large and spacious and the beds were really comfortable.Upon checking in, the staff were very efficient and friendly. Were very informed with recommending places to eat and where to catch the subway and getting to places. the hotel has free 30min internet in the lobby which is handy.As was not a Platinum member, was not able to go to the Club Room and take advantage of the lounge bar and take a look at the view, but when I mentioned to the staff that I wanted to take pictures of the view, they called security to escort me to the club room to allow me to take in the views and take photos. It was an amazing view of the city skyline and it was really lovely of them to allow me to see it and go out of their way.The hotel is not far from the Brooklyn bridge and the ground zero location. It is located in Tribeca, however it is more Chinatown- Canal st than Tribeca. The hotel surroundings is a little dirty, old, run down and looks a little scary, but once you walk a few blocks out of the hotel and you are right in SOHO, Tribeca, little Italy and it is lovely. As the moment you walk out of the hotel, you have all the street people trying to sell you fake goods.The hotel lobby area is quite small and you are cramped in however concierge is very helpful and arrange the bags out of the way. As we had a lot of bags with us, they provided us with scales to weigh our bags to make sure we weren't charged by the airlines. Overall, this was quite an enjoyable hotel and i would recommend it to anyone.

I found a great deal on the internet to stay here for (supposedly) $98. Of course, that's actually about $125 after they add on all the various taxes. My room was small but clean and the bed was very very nice. Bathroom was tiny. I was able to walk to just about anything in Soho and there were plenty of really good restaurants nearby. However, the block the hotel is located in is pretty crummy, the lobby is boring, and the only place you can get wi-fi without paying extra is in the lobby, which I always find irritating. All in all, it's a fairly generic experience.

Nice newer property with friendly staff at check in. It is one of the newer styled Sheratons and it shows...nice rooms, great beds, Club Room with free breakfast, water, etc for Platinum Members. It is smack in the middle of Chinatown/Canal Street so it can appear to be in a shady area but then you realize you are blocks away from the more aesthetically pleasing to the eyes stores at SoHo. The A train headed downtown from Penn Station is only 3 stops away and puts you right next to the hotel so is $2.25 vs. $20 for a cab.

Gathering for a weekend family celebration, this hotel and it's staff could not have been more accommodating. Greeted at the curbside with a smile, we "country folk" were immediately put at ease. The valet took care of the car are our belongings followed us to our rooms. Quick and simple. Fantastic view of the city from our rooms (huge windows) and very nice amenities on-site. Quality, tasteful decor, upscale, contemporary, inviting facility. Only a one or two year old hotel, everything is in great condition. The staff seems to enjoy working there and with each other. (Quiet and most effective heating and ventilation in the room.) Reasonable walking distance to Ground Zero, South Street Seaport, Little Italy, Chinatown, and the Spring Street shopping district. Stress-free weekend in the city with no regrets and fond memories. We look forward to a repeat.
The hotel is beautiful, clean and new! Every staff member we spoke to was friendly and helpful. I would stay here again!

I spent 4 nights here on business Jan 2012 and although not disappointed in any way I didn't really feel anything really justifies giving it a better rating. For a start the hotel is perfectly clean and everything seems and feels new. What I felt the hotel really lacked was character. It seemed like some of the main details had been overlooked when designing it. I had what I thought booked a 'King Suite', but as the price was very reasonable I didn't really seek to question the oversize double room. Sure it had a small dining table and a pull out couch, but wasn't a suite, nor did it have any storage or hanging for clothes, so I literally spent the entire 4 days living out of my suitcase. Not exactly a major problem, but more of an oversight by the management. The hot water went out one morning. I called guest services and was advised that it was being repaired and would be back on in 20 minutes. sure enough it was on in 20 minutes and again more of an inconvenience than a disaster, but not what I'd expect from a Sheraton. The coffee shop was always empty which meant ordering was quick. The bar area seemed quite adequete for a quick drink and nothing more. The location is about 1-2 blocks from Chinatown which makes for an entertaining diversion and some excellent and cheap food. Overall, despite my review I would stay here again as the price I managed to get for the room was excellent.

This is truly a great location and a gem of a hotel. This hotel will meet all your expectations. The service is fine. The rooms are fine. There are minor glitches like running out of umbrellas. Hey!I It's NYC, You can always pick up one on the street for a few bucks. I don't know what the bad review people were expecting, but this is a superior NYC hotel.

My husband and I stayed here for 7 nights mid January. We were initially given a room for the physically disabled, however quickly moved to a different room once we mentioned we were physically able and would like a full height shower. We were told the initial room was the one assigned to us as we had booked through Hotwire.Our new room was fabulous - room 1220 - had an Empire State view. It was facing Canal Street - we never had an issue with street noise.The room was a good size. Kept nicely cleaned throughout our stay. The TV has limited channels. The bed was comfy, the air conditioning good and quiet.Canal Street is very busy - this was not an issue for us. The hotel is in a great location within walking distance to a lot New York has to offer. Ther are also 3 subway stations very close by that enables you to get to the rest of the city easily.We did not eat in the restaurant. It was the only one in our 2 week stay in New York that we saw with a C grade rating (the lowest possible). With all New York has to offer we refused to eat anywhere that had a grade lower than A.The staff were helpful. Beware of the concierge/porter guys that arrange town cars. We sat waiting for our ride to the airport for quite some time and observed many guests come to enquire about transport options in the freshly-fallen few inches of snow. We observed the guys high-fiving each other as someone agreed to a high rate. Either know your rates or haggle if using the town cars - or get a taxi.

i cannot remember the last time i paid this price for a hotel room in NYC area. Maybe right after 9/11 with a 50% off from priceline? so I was a bit skeptical about this hotel but it turned out to be a pleasant surprise. It is not exactly in a touristy location but A,C,E and 4,5,6 metro stations are within 5min walking distance, so just a hop away. The lobby, elevator, and hallways are clean and well maintained. As a Platinum SPG I was upgraded to a balcony room on the 2nd floor. The room was rather small, just enough for a king bed and a work station along the wall, but this is NYC after all. It was at least very clean - comfortable bed and decent sized shower. The private balcony, though almost as big as the room itself, only provided view of another building but could be a nice spot for a glass of wine at night. I believe only 2nd floor has some rooms with private balcony. The SPG lounge on the 21st floor has a nice view of the hudson river. Morning breakfast at the lounge was a bit ho-hum but I did not expect more for a Sheraton in the US. Overall it was a bit better than average and at $109/night a very good deal! The only major complain I have is the sound proof quality of the room, or at least in my room. I could hear everything coming from the next door. Unfortunately the guests went to bed early, otherwise I would have to call the front desk to complain.

As far as NYC hotels go, this one is at the top of my list. I've stayed at many NYC hotels where the rooms are cramped, the hotels are old and in many cases outdated and you pay through the roof. HOWEVER, this Sheraton is unlike all the other NYC hotels I've stayed at. The reason...it's brand new! This Sheraton was built from the ground up just a couple of years ago, so everything is still new and fresh. The Rooms: The suites are very spacious and the regular rooms while a little cramped (like most NYC hotels) they are very clean, crisp and modern. The Staff: The front desk staff is excellent. Very helpful and knowledgeable. However, the concierge gentleman that I dealt with was not very helpful. He seemed like he couldn't be bothered. The Location: Not ideal if you have business in mid-town, but, it is very close to the subway (multiple lines) that can get you to mid-town fairly quickly. I love this location b/c I love Tribeca. There are some great restaurants in this location and boutique shopping. Tribeca for me at least, is also more manageable and easy. Overall, good property, great value and my go-to hotel in NYC.

Can't beat Tribeca location. This is absolutely dead average. The room quality is a little inconsistent but by and large you won't' make a huge mistake staying here, unless you are paying over $300/night. In that case you can definitely do better elsewhere. It's basically clean, the bed is comfortable. The food in the club room is Jenos party tray style so if you like that you're fine. Room service food also tastes frozen, so if you are a foodie, there are better hotels in the same price range. There are some very good folks on the Bell staff and a few good people at the front desk and that's what lifts this poor to average.

Booked a room here 2 Fridays ago because I did not want to take the subway home late at night.Room was very small, but very fresh and clean. Nice bathroom amenities. My partner and I used the room strictly to get some rest. We did not use any of the hotel amenities.In my opinion, this is a 3 to 3.5 star hotel, not a 4 star.

I stayed at the Sheraton Triceca on Friday January 20th (my birthday). I have stayed at this hotel five or six times before. I had previously reviewed it and was not going to again, until I read a review by Vivaladiva 1. First about my stay, it was even better than before. I am a Hilton Diamond member and I could have used points and stayed at a Hilton, but I have stayed at most of them in the city and I chose the Sheraton Tribeca over all of them. I did not want the hustle bustle of midtown and this hotel is a short cab ride or easy subway ride from midtown. I brought my wife and dog on the trip. My wife was so impressed with how well she slept that she asked me to find out what type of mattress they used. They set up a dog bed and dog dishes which was a nice touch. My wife had mentioned that it was my birthday and the staff all signed a card and sent up some drinks and snacks for us. I love the location as it still has the energy of the city without most of the congestion (except at rush hour). There is a parking garage right across the street (on a side street) which is convenient. We ate at a great Italian restaurand a few blocks away and went to the Blue Note Jazz club that evening. A perfect weekend with great service and a great room in a wonderful location.I was shocked to see the review by Vivaladiva 1. Sure, I had to wait five minutes to check in (seemed like 20), I would expect that in a popular hotel with good rates (as she mentioned). To have had a bad experience is possible, but three bad experiences at this hotel is highly unlikely. To give this hotel one star (actually a circle) just blew me away. I would guess that "La Diva" never gives more than three circles for any experience. Unfortunately she went over her credit limit on here charge card because other hotels had put holds on her card (come on now, I stay in hotels 70 nights a year and this has never happened to me). She gives them a credit card which is no good and she blames the hotel for not accepting it. She offers to give them cash. If you owned a hotel would you want this person staying there? I think Trip Advisor should remove reviews like this that are obviously someone's way of venting for a bad experience that they caused themselves. I never wrote something bad about a previous review before, but boy it feels good to defend a place that has made me feel so welcomed when I have been away from home. I hope you will not head her review but rather read the other reviews from people like myself who have nothing but positive comments for this special place.

I booked the Deluxe King Room with Club Access for 5 nights. It was on the 20th floor, with an ok view to the skyline and a glimpse of the Hudson river. The room was not big for a Deluxe king, but there was a bergère, a working desk, a tiny closet and a reasonable size bathroom with a glassed doors shower (which for me is a plus, 'cause I hate those tub/shower curtain bathrooms that are only good to colect mold). The up side of every Sheraton Hotel is the bed, 'cause it really makes you feel like you're sleeping in the clouds. Breakfast was no biggy, but it was not much different from the buffet breakfast the hotel offers downstairs as well. Club Lounge didn't offer much too, but it's good to have an option after all.

Our family of 6, teenage and young adult children, stayed at the hotel for 5 nights over the xmas break. I would happily recommend this hotel. The location is fantastic. Close to the subway and the "real" New York. We were on the club floor and had fantastic views and a complimentory breakfast every morning. Our rooms were on the upper levels and had great city views. The rooms were clean and the beds really comfortable.The concierge was very helpful and the ground floor bar was a great place to people watch and had a great vibe. The only drawback I can think of was the lifts, really really slow. Whilst I would probably not stay here I it were my husband and I, opting fro something a little more upmarket, for the six of us it was great value for money. Everything you needed and all the things you dont really need. For example the fit out is quite tired and I mentioned the lift.

I have tried my best not to write a bad review on this hotel......but I have to be honest. If you look at my other reviews, I have NEVER given a hotel only 1 star! I have stayed at this hotel 2 times and tried to stay a third time about a month ago because of the price. My first time I stayed at this hotel it was the first week they opened. My room was clean (I was probably the first person to ever stay in it. Check in took over 20 minutes! The bathrooms are cute and my room was a nice size and I had a decent view. The staff was nice, but there were a lot of different little issues. I chalked it up to it being the first week and that the hotel would get better with time. The Platinum lounge is one of the nicest with a rooftop deck and great view. I liked the location because I work downtown often and at that time I was working in Brooklyn a lot which the train to BK was a block away. The second time I stayed was for about 2 months later with friends. They upgraded me to a "suite", which isn't a suite. Its a room with a couch and dining table. The room is still small just more furniture. Our check in was again over 20 minutes. The staff seemed confused, but friendly. The weekend was a mess. With keys that weren't working all weekend, construction going on that woke us up at 8am and was making our bed vibrating our bed. We were told there was construction still going on, but I love how that information wasn't told to us before we checked in. I feel like if there is noise going on that loud, maybe you should tell us so we can make a descion of not checking in. After cursing out the manager, he gave me points for the headache, but I swore I would never be returning again. Checking out took us almost 30 minutes. We almost missed our train to go home because of their "computer" delay. Around the holidays I had a friend from out of the country in town. I booked this hotel again because the rooms were only $99 per night and were in the area we needed to be in. A year had passed and I was hoping the hotel had got their $h*t together. Well, I was wrong. I am a SPG Platinum member and have been for years, but this hotel doesn't care. My card didn't go through because there was other hotel holds still on it from stays I had from earlier in the week. I told them I would pay cash (which I and my friend had a lot of) and I would leave cash or card deposit. Well, well, well they told me they can't do that. Excuse me? I have cash to give you as a deposit for incidentals. Remind you that I have over 50 stays a year, the rooms have mini bars and the front desk has the power to lock my movie rentals and phone. Still a no go. The manager said we have people who trash the room a lot. Really? I don't walk around thinking I deserve special treatment, but the entire point of being a elite member to something is for the "special treatment". I show my loyalty to a brand then I want the same loyalty back. Especially when your standing there with your bags during the holidays and just want to get into your room to relax and enjoy the little time your in town. My friend swiped his European card which it was denied as well and he didn't know why. I asked the hotel if it was their computer and they said no. Well, after an hour of what I like to call a big ol mess we ended up at the Le Meridan (which was only $60 more) and the manager said "because I'm a platinum member and stayed here before" he would take a cash deposit. My friend said could you try my card first, and they did.......which of course it went right through!!!! So there was no need for the cash deposit, but its nice to know that we could of used if we needed to. My friend loved the hotel so much that he booked the hotel for his conference in the spring time.This hotel isn't worth the headache. I never thought I would give a hotel one star especially a SPG hotel. I'm done completely.

This hotel is on Canal St.So if you pick this Sheraton try to avoid walking east.Especially if you have kids and hang on to your purse!.If you choose this hotel be forewarned.I am an ex New Yorker and it's harassment from the bag sellers of bad fakes that is upsetting on Canal st.There are better hotels for more money across the street and slightly west.I think it would have been worth the extra dollars.The two positives of this location 1)a 15/20 minute walk southwest to 911 Memorial 2)Very close (north) to Soho and great shopping and eats.I am an SPG member and I was surprised at how they could care less.This is New York so I expected a smalI room(it was teensy)I asked for a luggage rack because I did not want to put my luggage on the bed.The closet was tiny and so dark! After two requests,I gave up.I never heard anything back not even a sorry we have no more.Nada.So I moved a shelf from under the desk to set my luggage on that.The bathroom you have to turn on a light because it's pitch black.Well with the light comes this horrible fan noise.There is another light that is not connected to the fan and it is in the shower.This light however does not give you enough light to put makeup on.So here I go moving furniture and now a lamp from the dark room into the dark bathroom so I can get ready in the morning.Sounds relaxing doesn't it? You can hear the people next to you so if you watch T.V. at night the sound has to be practically mute.Also the T.V. is fixed to the wall and it will not move at all so you cannot turn it in your direction.The thing that really was the most irritating is that you have an elevator key that you have to have each time you get in if you want your floor and if you forget your key well it's back down to the lobby to get a new one.When you check in they ask if you want your family members name on the record ,so,if your family member forgets the key your family member gets another.Well, so much for that. My family member was grilled when they went to get another key and they left the phone in the room and could not call me when I was in the club lounge to explain to me what happened. If there are alot of people in the elevator,each person has to pull out there key for there floor and it was hair-raising to try to get all the keys in and your button pressed before it passed your floor!This shows me that this is a sketchy neighborhood or they would not have this crazy key system.The Club Lounge is quite nice but this is extra $$.They have no heat lamps or anything cheery(even a fake flower would have been an improvement) out on the terrace.If you go outside on the terrace Club Lounge and take in the only reason to really stay here (the view of the Empire State building)You have to stand literally because the way they designed it if you sit down you stare at the wall.Not relaxing.At least there is a good pizza place around the corner Saluggi(sp?) I think.I suppose if you are on a higher floor and have a view of the Empire State Building and they did not make you pay for wi-fi per day, I might have enjoyed my two nights here.At least you could open your drapes and see your clothes to get dressed without having anyone look at you in your birthday suit from the building next door.On a positive note,great bedding one more negative beds are like xtra large twins.they do not seem to be even full/dble beds.The housecleaning lady left me a welcoming note in hopes of a gratuity I guess? When I went to check out I found that there was a charge of 2 five dollar waters.I think housecleaning must be responsible for telling the front desk this?I would have gladly given her the price of water before I would have drunk a bottle of water that was 5 bucks!The water was sitting there the whole time with the 5 dollar price on it.Then I had to spend time on reversing the charges.This was the nail in the coffin to a disappointing stay

Great Location away from the typical Midtown crowds and tourist traps. Conveniently located on the border between SoHo and Tribeca, the Sheraton gives you an excellent base from which to explore the real Manhattan that the tourists in midtown will never see. Steps from the subway and surrounded by great neighborhood restaurants we really enjoyed our stay at this hotel. Staff is helpful and friendly. Rooms are nice and bright. If you can - check out the deck on the 21st floor. It has one of the best views of Manhattan outside of Midtown.

Only the service at the hotel met our expectations. It was expensive considered what you could get for the money in the area, bad value for money, noisy, and the basic standard and cleanliness of the room was not 4* quality. Stay somewhere else!

We’ve stayed at several different Sheraton during this trip, yet Tribeca Sheraton is the BEST. Let’s start with the location; their location is a bit awkward. On Canal St. which has bad traffic most of time. Taxi drivers are avoiding coming to this area. However, it’s conveniently located close to China Town, SOHO, and Little Italy within walking distance. 2 blocks from subway station.  The service is outstanding. You can feel the staffs are well trained at the second when you walk in. We were greeting immediately from bell desk, front desk and room service staffs. Although the room is a bit small, but it has everything you’ll need including safety box in the closet. The surprise chocolate on our bed and a hand write note to wish us happy New Year totally melt our hearts. Hubby said he will definite stay here again if we are visiting New York. P.S. Provide complimentary 40mins WiFi at lobby.

Canal St is a strange anachronism. Squabbling street vendors haggle over fake handbags and watches while the real thing is being sold only feet away in the uber-chic boutiques that characterize current day Tribeca. But this is the fun thing about Manhattan - all the contrasts that make the city full of such surprises. And right in the middle of all this sits the Sheraton Tribeca which was a very pleasant surprise. It's definitely a struggle to find a NY hotel with a rate that's even close to sensible, so cost often trumps quality. I took a deep breath and crossed my fingers when I found a great rate at this hotel. And what I found was a wonderful surprise. The hotel is completely up to date, and while the rooms are small (but which rooms aren't small in NY?) they have the usual features that one expects. My room even had the added bonus of a wonderful view looking north towards midtown with the Empire State and other landmark buildings brilliantly lit up at night.OK, so walking out onto Canal St can jolt anyone out of even the worst jet lag but all the fun streets like Mercer and Green St's in Tribeca and local cafe's, restaurants, wine bars, boutiques and people watching more than compensate for being hustled to buy some cheesy T Shirt on Canal St.Definitely worth checking out.

We booked this hotel thru priceline with the biddng process. We got a good deal but didn't expect much after looking at the pics on tripadvisor. The checkin process was smooth and we got a room on the 2nd floor with a terrace. This is MLK weekend with temp in the teens so we did't use the terrace but it made the room seem bigger. The large sliding doors made the room seem bigger with the extension to the patio. The room was a decent size with 2 doublebeds. The room looked much better than the pics. We were all pleasantly surprised. Bathroom seemed new and modern. It's a good location if you like Chinatown/Little Italy. I can't imagin staying here for a week as a first time nyc tourist. Canal and West Broadway is not exactly a tourist hotspot and it's rather dark and deserted at night. We live in NJ so just stayed one night after dinner with friends. The location is okay if you are familiar with nyc and here for a short stay. The location is a few blocks from the Holland Tunnel.

I just had a great stay at the Sheraton Tribeca. Loved the location on Canal St bt West Broadway and Wooster. Room was clean with big windows and light color interior. Seemed much more minimal in design compared to other Sheratons. Nice big shower. Club Lounge was open on the weekend and breakfast was served until 11am which is nice on a weekend. While I liked the location one must realize it is on the Tribeca/Soho line... I found it very close to Soho, Tribeca, West Village, NoLita and Chinatown.Valet Parking is $55...

I loved the location!!! I liked being in walking distance to soho and the west village! Also the E train station is right across the street that will take you to JFK! I thought the room was very nice!! It was small but that is what you get in NYC! I liked that there was a loofah in the shower with shower gel!! Nice treat! I will defiantly go back!!

Stayed here for 4 days to celebrate New Year and this hotel is a gem in Tribeca. Thanks to the efficient Mr. Tom Keane for his gracious accommodation given to our family. Also to Zakia David, and Javit (?) sorry if the spelling was wrong. We're glad we booked here instead of the crazy Times Square Hotels. The hotel has all the amenities we need, superb staff service from doormen to the front desk to the lounge staff. People here are friendly and so helpful. Soho has countless shops on sale and the Greenwich Village has good collection of reasonably priced CDs. Other famous landmarks are accessible. The view from the lounge balcony is fantastic!

Had no idea how fabulous this location is! Everything is in walking distant, even on a cold winter day! Tons of great restaurants and bars nearby. Was here for a wedding and the hotel staff was extremely accommodating and the price was great for the TriBeCa area. Great for all people!!

Used it as a crash pad after a night out with my best friend. Good quality, room was on the small side, but I paid a very competitive price, it was like new, very clean, very easy check-in and check-out, so I was pleasantly surprised.

Positives: Clean hotel and no bed bugs! This hotel has a great location and helpful reception staff. We got a good deal on booking.com. Rooms were pretty spacious compared to other hotels in Manhattan. Negatives: hidden charges were a nasty surprise at check out, and the cleaning staff were rather aggressive asking for tips. Parking is a ripoff - we did it one night and then managed to find free parking in Manhattan! Maybe we were just lucky, but parking was definitely not as hard to figure out as in other major cities.

This is a very nice hotel with reasonable rates (for New York) and within walking distance (about one mile) to Wall St. and 9/11 Memorial. The hotel is new, so the rooms are relatively large, clean and modern. Platinum members get access to the club lounge which has a good breakfast and fair hors dourves. The location is nice too - with lots of souvenir shops/vendors. I would definitely stay here again.

I had a family crisis and needed to cancel our Christmastime trip the evening before it was to start. I called Sheraton central, was told it was less than 24 hours before arrival so they couldn't give a refund, but in the morning I should call the hotel directly. So I did -- NO HELP WHATSOEVER. No, they couldn't refund me anything at all. No, they couldn't apply it to a future stay instead. I spent my $300 and lost it.I know I was looking for an exception to a rule I'd agreed to up-front... but not even credit towards a future stay? If their argument is that they couldn't give the room to someone else that night, it's true, but that only means they lost their profit -- they didn't have to provide any service, make any beds, leave any shampoo bottles. I wasn't even refunded the high NYC taxes on the stay we didn't have.It seems telling that the person who "handled" my situation (i.e. blew it off) was the "Director of Revenue", not somebody focusing on customer satisfaction. Call me 0% satisfied. When we finally take that postponed NYC trip in a couple more weeks, why on earth would I choose the Sheraton? The chain has lost my business forever over one day's inflexibility.

I stayed on a Friday night here with my boyfriend for a quick getaway. The hotel is what you expect from a Sheraton which is clean with a friendly staff. The beds are extremely comfortable. I paid a little more for a city view but it wasn't worth it. Parking is $55.00, so I opted to park on the street for free. If you are staying on the weekend you can pretty much park after 6:00pm or 7:00 pm for free. Our keys didn't work for our room when we got in at 2:00 am. It took awhile for someone from the front desk to get up to our room to let us in.  I liked that there was 45 minutes of free internet acces since most hotels charge for this. The location of the hotel is the very tip of Tribeca and therefore, very close to SoHo. It is a good location for someoen looking to walk and exlpore the city. Overall descent stay.I like that you are given 45 minutes of free internet access.

Sheraton Tribeca was referred to us by a former New York resident. It was exactly as described. Peaceful hotel on Canal Street without all the hustle and bustle of Times Square etc. Multiple subway stops convenient and accessible. The hotel is very friendly, very professional. The rooms are smaller but this is NYC. An excellent buy in our opinion. We will stay here again for sure! 24 hour bagel/deli shop next door had some of best sandwhiches in town! Bed was comfortable, be sure to spend the extra $$$ for the skyline view as it's beautiful to look out any time of day!

First time Sheraton NY. we have stayed at other sheratons and got decent value for money esp on booking.com etc. in NY value for money over holiday period is impossible, this sheraton has daily rates and lots of city/room taxes, NYeve day rate was 899 dollars, day after 250.. be warned they will hit with every tax going. in fact we paid 700 dollars in New York city taxes. wow. money aside this is great hotel, yeah the rooms are hotel rooms big double bed, shower, tea-coffee, freenewspaper, ice vending, roomservice, cleaners daily, higher up you stay, great views and if you are savvy get club lounge access on your deal. this entitles you to go to the 21st floor open terrace(of course indoor part too) for breakfast(not bad at all bar the sausages) and evening drinks with views of the new yor skyline inc empire state building that you will pay 30dollars for at top of the rock etc. in fact you can access this space at all times. it is also fully staffed. the staff here at the tribeca were aweseome, great team effort , friendly, go the extra yard for you, good advice, good conversation if your sports fan, basically they make this hotel what it is. yes they want tipping but not all do and for those that dont know, they are taxed on all there tips even cash ones. wifi in room you have to pay for 10dollars for 24hrs or in the lobby free, plenty of computers to use and a starbucks in reception. great bar, tasty drinks, please ensure you ask for your bill prior to departure and ask for copies all receipts you sign. there are those in NY who will add to your bill if do not put a line through sections of receipts. (good tip that)do not get the hotel taxi to airport, flag down a yellow cab, it is cheaper regardless of what hotel says. getting around NY is easy, get a metro card, get a map and walk it and cycle Centra park on the weekend. Central park has a busy main roads runs right through it except wkends.overall, we would stay here again but fingers crossed it will be kinder to our bank balances.

Our room had a very comfortable bed. But the room was too small for comfort. Why to they insist on sticking large, bulky armchairs into a room the size of a closet? There are sleaker solutions available.Our room had no safe! But a room safe was actually installed in our closet on our second day, after we pointed out the fault!It was difficult to get a good heat setting for the room. This may have been because of the cold outside but it was still a problem. The largest towels in the room were NOT bath towels.Yet another a dinosaur hotel charging for internet access. Should be FREE in 2012 (or at least for Starwood members). Free internet only available in the lobby but the access speed was terrible.Some "borrowed" our morning paper from outside the door - which we pointed out with no apologies from the management.

I stayed 3 nights in a small room at the back of the hotel facing Lispenard Street -- very quiet, cozy, comfortable room with the typical high quality bed, sheets, amenities, etc. of a new Sheraton. The really wonderful, and unexpected, part of this hotel is the incredible views of midtown to the north and over to the Hudson to the west. The lounge on the club floor is terrific, excellent breakfast offerings, with a large outdoor terrace that allows unobstructed panoramic views of the city. Front desk and club lounge staff are friendly and cheerful.The location on Canal Street is not your typical tourist location, but it is great for exploring Soho (just cross Canal St and head north on West Broadway and go two blocks -- you're in the Soho shopping area) and Tribeca (again just turn south on West Broadway from the hotel and you're there) on foot. Lots of great bistros and little bars within 4-5 blocks. You can also get anywhere from here fast. Don't bother with a cab -- you're within two blocks of the subway stops for the A,C,E (turn left out the front door, then left on West Broadway), the 1,2 (turn left out the front door, cross Canal and walk west two blocks), and the N,R (turn right out the front door and walk east two blocks on Canal). Canal Street is not especially glamorous, but even with all the street vendors it is still less crowded and easier to walk through than Times Square. If it bothers you, turn off and walk along the side streets -- you'll see even more of the city!

So I booked 2 nights at the Sheraton Tribeca with my daughter, an NYU student. I booked through hotels.com for a refundable rate in January-not a busy month, right? I cancelled the reservation 8 days before arrival, plenty of time! But the Sheraton has a 'small print' cancellation policy of charging one night for cancellations, no matter how far ahead. Then I looked at the reservation and they were charging $239 for the first night and $175 for the second night. That way, in the event of cancellation, they could keep the higher rate. Clever. In any case, I called Five Star services at hotels.com and they called the Sheraton. Sheraton held fast-no refunds, sorry. So Five Star actually credited me the difference for a nearly full refund because I stay in hotels 5 nights each month and am a good customer. I WILL NEVER BOOK A ROOM AT A SHERATON. BAD CUSTOMER SERVICE. By the way, I cancelled due to medical reasons...!

Stayed here midweek, 2 days before New Year's Eve in NYC - when all other hotels were at least $100 more per night. The room was not large but totally perfect for our needs and it was clean and modern. The bathroom was great too, in fact, I now want to get one of those maginfying mirrors they have. The location is convenient to several subway lines and about a 20 minute walk to West Village or to dowtown/Financial District. And of course, if you want to experience an authentic Chinese, Vietnamese, Malasyian, or Thai meal, this is a great location.

My girlfriend and I stayed at the Tribeca Sheraton in early december. The hotel was in a great location, just blocks from amazing shopping in SoHo, and very close to a subway stop. The staff was very friendly and helpful. There were two that we had the most contact with, David and Michael, and they were both wonderful. The room we had was small but not too small. The bathroom was very nice and the bed was extremely comfortable. This was our first trip to New York City, and we will definitely stay at this hotel in the future.The only thing I did not like was the (about) $10/day for internet. But, we were rarely in our room so it wasn't a huge deal.

Attracted to the hotel due to the reviews, location, price and name Sheraton. However this did not live up to Sheraton expectations. When I checked in the room I requested was not available so I was moved to a room for the physically challenged which had no bath. Whilst it is claimed this is right in trendy Tribeca, it is not in the nice part of Tribeca, the hotel is right on canal street and right in the middle of the area where people hustling and harrassing you trying to sell you fake louis vuittons from garbage bags. Also full of tacky souvenier and electronic shops, whilst I felt safe I would not stay here with children. The concierge was helpful however now on reflection and after reading some reviews post event, I think the concierge actually over charges, eg my ticket to warhorse $139 + the same again as a 'brokers fee'. If you are travelling at a quiet time of day take the subway or a normal NYC cab to the airport the hotel cab is a rip off at + $100. Internet charge was $9.95 per day, yet when I checked out I had been charged multiple times multiple days. No mini bar and room service till only 11pm, I expected more from a sheraton. On the plus side, on site starbucks and possibly the most comfortable bed I have slept in. World Trade Centre is only a 20 minute walk, Times Square, Central Park in good traffic 15 mins in a cab.

Spent a long weekend with my mom and daughter (10) in this city hotel. Was all I would expect from a sheraton. Clean bathrooms, comfortable beds, and a good sized room. In this hotel you get a good value for your money. NYC hotel rooms tend to be very small, unless you spend a fortune. Breakfast as ok, nothing fancy. Staff was friendly and helpful. There is a subway close by, so it was a good hotel to explore the city.

We always stay in Midtown, but tried Tribeca this trip and loved it! The hotel is no frills, but has all that you need. Our room was fine. If you are a Starwood member, they have a great deck attached to the club room that they don't use, but you can go out and look at the great view. The lobby bar works, and there are so many great restaurants in the neighborhood! Parking is really expensive, but that is the price you pay to drive in Manhattan. There is a subway stop around the corner, too, and from here you can walk to everything from China town, Bloomingdale's, Ground Zero, the High Park, and Tribeca. And, our dogs were welcomed there!

We booked 9 days in December 2011 over Christmas and were pleasantly surprised at the quality of the hotel. A block away from Soho meant we had the best stores and restaurants in Manhattan within walking distance. Hotel is very warm, inviting and a welcome respite from a cold New York winters day.

Lured by the name Sheraton, positioned on Manhattan and availability on short notice, we took the chance to book for 4 nights. We noticed the following drawbacks: no shuttle service to JFK, very simple breakfast with mostly only sweet things (unfortunately very few breakfast places around the hotel), very small rooms, in the morning way too loud music in the lobby (for what reason? To appear youthful?). Positive: close to subway, extremely good beds and pillows, very friendly and helpful concierge. Frankly I thought it to be below general Sheraton standards also given the fairly high price at the time (250 Euro per night per room).

Stayed one night, they did a great job of designing the hotel on a narrow lot right on Canal Street. Rooms while small (this is NY), are so well layer out they feel larger. I had a king bed and there was lots of space. Full size bath with shower added to feeling roomier. Staff was friendly and helpful. My only complaint is that they have three small elevators to accommodate 22 floors, I can not remember the last time I continually had to wait for an elevator. Clean room, comfortable space, convenient location and reasonable price make this a winner. I did only give it three stars as for all the positives, it is just a basic hotel. I am surprised it is a Sheraton and not a Four Points.

This was a nice hotel. I was a little nervous by the surroundings when I pulled up in the cab, but the inside was nice and seemed newly refinished. Check in and out was very easy, and the bed was very comfortable. I didn't try the bar or restaurant but the deli next door makes a great sandwich. Easy walk to shopping and multiple subway stops.Only issue was the half used shampoo left in the shower, yuck, and the fan was very loud and always on when the bathroom lights were on. Besides that it was very clean and perfect for a short business trip.

This particular Sheraton, by New York standards, is very basic. It has everything you would expect from a Sheraton - clean, comfortable and good service, but it lacks some of the nice touches of other Sheraton's I have stayed at. I was there for business and for this purpose it was great. Good fast internet connection and a spacious desk and comfortable bed. Breakfast was a bit of a disappointment with a limited buffet selection but it was more than adequate.If you want to stay in the heart of New York and reliable comfort then this is a great choice. Canal Street can be bit dodgy at times but you're never far away from the action.

Im from south carolina and I stayed here for 4 days recently, and it is not in the best location in the city, its a bit far from times square and other attractions, but the hotel was nice, the front desk was helpful and tony, the concierge had great restaurant suggestions and tours for me and my wife.

We needed a place for an overnight close to/in Tribeca. Needless to say, rates at hotels this time of year (if rooms are available!) are quite high, so I was a little nervous to book the Tribeca Sheraton at the special rate of $119. We were so pleasantly surprised with the quality of the hotel and especially of the friendliness of the staff here. The room was nicely decorated & very clean. We were lucky enough to have an uptiown view of the Empire State Building, which was really pretty. Our room was on the 12th floor, so we were above the noise of Canal Street. The only negative about the hotel is the room size was small, but the bed was comfortable and the bath was well appointed and had nice toieltries. (We weren't going to be spending a great deal of time in the room, so it was not a concern for us.) I would definitely return, even if I didn't need to be in the area, as the subway is a block away which can get you almost everywhere else in town.

I needed a one night place to crash on the night of my company Christmas party. I chose this hotel primarily because of the proximity to the party, with the primary criteria being a clean bed and an inexpensive rate. I didn't expect much more of the Sheraton, especially given that I found a really low rate for a weekend night in NYC.I was quite pleasantly surprised with what we found. For starters, the lobby looks like it was redone recently - very clean and kind of funky interior. Check in was super fast and friendly. There is a business center in the middle of the lobby with internet access and newspapers. Off to the side is a bar, and to the back is a Starbucks. The room is about the size I would expect (ie: small), but it was really well designed and this too looked like it was renovated not long ago. Bathroom has a huge shower. Bed was very comfy with 4 giant pillows. The in-room safe is probably large enough for a laptop, which is unusual.Besides my location preference, this is right on the edge of Chinatown, Little Italy and Tribeca. There is parking around the corner, but like most NYC parking it's expensive (about $50 a day).I'd return to this hotel again, whether for business or pleasure.

On the plus side, the hotel is almost brand new and in a great location right between Soho and Tribeca. On the other hand, the 'deluxe' room was very small, with no storage / wardrobe to speak of, no mini bar, expensive wifi, the smallest bathroom with strange folding doors and an extremely noisy ventilator (we're talking hurricane strength), in top of the imcredible noise from the street (despite the higher floor). Staff efficiency and friendliness was mixed, the room wasn't made one day until we enquired. I know New York isn't famous for its warm hospitality but given you always seem to spend a small fortune in hotels (once the 6 different sales, room and local taxes have been added), this left room for improvement.

Lovely new hotel, staff really friendly, welcoming and helpful. Room with lovely big comfortable bed and in room safe etc (no fridge). Had the best stay i have ever had in NY, Tribeca is a great area with brilliant restaurants, cafes, bars and away from the oppressive crowds of Times Square etc - great to see but not to stay in (having done this before!). 15 mins walk to ground zero. 20 mins walk to Union Square. JUST BRILLIANT!!
Nice and dimly lit hotel with open air plan. Rooms are comfortable enough.
Had a great stay, impressed with the service. Lost bag from the flight, great help from Milev and David in retrieving the bags, thank you.

Stayed here for work at 250/nt. I was pleasantly surprised to find a hopping lobby full of fashionable people, a nice bar, nicer brightly lit space with what looked like a nice restaurant attached, the front desk person was friendly, the room had everything needed for an overnight stay. A one cup coffeemaker, a blow dryer, flat screen TV and plenty of easily accessible plugs for electronics. Good desk space, comfy clean bed with good pillows, climate control that's easy to use, panoramic view from floor 19, iPod radio. The bathroom products were not high end but for the price that's ok. Would stay here again. Why pay more?
great location, very clean room, large and comfortable bed. Thanks to the manager Lowell, we really enjoyed our 5 nights stay.

My husband and I just celebrated our 25th wedding anniversary. We normally stay at very high class hotels but that night we wanted to try something new without spending a fortune. (St. Regis, Ritz, etc are our norms) We wanted the Tribeca area so we pulled up to the hotel (unassuming front) The Bell guys were so nice and took care of our bags right away. While checking in we had at least 3 people come up to us and say Happy Anniversary. Being Starwood platinum, we had it all set up to hopefully get an upgrade. We gave 12,000 points which was the minimum. They told us we could not have a suite and we were a little disappointed but it would be fine because he was giving us a great view. Then the manager came in and changed everything and gave us the nicest suite ever! They gave us the top floor. They brought champagne and chocolate strawberries quickly to our room. It was the best ever!! The room was simple but beautiful. The view was amazing! The bed was soooo comfortable and I slept like a baby. I can't say enough about the bathroom. It was sooo nice. I would give the bathroom a 5 star. I'm not kidding! For a sheraton, it was very impressive. I don't know why I haven't been to this hotel before. Now that I know how nice everyone is there and how extremely comfortable they made us, I will go back soon. We go into the city a lot and I will for sure go back!! Thank you so much Sheraton! You wowed us!!
Good price for the room. But it's not four star. Three at a push. But makes up for it because it's cheap. Bad point: music too loud in lobby. Good point: great king size bed

For 350 dollars without breakfast, without safe deposit in the room and without free wifi, this hotel is a rubbery ! Way too expensive for what you get ! Taking into account it is on Canal Street which is gross !! Of course if you close your eyes on canal street and turn left you are not far from Soho, Mondrian hotel etc but still it is too pricey ! Won't go back !

We stayed at this hotel a little while back and were very pleased with the location, the staff and the accommodations. We decided to upgrade our room to one of the higher floors and thought it was worth it for the views of the Empire State building and the city skyline. There were some adverse conditions (hurricane / tropical storm) during our stay and the hotel staff did an outstanding job making sure we were taken care of and safe. The general Manager, Lowell, really took charge and seemed to still be enjoying himself during the entire ordeal. Little Italy and China town are both within walking distance. We also made our way down to the financial district, stopping to see the city hall and other sites along the way. Subway stops are only a block away and we found that if you walked over a block to either 6th Avenue or Broadway you could easily waive down a taxi. I had a sandwich (The Spiderman) from the Tribeca Deli next door to the hotel and was pleasantly surprised. The world famous Lombardi's pizza is also only a few blocks away in Little Italy and is worth a visit if you have never been. Up on Prince street is Torrisi Italian Specialties. We stopped to eat here twice as it was easily one of the best restaurants (albeit smallest) in Manhattan. Overall we found the hotel covered all of our basic needs and exceeded them in many regards. We have recommended this place to friends visiting New York city in the future and would gladly return.

First overnight stay in NYC and I don't think it could've been better for the location and price. Hotel is extremely clean, and new with modern decor. Hotel staff was extremely helpful and professional. We stayed in a room on the 20th floor with an amazing view of the Empire State building. From here, you could also see all the chic new condos/apts in Tribeca with their rooftop patios and lush gardens. It was really beautiful. The room was small, which is to be expected in NYC so I don't see a need to complain about it, I knew what I was getting when I booked it. Bathroom was very nice and shower was great. Once leaving the hotel, you are directly on canal street so expect it to be loud and busy. There are some really great restuarants within walking distance and I suggest walking around to see Tribeca a little bit while you are there. Bubby's is a great brunch spot and it's only a 10 minute walk!

During my week at the Sheraton TriBeCa, the staff were always amazing, from the chatty coffee shop servers, to the lovely front desk associates and the daily notes from Jane in housekeeping. But for me the quality of the hotel comes down to the doormen and how they treat the guests. All hail Michael V, one of the doormen at the Sheraton. This man became my Prince Charming when one horribly windy and rainy day I got my stiletto heel stuck in the outside grate. He ran to assist, helped me balance on one foot while he tried to free the offending shoe! On his knees in the wet, calling for tools to leverage the blasted thing as he didn't want to break the heel from the shoe. What a star, he got it free, only a little worse for wear! So thank you, thank you, thank you to my Prince Charming!

This is a nice hotel in Tribeca. It is not close to Uptown, theatre district or shopping - but you can hop on the subway and be uptown in minutes. I hate to tell "travelingfool" that no hotels in NYC or any resort for that matter have free internet. This hotel has an outstanding computer area which you can use for free and the lobby is wired for internet for free.Thanks to everyone who was so nice.

We stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca in NYC from Nov 3rd to Nov 8th. Our experience was excellent. The staff was friendly, the room was clean, the hotel was in a great location, and also had a good vibe. One of the doorman, named David, was especially friendly to us. We have a 1.5 yr old and he helped entertain her while we were in the lobby. We saw him everyday and he made us feel very welcome. When/if we come back I hope he is still working there. Would not change anything about our visit.Thanks,Eric

Our dry cleaning was lost for reasons unknown. I would like to congratulate Steve Lamour the front desk manager for the efficient way this matter was handled. Within 14 days of returning to England a full refund was credited to my Card. Well done

For the $300+/night price I paid for the room, they don't even include free in-room Internet. How tacky is that? Next time I will stay at one of their competitors' properties where breakfast is free and so is wireless Internet.Other that that, the room seemed particularly small, even for NYC standards. But it was clean and the bed was comfortable, so it gets the 2 circles I'm giving it because of those features. The USB charger in the wall did not work.Lastly, I asked the front desk agent about why my receipt showed I wasn't getting loyalty points. She declined to help and suggested I call the 800 #. Not very helpful. The bellman was very helpful though in getting our bags and hailing cabs.There is a nice little convenience store next door that offers cooked-to-order hot breakfast, pizza, and other hot food that is actually pretty tasty and much cheaper than the hotel restaurant.

Like many of the Sheraton/Starwood properties in NYC, this hotel has managed to capitalize on an excellent location. In addition to its address on Canal Street, one of the city's main arteries, within a couple of blocks of several different subway lines, this hotel is a very easy walk from all sorts of cool and interesting neighborhoods. If you should happen to decide that the restaurant in the hotel is too crowded or expensive (as I did), you are only a few minutes away from the much more interesting restaurants of SoHo, Chinatown, or TriBeCa. The hotel itself is pretty nice too - the lobby tends to be too crowded, but that's because it hosts the hotel's free WiFi, the Sheraton Link computers, a nice bar, AND a Starbucks. The desk staff is helpful and cosmopolitan, and there is also an on-site concierge.The rooms are fairly basic and a bit small, but clean and well appointed. If you can get a room on a higher floor, the views are great. The club lounge, although only available to club level guests or Platinum rewards guests, is clean and pleasant, and while the free breakfast for club guests isn't gourmet or particularly exciting, it is a) free and b) plentiful. It's also a lot better than the free continental breakfast many places offer (i.e. a packaged muffin or bagel and weird coffee). The club lounge also includes a rather spacious roof deck with completely amazing views - it faces north, but you can also look out over either the East River or the Hudson River.

This is a new Sheraton with a gleaming lobby and clean and new rooms. What sets this Sheraton apart is the friendly service from everyone. The front desk, the club floor hostess, and the doorman were all professional and courteous, which is saying something in NYC! The only other Starwood with service this consistent in NYC is Le Parker Meridien. The bill the Sheraton slipped under my door already had the internet charges removed (as they are for SPG platinums like me). Also, the breakfast is the best club room breakfast I've ever had. Lovely fresh fruit, scrambled eggs not dried out, sausage, bacon, tasty looking pastries, many different kinds of bagels and cereal, Starbucks coffee, Tazo tea, readily available skim milk, etc. The hostess (Zakira? She had a unique name) even procured ketchup for me when I asked, and apologized it wasn't already out ("I knew there was something I forgot," she said).Cons: In the boondocks, tacky room decor (does brick red ever look good used so liberally?), no views from most rooms, groaning bathroom fan.But the downsides are negligible, and I will be back!

This a newer Sheraton in a great location on Canal Street in Manhattan. You are walking distance from Tribeca, Soho, Little Italy, and Chinatown. You are also within a block or two of three subway lines so you can get anywhere pretty easily. The lobby area is nice and they have a bunch of stations set up for people to get on line. There is a bar but we did not visit it. The room was newer and clean, if a bit small (though probably standard by Manhattan standards). I would probably stay here again although I thought it was pricey for what is probably a 3 star hotel at best- but that's New York.

I loved the location of this hotel. The rooms are a bit small but clean and comfortable. It sucks that the only complimentary wifi is in the lobby and you have to pay $10 to use it in your room. So, the wifi area in the lobby is always packed.

As you would expect from Starwood Hotels, this is a fine hotel. It has a very friendly and helpfull staff and the location is perfect for business as well as pleasure. Soho and Chinatown are a short walk away and the subway lines A,C & E stop right around the corner to bring you to the rest of Manhattan. The only downside is that this part of Canal street is crawling with street vendors selling counterfeit Gucci and Prada.The rooms are luxureous; Good bed, large TV.We had no breakfast in the hotel because it appeared better and cheaper outside and it was very crowded in the morning. There is a little bar in the lobby where you get Starbucks coffee and a snack.But...: Internet is only free in the lobby (45 minutes a day), on your room it's $10/day. This should be free of charge.The rooms are reasonable quiet, but in this class of hotels you would expect better soundproofing - especially the doors. You can hear the doors slamming in the hallway all night and morning.And: All this does not come cheap, we paid around $380/night. With that in mind, the value is average.

the real benefit of this hotel is the central location that makes it to run around to meetings - the service level is excellent - especially the doormen Michael V & Jarrett seemed to be there to help me with anything I needed every time i hit the footpath. All the other staff were fantastic but these became almost like new friends in manhattan

I'm a starwood member and do love their hotels. As usual, the hotel was clean, staff was friendly and the bed was super comfortable. The drawback here is really the location. If you're in NYC, there is going to be street noise. I expected that. But being RIGHT on canal street, it was incredibly loud at all times. If you're going to book this hotel, see if you can get a room that's not facing Canal. I didn't mind all of the cheap vendors on the street but it's not a place I'd really want to walk around with my kids. It is close to shopping in Soho (W Broadway is fantastic) and has many subway lines nearby so that is a plus. However, for a similar price point, next time I'll be staying at the Sheraton Soho.

My husband and I stayed at this hotel recently for our 15th wedding anniversary. The staff was fantastic. They were friendly, helpful and very responsive. Overall the hotel was clean and the location was great - within walking distance to all the shopping on Canal and Broadway as well as many great restuarants and China town. The only negative is that it seemed a bit pricy for the area but in the end we felt it was worth it.

Very clean, pleasant and efficient. (Tribecca is a great neighborhood but Canal Street is gross.) Nice decor. Very comfy beds. If you're a light sleeper avoid the corner rooms because the doors open and close loudly. Free wi-fi in the lobby but not in the room. Great roof deck on the 18th floor but you have to ask to be let up unless you have a club key.

The front desk lies and says you "requested" one bed when you asked for two; the internet stinks & is virtually non-existent, so their "computer center" is a mean joke; the prices for rooms and even for breakfast are exorbitant; the advertising photos pretend that you'll get great views, but almost all rooms look onto brick walls; the owners regard guests as walking bags of money and they know they will get a lot of it.
Room was quite Spacious.. for NYC Standards, Clean & very Comfortable! Loved the Location.. walking distance to some of my favorite Boutiques in Soho!

Rooms are a decent size, considering this is NYC, with floor to ceiling windows. Very clean hotel with a nice bathroom. The bed is very comfortable and the glass shower is very modern. I recommend this hotel if you are looking for convenience. It is very close to the subway and walking distance to Tribeca and Soho. FYI-There is only complimentary wifi in the lobby. If you are a SPG, good for you as this hotel has high floors with great views and complimentary breakfast. Of course the breakfast is for gold members and above, but the view is amazing. You can sit inside and watch TV or sit outside on the rooftop and enjoy the city views.

I stayed at this hotel for a business trip in September. I usually keep my business trips to New York City to one night because a comfortable hotel room of good quality is tough to come by at a decent price and in a convenient location. My stay at the Sheraton Tribeca was the first time I was wishing I was staying longer.The room was a good size for NYC with ample space at the writing desk and a comfortable armchair for watching tv. There is no closet, but a decent sized armoir for two people that fit everything I needed. The bathroom was wonderful - a great shower and nice finishes.The view was decent, with a little peak of the bridge, and getting to the subway to zip around the city was a short two block walk.I didn't try the restaurant, but the bar was decent. A great location for exploring Soho. I'm looking forward to my next stay!

I took my two daughters to New York for a 4 day, 3 night shopping trip. The hotel was clean, the staff were always helpful, and the location is great. I was concerned after reading previous posts about the Canal Street location. There are other streets to go outside this hotel to avoid Canal, even though we were out until midnight and had no problems. Walking out the front of the hotel, you can walk straight down Wooster,( a really trendy art studio street) and turn at any of the cross streets, which are lined with cafe's, retail stores, etc. It's about a 15 minute walk from the hotel to Greenwich Village, on streets lined with restaurants, clothing stores, and the like. We had a great time, and would definitely stay there again. The only negative is having to pay $10 dollars a day to have Internet in your room, I think the Sheraton could do better

The Sheraton Tribeca is a clean, new, contemporary hotel near Soho. The location was convienient to travel easily in NYC. The subways are nearby. My husband and I enjoyed our stay at the hotel. We were stuck there during the hurricane and we were thankful we had a very nice new roomy comfortable king size bedroom, large flat screen tv with a terrific view of the Empire state building. There are computers available to use downstairs with free internet access. The lobby is very welcoming and the staff were very friendly and hospitable. I enjoyed my stay at this hotel and would highly recommend it. However, next time, I would stay near central park and the museums.

I wish there was a ranking between Average and very good as this hotel would definitely fall under this rating. The staff were mostly friendly and helpful and the location of the hotel is excellent. The room however was tiny. This may be standard for New York but $300 a night for a room that only just had enough room around the bed to walk around seems a little excessive. My biggest issue was the fact that there is no mini bar/fridge in the room. This was frustrating when bring back water or drinks to the room as we then had no where to keep them cold.On the positive side... there was always a computer available for the free internet service, it was only a short walk to SOHO, China Town, Little Italy and Greenwich Village. It is also literally a 3 min walk to the Canal sunway station which will take you directly to Time Square within 10-15 mins.The personal note from housekeeping each day was also a nice touch.

There was nothing outstanding about this hotel but it nonetheless is your typical, recently renovated Sheraton. The rooms were clean, the lobby was very inviting, solid fitness center, and a pleasant staff. The location is excellent as well. Don't have much else to say about it because if you are accustomed to the "new" Sheartons then it delivers.

The staff is extremely nice but the property is just regular and the cost seemed high to me (400 usd) the location is very good if you want to be in soho or tribeca and there are 2 metro stations very close. the hotel has an integrated starbucks making breakfast easy.

The Sheraton Tribeca is a new, mid-scale Sheraton located on gritty (but safe) Canal Street (a highly-trafficked through street that runs between an East River bridge and the Holland Tunnel), but is literally around the corner from the best of SOHO and Tribeca. Its 4* rating is reflective of its full-service status, but one should not infer "near luxury", as might be associated with 4* Westin or Intercontinental.The decor is trendy and high-tech and oriented to a younger crowd. During our 4 day stay, we saw lots of young people and lots and lots of European tourists.The staff was excellent- efficient and eager to please. The hotel is new and everything works. Like all Starwood properties, the beds are wonderful. The buffet breakfast at $15 is a bargain. Given how noisy Canal Street is, it is a pleasant surprise that the rooms are as quiet as they are.Bottom line: The hotel does the job and is convenient to the downtown scene. It isn't luxurious, but isn't down-market either. At $350/400 a night, I can do better elsewhere. With a one or two in front of the price, you will have done well in Manhattan, especially if you want to be downtown.

We stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca two weekends ago. The room was great - updated, nice size (especially in New York). It was crowded because we had a stroller, crib and fridge, but probably bigger than some studios. I had arranged for a crib and a fridge since we were travelling with an infant. They provided a full sized crib, which is wonderful. Other hotels we have stayed at have dingy pack and plays. Everyone we encountered was wonderful and helpful. I couldn't have enjoyed our stay any more, it was a wonderful place for young families.The only down side for us was that the location wasn't wonderful. It was pretty much a hike to every where we wanted to be, but that was my mistake. Also, the business center was right in the lobby and it provided you with a half hour or so of free internet time. We only used about 2 minutes of it to print our boarding passes, but that was a fantastic set up. Pre kids, I travelled quite a bit and while I have stayed at swankier hotels, the Sheraton Tribeca is now definitely one of my favorites.
Had a great overnight. Club floor great - especially breakfast. In particular like to commend Michael the doorman. He is awesome!!

Paid a lot of dollars to stay two nights here. Bad points:  1, They placed me next to the maids store room. The door was banging on a regular basis. Sound like nothing but after a few hrs of trying to sleep it kinda gets on your nerves. Good job this was vacation and not business. 2, Went for a shower in the morning only to find it was lacking no facilities to wash. 3, The elevators require your key card to work. Not a bad idea if it works correctly. Unfortunately for most of the people I spoken to found it a complete pain to use. Sometimes taking 5 mins to get to your floor. At one point I used the stairs. 4, The wireless connection. Only worked 50% of the time I was there. I was told to go to Starbucks. Nice! I pay 100s of dollars, only to find I have to visit Starbucks to check my business matters. If this was a working trip that would have made me check out! Good points:1, Nice friendly staffMy advice is to find an alternative to this place. Your get more for your money! Russ McCullochAndrea Holt

My husband and I stayed here over Labor Day weekend, from Wed-Mon. We booked through Priceline and got a really great rate as a combined air/hotel package. Our room was not ready when we arrived at around 11am, but we’d anticipated that, as check in isn’t until mid-afternoon. They happily stored our luggage for us and gave us an estimated time that a room would be ready. We went in search of lunch in the meantime and had a great meal in Chinatown. We wandered around, returning to the hotel at the estimated time. A room still wasn’t available, but the front desk clerk quickly made some calls and found a room that would be ready in 10-15 minutes. Enough time to grab a beer at the hotel bar! They had a special going on some bottles, so it was reasonably priced for us (I think $3 or $4?). The lobby was very nice - computers to use, a full bar, Starbucks, and you can use their Wi-Fi for free in the lobby (for 45 min at a time).They let us know when the room was ready and got our bags for us. The room was small, but not too small. We had a king-bed room on the 10th floor. As others have noted, there’s not a real closet, but they do have a wardrobe with some shelves to put your clothes and there are more shelves under the desk area. Only a shower, no tub, but that didn’t bother us as we don’t usually use hotel tubs anyway. The bed was extremely comfortable and the a/c worked great.The housekeepers our first 3 days or so were great. Left us notes thanking us for the tip we left and when I requested an extra towel, she responded and gave us extra everything! Much appreciated. The last couple of days we didn’t get any notes and the extra towels were gone w/o replacements. Oh well. Not a big deal, but the personal communications and accommodations were a nice touch.Canal St isn’t the most scenic or prettiest street in NYC. But you are within steps of Soho, Tribeca, Chinatown and Little Italy, not to mention a few different subway lines (and if you have a smart phone and are nervous about navigating the city, I highly recommend the HopStop app). I thought it was a great location to be stationed and we never felt unsafe – you have to use your room key to operate the (sometimes slow) elevators.I don’t know if I’d pay the full going rate for the Sheraton Tribeca – I’m pretty sure it would be out of our budget. But if I found another great deal, I would definitely give it another go.

After much searching my husband aand I decided on this h otel. We had reserved two rooms as two of our sons and one of our grandsons were meeting us in New York. The rooms were beautiful. Views were fantastic. Beds were quite comfy. Everyone we came in contact with was helpful, especially the gentleman who drove us to the train station, as there were five of us and that is too many for a taxi. Enjoyed the lounge area at night after walking and seeing the sights of New York City. The bartender was great! Canal Street is a little crazy but the location is perfect to get uptown or downtown. Highly recommend! We would stay again!

I made 2 separate reservations for a 2 day stay, first for one day and then for a second, when it became clear that I needed to extend my stay. This led to all kinds of problems with my being locked out of my room, etc etc. The hotel seemed completely unable to combine the 2 reservations into one. The bed was fantastic, the views are great, and the staff was nice. Breakfast was average.
Great location, on the border of Soho & Tribeca. Close to lots of great shops and restaurants. VERY SLOW elevators!

Super nice new hotel. Perfect location for fashion-shopping and so many bars and restaurants to visit. Beautiful wiev from 9. floor room towards north (Empire State Building) and overlooking Soho rooftop-silouette. Deli next door, rent-a-bicycle across Canal Street and delicious breakfast downstairs in the hotels restaurant or in-house Starbucks.Staff - ALL of them - were top-dedicated to the goal of making our stay a dream come true. Clearly recommendable. I´ll be back.

Stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca the last weekend of August, 2011 for a wedding. Irene, the hurricane, was not invited but she came anyway.We drove our car to the hotel and were a little surprised that there wasn't a better entrance for guests arriving. You're lucky to get a spot on Canal Street to unload your car. Valet parking was $60/day. Upon arrival, I thought we'd be bombarded by bellmen who'd help us get unloaded, etc. but not so much. My husband ended up taking our car to a local garage that was INDOORS and ABOVE GROUND to make sure we'd be okay if the hurricane hit. It ended up taking him about 20 minutes to go around the block and I attribute this to the mad rush of commuters getting out of the city before the storm him. Still, kind of a pain to deal with.Otherwise, check in was smooth. We were in the club level as our reservation was booked with my Starwood points. The bellman who took us our to our room, was extremely knowledgable, full of information, and eager to give us a great experience. We were taken to our room on the 17th floor. Our room was beautiful and roomy for NYC standards. One wall was all windows looking right towards the the Empire State building. Fantastic views and the rooms are brand new and well designed.Because of the impending hurricane, many of the guests were basically stuck at the hotel since all of Tribeca shut down.
