So the bars was full, the computers were being used and there was a lot of activity in the lobby and restaurant. I have to give the staff a ton of credit. No one seemed annoyed by the questions, the stress or the influx of guests. They kept a bulletin board with storm updates in the lobby and a flyer on each floor. Overall, the hotel was fantastic at providing news on the storm, what roads were open, what their plan was, and what we could expect if we got hit hard.Fortunately, we only lost cable for a an hour or two. Power never went out. And I have to mention how comfortable the beds were. We slept so well during the height of the storm and the linens kept us warm and cozy.Upon checkout, right after the storm, we decided to hit the breakfast buffet to get some food in us before our drive home. If we could actually drive anywhere. The buffet left a lot to be desired. The eggs were old and cold, there was no more toast left and none of the staff seemed concerned that they were busier than usual and guests were in line waiting to eat.However, I have to say that the Sheraton staff managed the storm and its inconveniences really well. I loved that there was a Starbucks in the lobby to get some morning coffee. And the lobby was bustling with travelers who made it a communal meeting space. The staff accomodated. The rooms are extremely comfortable, the views are amazing and the location is central to everything in lower Manhattan. Would definitely stay again.

I stayed at this hotel over Labor Day weekend and was very pleased with it. As a devoted Starwood Preferred Guest, I'm pretty picky about my hotels. And this one definitely hit the mark. First off, it's just around the corner from the subway station that serves the A, C and E lines. That means if you flew into JFK, it drops you off almost at the front door for a whopping $7.25 with both the Air Train and Subway fares. Other subway lines are within a few blocks, so you can literally get anywhere in Manhattan very easily and for $2.25 a ride. Add to that, you're right across the street from SoHo, which has shopping and restaurants a-plenty - all very walkable. This is a busy hotel with a fairly small lobby area that made it feel even busier. But that was never an issue for me. I was still able to get an elevator rather easily. The lobby is modern and clean with lots of amenities - a grab-and-go food/drink counter, a small bar with seating area, a restaurant, and an area with several computers .I was lucky to get into a room on an upper floor, so the view was great. Furnishings are comfortable, including the bed. The bathroom isn't huge, but it's well-equipped with a nice stand-up shower and well-lit mirror. The one thing I thought was odd was there were no drawers for unpacking my suitcase. The closet had hangers, but nowhere to really put things that don't hang. Not a huge inconvenience. Staff was very friendly, efficient and helpful. The rooftop deck (which I believe is only accessible to Club floors - Splurge! It's worth it!) has INCREDIBLE 180 degree views of the city, as well as breakfast and evening snacks. This is highly unique for a New York hotel.Yes, so this hotel is directly on Canal Street, which is totally nasty and crowded. But as you walk out the front door, just head left and go around the corner to the parallel street behind Canal. It's quiet, safe, and no one is going to try to sell you a fake Rolex. That's what I did to get to the N, Q, R subway stop. And once you get off of Canal in any direction, your'e right back to charming, movie set-like, downtown New York.Comparing to what NYC hotels are charging these days for a nice, modern, new-ish room, I thought this hotel was a bargain - and I compare all Starwood properties before I make my decision (always check AAA rates and "hotel offers" on the SPG site before you book). This one has often had the lowest price. Request or book an upper floor, or at least one that faces uptown. You won't be disappointed!

Sheraton Tribeca is a newer hotel in downtown Manhattan. The rooms were clean and the beds comfortable. We were in a connecting room and could hear the neighbors children. Easy walk to Soho and the subway. Would stay again.
Not too many hotels in the Tribeca/ financial district. Good location for business and prices are fair. Service was ok as was food. I would come back.

Sorry--I am not accustomed to posting negative reviews but must share my terrible customer service experience at the Sheraton Tribeca as fair warning. This is a very nice property but if the hotel can get away with charging you for something, they will.I stayed here in April for a college visit to NYU with my daughter and booked another reservation on August 29 for her move in at NYU. Unfortunately, I had to cancel the reservation because NYU shifted move-in schedules due to Hurricane Irene and it would no longer be feasible for me to check in to the hotel on the same day as the rescheduled move-in day. I called the hotel directly to cancel the reservation. For some reason, the hotel staff member did not provide a cancellation number--perhaps distracted due to--I don't know--maybe a myriad of guest cancellations due to the hurricane? Moreover, for some very strange reason--perhaps with so much on my mind between rearranging all of my travel schedules, being emotional over my first-born going away to college, and feverishly shopping for dorm items online while the city was shut down--I did not ask for a cancellation number for the first time in my life. Not only did the hotel charge me for the room and not retain a record of the room cancellation (don't they record conversations in the event of disputes like this?), they also insist that if I did not receive a cancellation number, then 1) the responsibility is mine to ask for one, and 2) if they don't have a record of it, it did not happen. Really?! Is it not possible that perhaps one of the hotel staff members got distracted and neglected to give me a cancellation number and record this important information? I have the phone record to prove that I called the hotel in advance of my stay and–believe me, it was to cancel the room, not a request to fluff up my pillows! I had four phone conversations with the hotel to try to resolve this--first with Steven at the front desk, who promised I would receive a phone call from the general manager--a phone call I never received. When I called back, I spoke with Priscilla, she insisted she was "the manager" and insisted on resolving my problem, and then when I asked for the general manager, she instead referred me to Cornelio Encarnacio, the reservations manager. Fast-forward several days later, and a conversation with Cornelio that went nowhere. When I again asked to speak with the general manager, I was referred instead to the revenue manager. Um – me thinks the revenue manager would not be inclined to reverse charges if he is responsible for increasing revenue. Just a guess. Why were guarding the GM? It was not until I looked up the general manager's name online and asked for him by name that I finally spoke with GM Lowell Beebe-Center. Apparently, he had been spoon-feeding his staff the responses to me because he held the same position -- no record at the hotel means it did not happen. He refused to reverse the charge and assume any responsibility for the mistake his staff made. Lessons learned: 1) always ask for and record a cancellation number and, 2) apparently, the customer never wins at the Sheraton Tribeca. I have never encountered such unfriendly and unbending management and staff—especially in light of the circumstances. We were both affected by Hurricane Irene and the hotel took advantage of that. I guess they really, really needed the revenue. Unbelievable.

The Sheraton Tribeca is a tyical business hotel suited directly at Canal Street. The rooms are not too small, the furniture is nice and the bathroom was clean. So, the objective aspects are all right.But then again, you do not have normal glasses in your room. Plastic mugs are okay for a YMCA or some low budget hotel, but not for a Sheraton. Further, the rooms do neither have a deposit nor a mini bar, the shampoo wasextremly greedy portioned etc.Many minor details, but still, a Sheraton does not have to present itself like thtat.

Stayed as a Plat for the first time last weekend with the wife. It is a 'fine' and basic hotel. I got the usual ''upgrade'' from a basic room to a club floor -- still dont really consider this an upgrade- but nevertheless. This hotel is in a great location for shopping. Next to Broadway and Soho -- some great places within walking distance...There is a club lounge which is very nice and has a great patio, BUT no free alcohol! Which basically renders this lounge useless except for a basic cold breakfast in the morning. What's the point? Might as well go to a nice bar...The rooms here are fine. Basic. Nothing fancy...Staff was friendly...Ultimately, good location for shopping -- and if you want to get away from Times SQ.
Everyone was delightful, especially David Tom. He did everything with a smile. The beds and pillows were OUTSTANDING. We slept like babies.

My daughter and I stayed for two nights while she moved into the NYU dorms. It is close by, but not walkable. It is about an $8.00 taxi ride. It may be possible to take the subway, but since I was not familiar with the subway we did not bother. The check in was quick with no problems. The hotel is modern, clean, and the lobby cheerful. There is one restaurant and a coffee bar/cafe (which is not a sit down restaurant). The restaurant is okay, but there are no windows in it. Prices are typical of a hotel. There are complimentary computers in the lobby with free wifi. However, it is $10 per day for wifi in your room. There is also a bar in the lobby, although I did not order anything from it. The block that the hotel is on is not the best. It is deserted at night with few businesses. It is not scenic. Security in the hotel is good and you need a key card to operate the elevator. I found the room to be very small with not much room to walk around. The bathroom was tiny as well, with just enough room for one person to stand in it. It's possible though that other rooms were bigger. The room was just big enough for a king size bed, two small night table and a small desk. TAhe bed however, was very, very comfortable and the room was clean. It was also very quiet. All in all, I would say that it was adequate, but not worth the $325.00 per night charge (with taxes) that I paid. It was not on a particularly nice street (although the hotel is fine), but I guess the price is typical of Manhattan hotels.

We (I mostly) travel to NYC regularly, so we are quite independent there. Great place if you love downtown: SoHo, Tibeca, etc. Walked to Ground Zero. Hotel was busy! Totally set up for convenience (2 outlets in each bedside lamp, extra little shelves in the bathroom and right inside the guest room) and very helpful staff. Obviously recently remodeled and well-conceived. Used the front desk and Concierge rarely, but they were quite helpful. Great open multi-use area in the center of the lobby for computers and for drinks just over a partial wall. OH! Our room was out-of the way a bit, so VERY quiet. Great view of midtown!
Very clean & modern hotel. Staff were very friendly & helpful. No problem getting refund when we had to evacuate for Irene.

This was my 1st trip to NYC and I was not expecting to receive this level of friendliness from the Staff at Sheraton Tribecca.I arrived in the hotel at about 9AM from JFK and was praying that I was going to be able check-in early since I was not feeling very well. I was greeted by this very nice lady at the front desk (she was pregnant) and she was immediately aware of my condition. She checked her computer and gave me a room. The check-in process was very fast, probably 5 minutes (or less), which I was so grateful for since all I needed at that time was sleep. We only stayed there for 2 nights but during that time all the Staff we encountered were very friendly, informative & helpful. From the Concierge, the Bell Man, the Barista (at the coffee shop at the Lobby), to the Housekeeper. The hotel looks new & have modern ammenities. Room and bathroom were both very clean; I did not notice any stains on the carpet, the wall, and more importantly the bed spread. Everything was immaculate. It's on the small side, but what do you expect, it's NYC. And there is only 2 of us. 3 would be a crowd. The AC is a little on the loud side but it didn't bother us. Bed was very comfortable.The hotel is located on Canal Street which was always jammed packed. We avoid hailing cabs on that street and just took the subway which was only about 1 minute walk from the hotel. There wasn't much going on at nite on the Canal Street. It was around 11pm and we were looking for a bite to eat and so we walked a few blocks away (towards the Tribecca Grand Hotel) and found a few restaurants there and a night club. The restaurants did not serve food at that hour (I think we had just missed the last call) but the host was nice enough to send us over to the Lobby of the Tribecca Grand Hotel...they served great midnight snacks and we were very satisfied with the quality of the food. I should probably write a separate review of the Lobby @ Tribecca Grand Hotel :)Overall, I think Sheraton Tribecca is on the average side. But the Staff and Cleanliness were definitely above average. I would stay here again in the future.

We planned on staying here 2 nights for multiple concerts at Governors Island and received a group rate through the band. Due to the threat of Hurricane Irene, the Saturday show was postponed, so we tried to cancel the Saturday night reservation. When I called the hotel, I kept getting patched through to their national customer service call center. Every time I spoke to the customer service reps, they said if I cancelled the second night, I wouldn’t be able to keep the discounted rate and it would result in a rate change of $100 more since it was less than 24 hours from the first check-in day. They weren’t very sympathetic to the upcoming hurricane threat and weren’t even willing to match the current online rate, which was about halfway between the 2 rates. We decided not to cancel the 2nd night and take it up with the hotel when we arrived. Upon arrival, we asked to cancel the 2nd night so we could evacuate due to the hurricane. The friendly and helpful gentleman at the front desk said that wouldn’t be a problem and promptly cancelled the 2nd night without any rate change. We were very pleased that the employees at the actual hotel were more sympathetic to this unusual circumstance and made everything very simple and quick for us. They also let us check in 45 minutes early, so we were thrilled about that as well.The King bed room we had was very small and the bed and a chair took up most of it, but that’s pretty typical for NYC hotels. The bed was one of the most comfortable beds I’ve ever slept in, so I was pretty mad when I had to wake up at 6 AM to catch a train the next morning. Everything in the room and bathroom was very clean and modern-looking, especially the flat screen TV, phone and shower. There was also a pretty cool electronics hub in the room that could accommodate all sorts of different input and output cables for various electronics, although I didn’t have time to play around with it.I can’t really speak for the Tribeca neighborhood since I’ve never stayed in this part of Manhattan before, but everything for many blocks was closed at 1 AM so there wasn’t much nightlife around. The hotel bar closed at about 1:30 AM, so that didn’t really help our cause. I had to walk about 10 blocks just to find a convenience store that was open. The subway entrances for the 1 and A/C/E lines were both a couple minutes away, so that made it cheap and easy to navigate to various parts of the city.A final note about the Hurricane - The hotel had flyers at the front desk and elevator areas providing guests with an update of the hurricane on Friday. Even though the hotel wasn’t in the mandatory evacuation zone, they took the time to give another update to every room late Friday night asking people to leave for their safety early Saturday morning if possible, but that they’d remain open with limited services if they had nowhere else to go. This is evidence of the hotel’s genuine care for their guests and quality management during an event that’s very unusual for NYC.

This was the 5th hotel we stayed at at the end of a two week holiday in USA, and was by far the most disappointing. Don't get me wrong - the room was ok, clean and comfortable, but it was the smallest of the three rooms we'd stayed in in NYC, and the most expensive. We thought we'd book something nice for our last night - so splashed out on this 4star hotel and expected something special. Wished wehad gone back to the Yotel or Thirty Thirty.

What makes this hotel is the staff and the location.I had a number of queries before booking and these were addressed by Lowell the manager via email to great satisfaction. Tamika the night manager is one of the nicest people you could ever meet. The "breakfast lady" in the club lounge is hilarious - so nice and entertaining and natural. Nothing is an issue to any of the staff at this hotel. The bar has a really nice atmosphere as well and again the staff make the place. Did I say the staff were friendly ?Downsides - Small rooms, pay for internet Upsides - We LOVED the location. Did not feel unsafe at night like other reviews and we walked for miles day and night (by choice).It is worth paying the extra for the club room so that you get access to the rooftop balcony (and breakfast). It is a great place to enjoy a glass of wine and take in this incredible city from an unusual perspective.

New hotel, but very small rooms, even wardrobe can fit just few things...Despite i m a spg platinum they didn t gibe me a suite saying it was sold out, but it was available.....And any welcome amenity in the room. Doorman offered us a private trasportatiom to' the airport wirh a suv for 7 pax when i asked for 8. Unprofessional!!!!!

I stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca in July. Although I was a SP guest, they assigned me a room on one of the lower floors. I asked if there were any upgraded and the receptionist said no. I checked into my room and was shocked to see that the carpet was dirty and the room smelled musty. I opened up the drapes to the roof of the building next door that had a large industrial vent spewing green slime every 60 seconds. There was a hotel pillow on the roof outside my window. It was like a low end motel.I called the front desk and asked them to move me. I will give them credit that they immediately found me a better room (not sure why they didn't give me that room to begin with) and sent a bellman to move my stuff. the new room was even smaller and had a tiny corner window. They don't offer any perks like free coffee or breakfast. If this hotel was $150 a night, I would understand the quality of accommodations but for the rates they charge, this is not worth it.

This was to be a new adventure in Tribeca/Soho. I arrived with a 13 year old daughter and through our 5 night stay we had my husband join us 3 nights and my college age daughter 1 night. The location is not great for women alone or with teens. Canal street gets very empty and walking from 2 of the train lines doesn't feel safe. The location is more like Chinatown/Tribeca/Soho. Canal street is a mess. However, Tribeca and Soho can be fun for shopping and restaurants. For site seeing (museums, UN, Theater, Rockefeller Center, Central Park etc) we spent a lot of time on trains and taxis. The hotel itself is just okay. The staff vary from the bellhops which were wonderful to the front desk which was rude and hopeless. We booked a suite and asked that they have the queen sofa bed made when we arrived. When we arrived I double checked and was told it was fine. It wasn't. On the 3rd night it was finally made. The suite is actually not a suite so much as a sizeable room with a king bed and queen sofabed. If I were to do it again, I would go back to the Lucerne or one of the hotels that has true suites. I should say the air conditioning here was great for a NYC summer, the room amenities were very good and that Sheraton bed is great (the sofabed was not). We are loyal SPG fans, but sometimes it pays to look elsewhere and this hotel is not worth the cost. Also the large groups staying there meant the noise from halls was a pain if you are trying to sleep. The lobby is packed all of the time. My one serious recommendation if you stay here. When you leave the hotel go to the right (west) Great restaurants, train line to upper west side and Ya-Ya nails spa! To the left (east) and it's awful.

This isn't the fanciest hotel in Manhattan, but it was clean, the beds were incredibly comfortable, the service was friendly and efficient, and we couldn't have asked for a better location. Tribeca around the corner, Soho across the street, Chinatown right next door, and a whole bunch of other great neighbourhoods a short walk away. I would stay here again. My only complaints were minor: elevators were slow (it was faster to take the stairs), and the air conditioner in the room was loud and cycled on and off a lot, which required earplugs. If you're looking for a memorable meal nearby, try L'Ecole, the teaching restaurant for the French Culinary Institute. It's a couple of blocks away at Broadway and Grand. You'll need reservations. I've eaten there twice and had a completely wonderful experience both times.

My friend and I live in the city and love to take mini vacays right in our own amazing city every now and then. I booked this hotel in a different part of town than we usually stay in on a whim and we were pleasantly surprised. The hotel itself was clean, new and spacious. Our room had a large extra comfy king bed and flat screen that we watched movies on all day. We also loved that there was a bar downstairs and a 24 hour deli right next door, which we utilized respectively. We were sad to leave this morning. Even though we live just a mile or so north of this hotel, it truly felt like we were on vacation. I recommend this hotel and can not wait to stay here again!
As a frequet travellor at Starwood hotels I can not accept a $250 per nite hotel without: in room safe, adequate fitness facilities (small room, no free weights, no sauna or pool)

The street on which the hotel stands, Canal Street, is not for the faint of heart. I lost count of how many fake Rolexes I was offered on my way to the subway. Yes it was grimey and noisy, but it's a fun area and a part of town where you really can say that it's the city that never sleeps. Fantastic shops and restaurants are within a very short walk, as is the subway. But it is noisy at night. I think the hotel tries to drown out the noise of the traffic by making the A/C even noisier; and gaps under the doors mean that you can hear hallway noise very clearly. The room was small, even by NY standards, and the bathroom was tiny. A little bit mean with bathroom products - only one soap and shampoo, no matter how many nights you were there - and the room was never cleaned particularly thoroughly. There were still coffee stains down the wall from a previous guest, which hadn't been wiped away. The communal areas are fine and very clean. The best thing about the hotel was the service of the staff. From the barman, to the doormen, to the reception staff, everyone was friendly, helpful, and really made you feel welcome. Oh and one piece of advice - if you want to get Starwood points (this is why I'd chosen this hotel), you can't get them if you book through Expedia, as I had done.

Good - location, cleanliness (no bedbugs here), location, location, location, service, great shower.Bad - lack of storage space in the bedrooms, sparse toiletries and barely any coathangers.If you want to be downtown then this is a great place to be. Easily within walking distance of SOHO, Financial District, Tribeca and even the East Village if you're in shape and it's not too hot.

We had a couple free Starwoods nights and this was the best location of the available hotels. We booked another more boutique hotel but after seeing the Sheraton Tribeca we extended for another 2 nights at an outrageously low price (for NYC). Nicely remodeled and modern feel. Canal street is a little rough but walk half a block north and you're right in Soho. Close to subway lines.

This was a great, last minute decision to stay at the Sheraton because you can always count on their properties. Don't get fooled by the fact that you are staying on Canal St. because as soon as you cross the street, literally you are amidst the nicest restaurants and galleries of Soho. We were able to get around the entire city by train and for the most part, we walked to all of the neighbouring areas because they were so close. Soho has great resto options across the street. Walk 15 min. you are in Chinatown, and then add another 5 minutes and you will end up in Little Italy. The rooms are spacious for NY standards. The hotel concierge and staff are very friendly and give great directions and suggestions for the area. I don't let small things like the size of the bar or the lobby get to me because I don't intend to spend time there! The amenities were great and we even got an upgrade in our room even though it was an online purchase. We got in at 11am and although check-in was for 3pm, we had a room by 11:30 - super service.I would recommend this hotel to friends and would consider staying here again because of how conveniently located it is to pricey areas for less money!Shopping on Broadway is less than a 5 min. walk!

Blech, we got in to NYC late, the check in process took a long time, the staff wasn't overly friendly, the elevators were slow and cramped and worst of all we choose Tribeca because on the website we saw there was a patio on the rooftop for drinks... nope, only for their vip program customers. The entire reason we wanted to stay there was because of this and they wouldn't budge. What a waste! Rooms weren't impressive at all, bathrooms were so-so, would not stay there again. Also I know I left some souvenirs in the room and the hotel said they weren't found. I expected more out of Starwood.

The hotel itself is great - it is relatively new, very clean, and has a nice buzz in the lobby. The rooms have everything you would need and most (if not all) of what you would want, and are a decent size for Manhattan.The only negative I had about this hotel was the elevators. There were three available serving all 22 floors. I stayed on 18, so on the way up, it often stopped 5-6 times. And on the way down, it would be full after the first couple stops and would continue stopping every couple floors with no more room. It's minor, but something that became kind of annoying, yet expected.The location was pretty convenient to many cool areas/places....SoHo, Little Italy, Financial District, Brooklyn Bridge, Battery Park, Ground Zero, etc. In my opinion, the immediate area (China Town) is a dump. But if you get a few blocks beyond, you're back to "normal" Manhattan.

Hubby and I stayed at this property for 7 nights 11-18 July 2011. We were in NYC to search for an apartment and so were pretty busy and stressed out. We wanted a place that was central to lower Manhattan while also an oasis from the city stress. As longtime SPG members we decided to try this new hotel.I reserved a club level king via SPG and was able to easily contact the hotel. We were having a few items shipped to us at the hotel and needed to coordinate with the desk. Everything arrived and was held for us!Check In:Check in could have been better. This property has been slammed with business since its opening with a host of difficulties that I hoped would have been smoothed out by the time we arrived. But when I walked in at 6pm to be told "hang on while we find a room for you" when I had a reservation booked for several weeks did not make me feel secure. It all worked out quickly and we were on our way up. Please note that the bellman didn't even offer to help us take our bags upstairs.Room:The room was small but quite well appointed. The bed was extremely comfortable, and even though we were near the elevators I had no problems with hallway noise or sleeping. Immediately upon check in engineering came up with our refrigerator (free, you just have to ask) and a "Gym in a Bag", which was a fabulous idea - mat, foam roller, exercise tubing, and a massager. The only thing we really missed in the room was a safe. There is only a safe at the front desk, not in the rooms.Club Lounge:The Club Lounge is lovely and the view from the deck is stunning. The concierges on duty were always pleasant and attentive. The Food & Beverage service, however, was lacking. Every afternoon we had the same food - samosas, some kind of sausage in pastry, fried artichokes, and various crudite. Breakfast was a bit better. The printer and fax didn't work in the Club Lounge, so anytime I needed to print or fax it was a trip down to the lobby.Room Service:We ordered room service on 3 nights, and it was consistently good food and service. Portions were HUGE!WIFI:Wifi sucked for the first day or two, but them smoothed out. Be aware that even if you have a "Free Wifi" Club Room you will need to check your bill for wifi charges.Checkout:Check out was pretty smooth, except for the previously mentioned wifi charges. We have 2 laptops, 2 blackberries, 2 kindles, and an ipad. Every single day we were charged for each device connected at $9.95 per device - that's $70 a day! Plus we had been charged for a phone call we didn't make (I never use hotel room phones; it's cheaper to pay roaming!).In the end our stay was great and the hotel served as a nice refuge from the city while giving us the space and support to get work done. We love the location - near Chinatown, Little Italy, Soho, Tribeca. Just a few blocks to Excellent Dumpling House!

It's a good hotel for New York i guess, rooms and other parts of the hotel are well maintaned.Staff is friendly and the placement of the Sheraton Link computers and hot spot in the center of the lobby area is good. A nice way to socialize if you like to. Around the Link Area is a starbuck and bar.Wifi isn't free in the rooms we haven't tried using it at this hotel but i guess just like other Sheraton hotels it is $ 9,95 per device be aware of this.The hotel offers Valet Parking, they don't display the prices but they do point out self parking nearby. What i don't understand is that most Sheraton hotels on this trip don't display or tell Valet prices anywhere. We paid $ 100,00 for two nights of valet, this is a rate which certainly should be mentioned when checking in.In the direct area no big shopping possibilities. If you want to stay in this area consider staying in Jersey City. Parking is cheaper, hotelrooms are larger and cheaper. When using Path (Subway) you can be in NYC faster.All in All the hotel is a good one but expensive as you could expect for NYC.

Husband and I came to NYC to Celebrate anniversary. Our Son booked the room through priceline and got a great price. Before we arrived emailed hotel to inform of our special occasion. Not only were we upgraded, we were greeted in room with a lovely bottle of wine, and a decadent dessert. Way beyond my expectations. Stayed on club level floor which was awesome. Breakfast and afternoon snacks included. Did I mention the view from our floor to ceiling windows!! Fantastic. Cudo's to Lowell the GM for making our stay wonderful....Great location also.

Very convenient location ! The room we had was modern, very clean and bed-bug free ! The beds are extremely comfortable, Wifi was free and we had breakfast every morning at the lounge. The Metro is just around the corner. Plenty of restaurants and shopping nearby. The Manhattan area is so easy to walk around in that we ended up walking and discovering lots on our own.

Pros:Location near my office in TriBeCaLots of great restaurants in the areaPet friendlyFriendly conciergeCons:Cheap furnishings in the roomHousekeepingAmenities - e.g. no fridge in the standard room, only two bath towels provided for two people, cheap bar soap. Nothing was replenished during my 4 night stay.I also think that the front desk is full of incompetent staff. While friendly, from arrival to departure, they've completely missed the mark on my book.Case in point, upon checking out at 8 AM in the morning, I found out that there was an incorrect charge on my bill. I notified the front desk and was told that they will research the matter, and email me the correct bill within a couple of hours. I didn't hear back from them during the day. So, I came by the hotel at 5PM and was told that their accountant had left for the day and that the matter will be resolved on Monday. I told them that they knew about this problem at 8AM in the morning, so there's no excuse... I was asked who I spoke with, etc etc... After a few minutes, they printed the corrected bill for me, and said that they will refund my credit card for the incorrect charge. While the matter is resolved, it left a bad taste. There were few other examples... Anyway, I will not stay again here.

Don't be put off by the Canal Street address. The entrance is on Canal St and a bit gritty but around the corner is TRIBECA and across the street is SOHO.....not to mention quick access to the subways.Rooms are very modern, updated, clean and well designed. Rooms are regular size for NY which is small but the bathroom was perfect.The entire lobby area is designed as a friendly calm upscale internet cafe and bar (liquor as well as coffee et al). I loved it so much that I spent more time there for meals and going online than I had expected.Best of all was the friendly and informative staff. I believe they always went above and beyond to meet everyone's needs. The front desk was so very helpful as was everyone else. I do have to give a big 10 plus to Michael---the doormen/bellman---who worked very hard finding HARD TO FIND taxis for me so that I could make my meetings and flights. He was fun to talk to but very serious about helping me get to and from things.Last but not least, as a female business traveller, I felt safe. THANKS and I will be back.

This is a cookie-cutter Sheraton, nice staff with good location. The rooms are very small but who stays in their room while in NYC anyway. The dining room was never open during our stay, you had to eat in the bar which was just OK. I would stay their if the rate was low (125 per night in the Summer via bidding site) but it is absolutely not worth the $350 standard rate. The lobby is too small and poorly laid out but the luggage storage system is excellent. The area is not the greatest, but it is reasonably close to a subway stop. I was happy with the price vs. value.

New, good hotel in good location. We stayed twice in July. First time we were upgraded to 16th floor (apparently room rate is higher for rooms in upper floors).The second stay did start as smoothly; we could have had a room in upper floors only for surcharge. We declined and received a fourth floor room facing opposite wall. When we were going to bed few hours later we noted sheets weren't changed after the previous guest; there was a used tissue paper and black hairs in the bed. We went to complain in the front desk. The clerk apologized, but could only offer us similar room in fourth floor; she told there was only one room available? So we ended up changing room at 12.30 am. I wasn't very happy, but it was late, I was tired and didn't feel like arguing.To be fair, this was one time incident, otherwise our room and hotel were clean and ok. The only faults were lack of safety box and drawers in room. Iron was good but hte ironing board was very low.Canal Street is very busy and there are lots of counterfeit vendors, but there are attractive streets with restaurants and shops around the block in Tribeca and across Canal Street in Soho. Several subway lines within few blocks whisk you to around New York in no time. To fetch a taxi is not very easy in front of the hotel; taxis seemed to avoid Canal Street due to heacy traffic, so we usually walked few blocks to hail a taxi.Guests can use six computers for free in lobby, but they are very slow. Many pages, eg. Open Table could not be used; they were blocked as "adult pages".There are several laundries nearby hotel offering wash and fold for 12 $ for 10 pounds.The doorman recommended us to take a towncar to JFK, it cost the same as taxi (45$ + tolls & tips =60 $). We took it as we were leaving a bit late and to get a taxi was not easy in front of the hotel. I gave the driver 70 $ and he seemed to be very happy.

Whether you’d enjoy the stay at Sheraton Tribeca depends on your expectations, and the price you’ve paid. If you’re a business traveler, as we were, you’ll be disappointed. The lobby was overrun by families, and the “business center” filled with giggling teenagers on Facebook. Service was mixed: the technician dispatched to our room to fix the non-functioning electronics was genteel. The night receptionist demeanor was appropriate for a prison warden. The “concierge” was downright shady, attempting to sway us into an overpriced “limousine” when all we wanted was a taxi. However, the property is fresh and the room was well equipped, albeit extremely noisy even on a high floor. All in all, it was acceptable for the $100 we paid.

Our experience at the Sheraton hotel was great. We were greeted by Michael V. Michael helped us unload our car and showed us to our room. Each morning Michael greeted us and made sure we knew where we were going in the city. He always offered us a taxi or car to use from his company. Michael made us feel very comfortable and welcomed.

This is a newer hotel. My rooms was in a corner next to the stairs and very small. I've had this size room at other nicer NY hotels, but at least they came with a view. The room was nice, but not what I would expect for a Sheraton. It has the look and quality of what I would expect at a Four Points hotel in other parts of the country. Also, the hotel is on the edge of Tribeca in a somewhat seedy section of Canal Street near the Holland Tunnel entrance.

Though this property was the most convenient to my client site, I have avoided it whenever possible after repeatedly marginal experiences followed up by promises of a call by a manager that never materialize. The roof deck in the club lounge is the only reason to use this hotel; but don't expect access without a $50 fee or Platinum status.

Nice new modern hotel on Canal Steeet, on the edge of Chinatown and little Italy. Perfect access to subway and all the boutiques on Broadway and SoHo. HOWEVER, we had paid for an executive floor and were disappointed. We arrived at 4pm only to be asked to wait 15 minutes which turned into 30 minutes more. The lounge was poorly stocked and not clean. The fridge supposedly with soft drinks was empty and never regularly stocked. Coffee and tea available as well but no tea bags.Evening appetizers consisted of samosas and chicken skewers of average quality. The fridge still was not stocked with any additional soft drinks and the tea still absent.Breakfast in the morning was less than average, no breakfast pastries for those who didn't want eggs and bacon. The hostess present, however, was nice to go get a whole wheat croissant, that's all that was left downstairs. Silverware and plates were coffee stained ... Just an overall dirty atmosphere.We brought this to the attention to an assistant front desk manager who asked us why we didn't talk to a food and beverage manager !? We can only hope our feedback has been taken seriously. We were not expecting 5-star service but it can be a good club level lounge if there is attention to detail. For us the rate difference for the club level was not worth it.

Sheraton Tribeca 's location, straddling SoHo (directly above), Tribeca (directly below), China Town, and Little Italy, (short walks East), make it an ideal setting for exploring these very diverse and fascinating ' real New York City' neighborhoods, with such a wide range of architectures, shopping (international designers to street-corner hat sellers), dining opportunities, (from best-of-NY (e.g. NOBU) - to great pizza-slice joints). And close-by A-C-E and #6 Subway lines offer quick access to the rest of Manhattan.The Hotel is brand new (Oct 2010), with modern and sophisticated design throughout the lobby and the guest-rooms themselves (but not stuffy, families should feel very comfortable here). The staff were very courteous & efficient, genuinely friendly and helpful, from front-desk to housekeeping. (Our transportation arrangements resulted in our arrival several hours before official check-in, but we were allowed immediate check-in to an available room - a blessing as the outside temps were mid 90s). Our 12th fl corner room was directly over Canal St, but extremely quiet, and offered a great view uptown, including the Empire State Building. Room furnishings, bedding, climate-control, flatscreen TV, and bathroom toiletries are very modern and high-quality. The 'Traditional' King (standard) room is typical NYC size (sufficient for two, but not a lot of additional space to move around), has an armoire for hanging clothes, but no chests of drawers for other storage. A single business-type desk chair offers the only sitting / eating opportunity, other than the bed itself (besides a very low -to-the-floor ottoman). We found the elevators to be very prompt (despite others' reference to the contrary in these posts- and the requirement to insert your key-card to gain access to your floor offers enhanced guest security). We had a decent rate, and highly recommend this hotel, and would rank it at the higher-end of Sheraton quality (easily 3.5 stars), with a caveat that an upgrade in room might be in order if you desire more spacious accommodations.

I booked this hotel through www.priceline.com and got a great deal I couldn't find anywhere else. The Sheraton was brand new and modern. I found the bed extremely comfortable and the room small (although thats the norm in NY!) but with every possible amenity! The one thing we did find though was that it was very noisy.. you could hear every time someone's door opened and closed (and they slammed) and people taking a shower you could hear... quite disruptive for sleep but that is the only negative.. (our room was on the 10th floor at the back of the hotel opposite side to Canal St)The location was a very short walk from the metro. Canal St isn't the most glamorous street in NY thats for sure but the Sheraton itself was great. They offer free internet in the lobby which was convenient.We did get involved in a fire alarm which made us miss our reservation at Tao but to be honest they were very good about it all and I enjoyed my stay!

My husband and I stayed the weekend here in May 2011. The hotel is pretty much brand new and you are walking distance to TriBeCa and SoHo. Several subway stops are close so we were also able to venture around other parts of New York. The room was small but very nicely appointed and comfortable. But hey, it's NYC so why stay in your room except to sleep!

This new ( about 10 months old in July 2011) Sheraton is located on Canal Street riight in the heart of one of my wife's favorite shopping areas. It is in Tribeca and very near SOHO which means scads of good restaurants to choose among. It is very close to many of the most handy subway lines. The staff are great! The club lounge is huge, and includes a great outdoors area....actually designed to be able to easily eat in...instead of having mostly sofas and soft chairs like most other lounges. Breakfast was a bit erratic but at least is supposed to include eggs, sausage, bacon and potatoes plus normal continental breakfast stuff. Only real complaint was that it was suspicously difficult to to get a cab at 4 PM...we gave up after 20 minutes and had to take one of the relatively pricey ($50 to LaGuardia was quoted, but we negotiated down a bit) limos the bellmen offered "right away".

I recently stayed at the Sheraton TriBeCa while on a business trip. I found the hotel to be conveniently located to both the Financial District and SoHo. The staff were extremely nice and outgoing. A great place to stay while on vacation or on a business trip.

Hotel is on Canal Street - so a busy, noisy area but it was very clean, small but reasonably sized room, and excellent service. A good option and the only reason I might not stay here again is a preference for midtown area of NYC...

Some friends and I stayed here for two nights in July. Location's decent - a 6-minute walk to the Subway, and plenty of little shops & restaurants also within walking distance. The Starbucks in the lobby is nice and the staff were helpful (as was the in-room Starbucks coffee and - almost a rarity - milk creamers!) It would have been nice to have mini fridges in the rooms, though.The bartender in the lobby lounge was quite nice - he gave me some snack mix even though I wasn't drinking - just waiting for my friends for dinner and lightly complained of hunger.Check-in staff were efficient and friendly. When I accidentally left the "do not disturb" sign on the door before heading out for the day, I got back and called the front desk for certain supplies. They were brought up promptly, and I appreciated that. Negatives: No real big negatives. There was a spot of something that looked like blood on the pure white duvet cover. There was no luggage rack in the room. The gym was nice but did not appear to have any free weights (not that I ended up using the gym - no time). The elevators were slow at peak times and once I could not get on one and had to wait another 6 minutes for the next one. It would have been nice to have two boxes of Kleenex (one in the bathroom and one outside in the room itself). The pillows were awful - some sort of foam material that felt like it was smothering my head - could not sleep the first night. I then requested down pillows and it seemed to help, although still not perfect. The decor was "bland-modern". The shower was nice and the toiletries were of good quality. I liked the full-length mirror beside the wardrobe.I heard there is some sort of open terrace on a upper floor, but I didn't get to see it. I did not eat in the restaurant situated in the hotel lobby.Overall, a nice stay. But I do wonder about the other options out there for apprx $275 per night.

My husband and I stayed here for a week. We enjoyed being away from all the tourists, and several metro lines were close by. If you want a quiet area with good restaurants stay here. The room was clean, cool, and comfortable.

We had enjoyed our stay until items left in the room ended up "missing" - or as the hotel staff repeatedly referred to them as "misplaced" - I tried to get the hotel to locate the items taken out of my room without success.

I usually like Sheraton's, but unfortunately this one is not what I've come to expect from the brand.... First the good: friendly, helpful staff; usual Sheraton good computer area in lobby, given requested room (higher floor with king bed), nice view.However.... the Fitness Room left much to be desired~ some cardio machines and only ONE weight machine (which was being used by someone for most of the 30 min I was there)- no dumbbells (even though posters showed exercises needing them), not even resistance bands. There is no pool, which is usual at most Sheraton's, and I wouldn't want to be out in the neighbourhood after dark alone. I agree with the previous comment, you could probably stay at another hotel to get more value (I was eyeing the nearby Courtyard)... C'est la vie!

I stay at Sheratons all the time for business in the NYC area. This hotel was new so I figured I would give it a try. The location is good...close to the N,R, Q subway station and right on Canal street. It's an easy walk to some great food and entertainment in any direction. You're within easy reach of Little Italy, Chinatown, Tribecca, SoHo, and WTC. The lobby is small but nice and they have the standard Link setup for computer and internet usage. There's a Starbucks in the hotel which is cool. The fitness center is basically just a couple pieces of cardio equipment and a mat. No free weights at all. But I am a 24 hour member and there's an Ultra club right up the street in SoHo.The rooms are OK. Mine was clean but small (but this is pretty common in NYC). The elevators are a bit slow which is kind of a nuisance. They participate in the SPG Green program, which is pretty cool (so you can stack up on Starpoints).Overall, I would definitely stay there again. I really liked the location and the fact the everything was new was a nice perk.

Stayed three times in the hotel in June, always for one night. The first time we got such a small room, that there was no space to move, unpack, or anything. Literally, this was the smallest room I have ever had in NY, including Four Point by Sheraton Chelsea... The reason we got such a small room as Starwood Platinum was that we checked in early, requested a quiet room and there were no better rooms, and to do room change in the afternoon the front desk made it soo complicated, that it did not work out. So if you do need to check in early, make sure you are getting the room you like, rather that bother with the room change later. It is better to drop your bags, and check in later when usually better selection of rooms is available. To be fair the agent who checked us in, did try to arrange to move us to a better room, but the new shift was less than forthcoming with the move. The following morning the agent confided she could not sleep for putting us in such a small room.Two subsequent times we were allocated a much larger room, and the experience was much much better. Those rooms had Canal St orientation, and window insulation was good, the noise did not bother the sleep, and a bonus was a fabulous view of midtown as well as over Soho.The hotel gives a complimentary access to Club lounge for Starwood Platinums. They do have some cheeses, appetizers in the evening and some not very impressive breakfast spread. Please see a picture of available drinks in the lounge. I find it strange that having invested in the lounge, nicely furnished it, hotel does not bother to take drinks out of their cartons before stocking the fridge... It is also worth mentioning that the lounge is connected to an open-air terrace with amazing views as well.The location of the hotel makes it a good option for someone needing to be in financial district or Soho, Tribeca areas. It is easy to access both 1 and 6 lines of subway, and Tribeca has many restaurants within walking distance.

The hotel is in a prime location with two different subway stations just a few blocks away and the much quieter south end of town. The hotel was spotless all the time. The employees were polite and went above and beyond to be helpful at all times from the desk clerk to the housekeepers. The rooms were absolutely imaculantly clean and perfect. Good sized rooms and the most comfortable bed I have ever slept on. Will stay here again.
Not terrible, but you could find something in a better area for the same price. Also, the floors were dirty, both in the room and the corridors, and the air conditioning was loud.

Just completed a one night stay during a quick trip to NYC for work. I was very disappointed in the room size and layout. Extremely cramped and dark. The bathroom was tiny and more befitting a 1970s Holiday Inn with only the most basic amenities. And I purportedly received a "Deluxe" room. Unclear as to whether that was a Platinum upgrade. I hope not. Appears that this is a very old property so Sheraton was probably quite limited in what it could do with the place. It is absolutely not a Category 5 so don't be fooled. This is really a tourist hotel. A low 4 because of the great location (directly adjacent to Soho though Canal Street is not a nice street as everyone knows) and well maintained common areas. The Club Lounge and rooftop deck are very attractive. And the staff quite professional and friendly. I'm glad my stay was short as the room would have given me fits had I stayed there for any length of time. I have stayed at the Four Points Soho and think it's a better choice if you are in the area.

My husband and I stayed here this past weekend and absolutely love the hotel. We are Starwood Gold members so we used points and got a room on the 22nd floor, and access to the club lounge. The club lounge food is unexceptional and limited of course (it's free so no complaints!), but the view from the terrace is phenomenal! Our room was a standard size for NYC, which are almost always on the smaller size which is just fine. We had a floor to ceiling view of Canal Street which was great as we saw all the hustle and bustle of this very lively area. As always the beds at Sheraton are the most comfortable you will ever sleep in at a hotel - seriously. The air conditioner worked perfect and was ultra-quiet. The shower pressure was just right in a big walk-in shower so lots of room. The room was very clean and "fresh" with cool white sheets, pillows and soft fluffy comforter. The lounge bar was very nice and they have a vast selection of beers - even a seasoned beer connoisseur would be impressed and the barkeep, Tomas, was very helpful and pleasant! You are close to SOHO and China Town, and of course in the heart of TriBeca. We saw a concert at City Winery, which was within walking distance. We ate at Aqua Grill (FAB!!), also within walking distance. Had brunch at Landmarc, so good and within walking distance. We also took in the shady park on W. Broadway, literally around the corner from the hotel. We took a cab to Battery Park ($6 fare), to walk along the Hudson - so nice! You have it all here. We have stayed at almost every Starwood’s facility in NYC and this is our new favorite: great hotel, friendly staff, and clean comfortable room in a really great downtown area of NYC.

My husband and I headed up for just one night to catch a baseball game and made the Sheraton our home base. Quick highlights - great staff, very friendly and informative all around with directions, restaurant suggestions and cab info to the airport. Room was clean, water was hot, plenty of towels. Hotel is right next door to a 24 hour convenience shop which was great for more reasonably priced sodas and snacks. Also good location for the subway, shopping and general fun. Felt very secure here in the big city, no issues or challenges with being right on Canal Street. I would recommend this hotel and would certainly return.

When I am doing business in this part of town, I will be looking to stay here again. Close to subways, food, and our data center!The hotel feels new. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful. The rooms were a bit small, but perfectly outfitted. Charging for internet is old school, but I don't need it.Overall very good deal!

Adult Family Ladies: Mom, 2 daughters, sister-in-law, Daughter-in-law recently enjoyed a trip to exciting New York City. We stayed at Sheraton Tribeca thru recommendation of a friend. It was the Best ! The Staff went out of their way to accommodate our early arrival, letting us store our bags, and getting us into our room way before check-in time.The Staff was very attentive, very helpful and always eager to accommodate our every need . Michael, the Doorman, was outstanding ... always so pleasant and helpful ... As there were 5 of us we couldn't get taxis so we used the clean, new SUVs always out on the curb ... they were new, clean, and great drivers ! Also,, used the subway which was just steps away ... great experience, there as well. NYC was clean, safe and so enjoyable. Rooms were nice and the Beds .... So Comfortable !!!! Great Location !!!!!!!!

I wasn't sure about staying at a Sheraton as I usually like a boutique hotel but liked the location and the price! This hotel is only about 8 months old so it is very clean. Had a wonderful woman check us in around 4pm Saturday (can't remember her name). We were upgraded to club level. The location is wonderful for people who really aren't that interested in mid-town etc. We were able to walk to Soho shops and great places to eat in the village. It really was a good choice and the terrace has amazing views. I would go back to this hotel in a heartbeat.
bellman michael v. was knowledgable courteous and helpful and should be considered an asset to your organization.

This is not a 4 star hotel in my opinion. The standard rooms are very small, not claustrophobic small, but small for the price. I saw 3 rooms, the first had scuffs all up the wall and hair on the bathroom floor. The second was a corner room which was dark and had only a tiny corner window. We thought we had better keep the 3rd room we saw - it had a slightly better layout, but there were still hairs on the bathroom floor, and a small blood stain on the quilt. Apart from this, the room was clean and fairly comfortable, though there were noisy air conditioning units outside on the roof of the building next door.It was memorial day weekend, and pretty full, but even though we had booked a long time in advance, we were only left with the scuzzy rooms to choose from, because they allocate on a first come first served basis, and we got there quite late in the afternoon.There is no free wifi in the rooms, but the business centre in the lobby was good - I don't think I ever waited to get on a computer even though the hotel was busy. We enjoyed the Starbucks in the lobby, too.The hotel is only a ten minute walk away from Whole Foods on Greenwich St (for anyone who cares about this).Overall, I would stay here again - but only if the price was right.

This is a new nice shiny hotel on Canal on the northern edge of Tribeca. It's conveniently located, particularly if you want to spend a lot of time downtown. The one thing that really bugged me is internet in your room is $9.95 per day. I thought having it free in your room was standard these days. Harrumph. It's free in the lobby, however I wasn't able to connect to it on my laptop (I didn't persevere though). There are about 7 computers in the lobby free for guests to use, but they're usually already taken in the morning, and the connection is SUPER SLOW. Also the fire alarm went off at 8 am two mornings of our stay. So that was kind of annoying. They need to sort that out.Other than that, the staff was really friendly and the bathrooms in particular are really nice.

We stayed at the sheraton tribeca for 4 nights as of 1 June. We'd booked through booking.com and therefore had a good deak, ie costs of less than usd 200 per night incl taxes. The room however was the smallest om the floor, we first thought we had a room with a view as we were located on the 20th floor but that didn't add anything special. We could barely fit our two suitcases in the room, so a bit more space to mover around would have been nice. But as said they do have slightly larger rooms from the view of the floor map. Furthermore the room was just fine. Clean with a good bed. And as we were out most of the time that was all we needed. Bathroom was relatively spacious and modern so no complaints there. Internet in the lobby is complimentary, unfortunately you'll pay usd 10 per day in your room which felt a bit outdated. We didn't took the breakfast as there are enough possibilites closeby and nobody seems to take the breakfast. Then, location. Well Canal Street isn't much fun. But you're on the edge of SoHo and so after crossing the street you're in anice neighbourhood after all. We spent a lot of time strolling though SoHo, Little Italy, Chinatown and West Village, all within walking distance from the hotel. So if we come across a good deal again I think we would stay in the hotel again... I would say: the hotel is just nice and if you're looking for a three star hotel in the area you'll be in the good place.

We were 5 ladies traveling to see New York after a cruise. We only had 2 days and werent expecting much from a 2 night stay (heck, we didnt need much), but Michael V. and the desk staff were fast, friendly, and fun. No issues at all. Called for extra pillows, they were there in 5 minutes. Called for a wine key and glasses, they were there in 5 minutes. Early check in, they at least got us into 1 room to relax while the second was being finished. The suggestion for pizza around the corner at Saluggi's was fantastic!! Will come back here again for sure with the family next time. :)

My family and I found ourselves in a difficult situation with housing recently and needed to stay in a hotel near our children's school. The Sheraton Tribeca was like all other hotels in the area and quite full. the director of sales was very helpful in getting us a place to stay and we were able to check in on the date we hoped....first experience "relief and thanks".when we checked into the hotel we were met by Michael, Jarrett and team who quickly recognized we were a little out of sorts and made sure we were taken care of....second experience "friendly hospitality" . our check in was smooth and well handled and we were helped to our room with quite a bit of luggage....third experience "efficient grace and control".during our time there the entire team was kind to our children, truly interested in us as a family and generally just good people to us at every opportunity. As I was sensitive to the whole experience I was aware that they were treating everyone the same way, and that felt good - like they were really just good people, not doing it "for us" - they meant it and we could tell.upon check out I met with Zakia who was gracious, kind and helpful as well as professional. ..as well as Jaleel who was also helpful. I wish I could remember everyones name that we came in contact with but thank you from our family to all of you and the management team at this hotel for creating a positive environment. the hotel was clean, fresh and modern. room was perfectly fine and quiet....our housekeeping team was also on top of the situation which we appreciated....but at the end of the day the stay at this hotel was made by the people who work there. thank you all.

We had a flawless weekend at the Sheraton Tribeca, we had been relocated from another Starwood Property, and in fact, more or less upgraded. While it was a little bit of trouble logistically, the staff I worked with wanted to make sure I was fully taken care of during the process, and indeed we were. Would definitely stay there again.

We stayed here weekend 6/11 for my son's wedding. We had booked 13 rooms with points and cash and many of our friends also stayed here on their own. We had scoped this hotel out on 2 previous trips. We were thrilled with our entire stay. Not 1 negative.We had complicated room reservations which were handled with ease by front desk manager and asst front desk director-I wish I remembered their names!!The rooms were clean ,great for sleep-NOT noisy. We ventured around block for coffee at Colombe-the best. We enjoyed the hotel bar 1 night with guests-fun. We always ahd atxis when needed. The front bellman Michael V helped on many occasions to pack our multiple suitcases and wedding things with ease and was so friendly.What can I stay-it was the best and made our wedding weekend a breeze.Thanks

I was greated with kindness and respect the moment my cab pulled up in front of the hotel by Michael V. He saw my last name on my luggage which he had unloaded from the cab the moment it stopped, and welcomed me by my last name. I was not feeling well and he escorted me into the hotel and introduced me to the front desk where I was able to check in early to recover. The front desk clerk was quietly, quickly accomodating and I was in my room in a few minutes with my luggage delivered. The remaining of the 4 day stay, I was treated with courteous help from the room service staff to my housekeeper to the bell staff and upon checkout. When you arrive in a city not feeling well, this service was so reassuring. Thank you again for your care.

The hotel is in a good location, close to subway lines and walking distance to many SOHO restaurants. The rooms are quite new and the bed is comfortable. too bad I could not sleep too much. I have stayed in the hotel for 7 nights and was awaken everyday by a squeaking noise in the morning. On the third morning day I realized the noise came from the elevator door (unfo my room was close to the elevators..), spoke to the reception and they said they were going to take a look at it, no offers to change room or anything like that, just reassured me that they would take care of the problem. I went out for the day, came back late in the evening to be waken up in the following morning by the same noise. Complained again, heard their promises to solve it and next morning more squeaking.. by the 6th day I had given up complaining, it was simply not working. The funny thing is that I was actually expecting to be asked on the check out how my stay went, but no questions were asked. The staff really did not care. Will not stay in this hotel, and have serious doubts on how Sheraton is training its staff in NY, a shame. Do not recommend this hotel to anyone looking for a hotel to relax.

I stayed here in May for 4 nights and had a great time. It's in a fun location right next to China town and walking distance to some great restaurants...TriBeCa Grill, Locanda Verde, and Bubbys to name a few. The rooms are TINY but we didn't mind as we don't spend much time in them. Everything was great until check-out. We checked our bags with the bellman because our flight didn't leave until 5:30. We told him we needed a cab later and he talked us into taking one of the town cars out front. I'm a frequent visitor to NYC and know that these can be a rip off so we declined at first but he insisted that they were trustworthy drivers and it would be $60 tip and tax included. We asked several times if he was SURE there wouldn't be any other charges. Once again we were reassured there were no hidden costs. We decided to go with it as it seemed the Sheraton was endorsing it. We also made sure the driver knew ahead of time we were going to two different terminals. When we arrived at the first terminal and my friend was getting her baggage out the driver told us we owed him $65 for the ride to the airport and another $15 to go to another terminal. We told him we weren't paying him anything extra as we had already negotiated the price with the bellman. He told us he didn't care what the bellman said, we owed him more. I got on the phone and called the Sheraton and explained our situation to the woman who answered. I asked if this was some kind of scam they were running on their guests. She assured me no it wasn't, their drivers are very trustworthy. She then connected me to the front desk where I explained again what was happening and this woman got the bellman on the phone who requested to speak to the driver. I handed my cell phone to the driver and after a few minutes the driver hands me my phone back and tells me fine, I'll drive you to the next terminal and he was not happy about it. I didn't feel comfortable getting in his car so I said no thank you and took the airbus to my terminal. Again, I wouldn't NEVER have taken the car if the bellman hadn't reassured me over and over that it was a trustworthy service. If I didn't have the nerve to call the hotel or had been in a big hurry I would have had to pay the driver more. I was disappointed in the Sheraton for allowing something like this to happen but was relieved the situation was handled promptly. I've lost some faith in them though, and I will probable stay elsewhere next time.

My husband and I stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca just to get away for a night. We chose this hotel because we could stay using SPG points and because my husband works in midtown and wanted to get away from his work environment. The location is a good, central to lots of great downtown neighborhoods. The hotel is very clean, our room was nicely appointed and we had a wonderful view of the midtown skyline. The standard room isn't big, but it's fine for New York standard. The staff was helpful and friendly. They gave us a GREAT dinner restaurant, just around the corner called Pepolino. The staff was all smiles, a really friendly crew. There is a basic bar in the lobby and a nice breakfast area for a quick coffee and bite to eat. I would recommend this hotel as a no frills, but a clean and friendly stay. Very nice. No complaints from me!
Overall we had a great stay and I would recommend this place. Plenty of train stations nearby to get you to where you want to go.

Huge room for a "standard" in NYC. It's a great location and surprisingly quiet for being directly on Canal. I was traveling with a small child and the entire staff remembered his name, greeted him in the morning - even recalled the name of his stuffed animal. A great home base for sight-seeing and taking in all of New York. The only thing i would ask is that - DUDE, for the price, how about free wi-fi?
The staff at this hotel is very friendly and helpful. I especially want to commend Zakiya for going out of her way to help me and a colleague find a quiet place to work on a project.

We had the pleasure of staying here in April 2011 for about 10 nights. We were in New York City for the Tribeca Film Festival as we were part of a film that had its World Premiere there ( Love Hate Love). ALL the staff at Sheraton Tribeca ensured our stay with them was delightful. Nothing was ever a problem for them and they went out of their way to make our stay memorable. Lowell the General Manager went out of his way to ensure our stay was perfect. It was great to be witness to a GM that doesnt just stay in his office and was constantly seen mingling with guests and making sure their stay at his hotel was a memorable and hassle free one. The hotel and our room were immaculately presented and we certainly will be staying here again when we return to New York City.
The hotel is located at chinatown. Horrible Street. There is no safe or minibar at the rooms, the breakfast is bellow the average. Definitely not a Sheraton.

We book our room our priceline.com and got it for $169 a night. We requested to have 2 beds in our room because I really didn't feel like sleeping in the same bed as my father. We took the subway to our hotel since it was about a 10 minute subway trip and the A,C or E train had a stop right at Canal street and put us within about 200 yards of the hotel.When we walked into the hotel we were greeted right away by a bellman with a smile and can I take your bags. Not being pushy but really helpful. We then walked to the front desk and tried to check in early and then our only problem with the hotel popped up. We had booked 2 rooms that were suppose to have 2 double beds in each room. Well that didn't happen. Priscillia, was the young lady checking us in. She jump onto the problem and corrected it right away with a smile. She gave us one room early and told us the other one wasn't ready yet which was fine with us. We took our bags up to one room and went on with our day.When we came back we got our room keys for the room that wasn't ready. We were upgraded and didn't know it yet. I have pictures of the room that I will post very soon but we were given a room with a porch that was as big as our room. It had a table and four chairs with it and it was a great place for the four guys to hang out and have a couple drinks and wind down from the hustle and bustle of the busy New York streets!! There wasn't a view to die for but if you know New York hotel rooms, you know they are very cramp and small, so to have this huge porch was great!!

First I want to say is that I work for a hotel so I know the procedures very well. I booked a room with DD for 2 adults and a teenager. I know room types are not guaranteed but I've never heard of being charged extra for another bed. Then I asked for a possible upgrade and how much, they came back with a "suite" which has a sofa bed in it hat was an additional $150 for the same size room but with a sofa bed. I know a suite is usually bigger than a standard room and more money. So basically all 3 of us slept on the king bed. So if you stay here with your family please be prepared to sleep together or spend more money. The only good thing about this hotel was the location!!!

Just built in october, nice, clean and contemporary hotel. Located on canal street, right across the street was the edge of SOHO, short walk to the west side and Chelsea districts.Great shopping and galleries close by the hotel.I would stay again.

Of the star wood collection I find Sheraton the least consistent. This is a new and well located Sheraton. Nothing special in the rooms, but perfectly clean and functional. The lounge is very well stocked for such a small space. Staff all excellent except one manager who clearly has not heard the notion that the customer is always right. After a heated exchange with me about room rates for a colleague he was properly overruled by another manager who apparently had heard the dictum. He looked foolish.Pass on the restaurant...truly horrible. Lots of great eateries close by. Would happily stay again.

The Sheraton Tribeca met our expectations and more. The club level observation deck has a beautiful view and the continental breakfast exceeded our expectations. The room was clean, and while not exceptionally big, it was modern and had a great view. The shower was great and the water pressure was perfect.The Sheraton Tribeca is located on the border of Tribeca and Soho. There is lots of shopping to be had on Broadway, which is only 4 or so blocks away. Walking distance to Chinatown and Little Italy make for a nice visit as well. If you are a vegetarian, there is a place called 'Dojo' at 14 W 4th St(Btwn Bway & Mercer St). They have an excellent Soy Burger dinner with a soy burger patty, salad and brown rice for 5.25.. Thats right, only 5 bucks, unheard of for a dinner/lunch in Manhatten. Its a casual sit down place that also serves beer/ liquor.If you are looking to save money on your stay at the Sheraton Tribeca, there are some great options. If you need a quick snack, there is a cheap deli next door with everything from pizza, to sandwiches, subs and more. On the corner of W. Broadway and Canal there is a Bodega where you can buy beer to bring to your room if you dont want to spend crazy money on booze at the bars or club. If you have club-level access you can bring your drinks up to the 21st floor observation deck and enjoy the sights and sound of the city in style. If I had one complaint, it would be this. I booked my trip on Priceline.com and was supposed to get a Deluxe King room, with Club Level access. On check in there was no mention of the club access and when I tried to access the 21st floor for the club lounge I was denied entry and had to call down and explain to them my situation. They were happy to help, and looked up my reservation, and confirmed that I was indeed supposed to have that access, so Im not sure why it was missed in the first place. It caused some embarrassment, as I booked the room as a surprise for my girlfriends birthday and when the key card didnt work to the club lounge, the surprise was cut short and spoiled as we had to back to the room to call the front desk.Thats a small thing I guess overall, and my suggestion would be to make sure inadvance that they know you have club level access if you book through an outside source. It will save yourself some time/ embarrassment/ hassle.I travel to NYC frequently and would most likely stay there again.

We loved the Sheraton Tribeca. Staff was the best especially Paul R. Any time we needed help he was always there to assist us with anything. He went above and beyond for us and we will come back because of him. There was one bellman though who was a little to friendly and a little too energetic and was always around us to much. It made me and my family feel uncomfortable and I think his name was david but other than that everyone else was fantastic.

I wrote once previously about this hotel and gave it a great review, however I think the true test of a hotel is in it's consistency. I have stayed at the Sheraton Tribeca on Canal Street four times. I typically come in on business but the last time I stayed an extra day to enjoy New York. The beds are so comfortable that I get a beetter night sleep here then at home. I think I need a new bed at home. The staff is extremely helpful without that New York edge that many hotels have. The location can't be beat. a $6 cab ride lands you in midtown and the subway is just around the corner if you want to save a couple of dollars. One tip is that some cab drivers do not know where the hotel is. Just tell them that it is next to the post office on canal street. This hotel has it all: location, good value, comfortable rooms, good food, convenience and a delightful staff. You just can not go wrong. I stay in 80 hotels a year and this is my favorite.

This hotel is very nice, has it all going for it. It is close to Soho, Tribeca, Little Italy, NoLita. The rooms were a nice size for NYC, and the concierge floor was very nice. We were given an upgrade due to Starwood Status. Maryann, the concierge was excellent and tried to please in every way. We have stayed at the Sheraton Soho which has a more neighborhood feel, but this one is literally on Canal Street, a part of Chinatown. It is only a ten minute walk to less hustle bustle and has a lot of computers for your use on the main floor that are free for you to use, and a Starbucks and nice Bar too. Really great property especially if you have things to do in the Tribeca area. Nice Gym too.

I was very impressed with the reviews for this hotel, so I booked a three nights' stay with my daughter, who is 18 years old. The hotel itself was OK - the bed was comfortable and the bathroom was nice. Tiny room, though. Our room backed on to a huge Post Office sorting centre, so I could hear the vans loading up early in the morning! We would generally arrive back at the hotel at around 11:00pm and the walk back from the subway was quite unnerving as there were quite a few "colourful" characters around at that time of night. I would have felt fine if my husband had been with us, but we really felt vulnerable.The deli next door was a great place to grab breakfast or a late night snack - I believe it's open 24 hours.In hindsight, we would have been better off staying closer to Time Square, where we spent most of our evenings watching shows.

Nadir in the hospitally room went out of his way to get us honey or whatever we needed. Micheal V. always managed to get us a cab. He works from his heart and the Sheraton is lucky to have these people. Jarrett was a doll too.
i had an amazing stay at this hotel it's very clean and no bed bugs what else do you want me : nothing more only thing missing free wi-fi in the rooms

Stayed 2 nights at the Sheraton Tribeca NY. Took the kids there for spring break to see the sights.
